Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
>>          Can anybody please suggest some good
>>books/resources/websites/ebooks for network
>>security.
> 
> *) Applied Cryptography by Bruce Shneier (around 40$)
> (Bible of every cryptographer)

He's asking about network security - and while crypto is a useful thing 
to know in that field, it is not the only thing around.

Read through the linux network administrators guide (NAG) - its 
available online, as well as published by o'reilly.

That will do for a start .. and there are other resources you can read 
once you have the basics in place.

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> You cannot rule out a hardware issue here in the NIC chip of the 
> ethernet card. What card is it? Realtek? Intex?

It is a card that was bought from HP. It has a The Intel 82546EB Dual
Port Gigabit Ethernet Controller.

> You can check for hardware problem by stressing the receive path of 
> the NIC. Only recv causes interrupts and NICs normally expose their 
> problem that way.

If the recv has an issue., then even the ping replies from the
cisco-router should get screwed. However., that does not happen.
Everything seems fine till the router. We are able to ping every other
NIC that is connected to the same switch.

However., I'm still waiting for the issue to occur so that I can grab a
tcpdump and see what is happening.

> Anyway pls observe the problem for some time and theorize after you 
> have data. Observe tcpdump output for a while. What particular packet
>  exchange causes this behavior? Or is it after a certain period of 
> time?

Yeah. I'm not in the campus right now., so i'm talking with the admins
there to start tcpdump to log interesting traffic till the issue occurs.

Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
> If its a dirt cheap and poor quality ethernet card like one of those,
> then it is quite likely to get solved by replacing the card

The NIC is a HP card having a The Intel 82546EB Dual Port Gigabit
Ethernet Controller.

> Another thing - if that router is also the NAT gateway for your
> office PCs, then see if you cant seperate your LAN gateway IP and
> your mailserver IP .. you wont have junk traffic from your LAN [and
> infected systems, older windows installs etc can generate a ton of
> that], and this problem would be minimized even more.

The entire local network is behind the proxy-server shown in the diagram
(check http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/pipermail/ilugc/2006-July/027566.html).
The proxy-server has a Squid running on it for HTTP traffic., and is the
NAT gateway for SMTP, POP3, NNTP, XMPP and IRC. No local traffic comes
beyond the proxy-server.

In-Reply-To: <20060801063620.51905.qmail@web35607.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Message-ID: <44CEF9D3.5020500@frodo.hserus.net>

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> And for someone asking for books or resources I
> thought it pertinent to start with basic and crypto
> was the least common denominator for everything. 

Schneier and a few other things would sidetrack you into going too deep 
into crypto.

Start with basic concepts such as those described in sag / nag for good 
systems and network design and security

layer crypto on top of that .. you'll pick up a working knowledge as you 
go along, without having to go as deep into crypto theory initially

in fact picking up schneier without having a good, solid foundation in 
systems and network admin, design etc is not a productive thing to do

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Aug  1 00:41:10 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Aug  1 13:11:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Monthly reminder: mailing list guidelines
Message-ID: <20060801074110.25498.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

This is a monthly reminder to members of this list
about the posting guidelines. Please don't reply to
this e-mail. If you'd like to update it, do it here:

http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/List_Guidelines

1. Use a proper subject line.

2. Do not troll in the mailing list

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll

3. Use [OT] for off-topic messages and general
discussions or use ilugc-non-tech at googlegroups.com.

4. Do not top-post:

Link: http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

Example of a top-post:

   Because it messes up the order in which 
   people normally read text.
   > > Why is top-posting 
   > > such a bad thing?
   Top-posting.
   > > What is the most 
   > > annoying thing in e-mail?

Always use bottom-posting.

> What is your name ?
  My name is ILUGC.

5. Do not over-quote:

Example of an over-quote:

>>> On Friday you said
>>>  blah blah blah
>> On Saturday you said
>>  foo foo foo
> On Sunday you said
>  foobar

6. Do not post HTML messages

7. Do not recycle messages

8. Do not send attachments

9. Do not attach obnoxious, nonsensical legal
disclaimers. If your company uses disclaimers, don't
use your company ID for the mailing list.

10. Do not reply to a digest. (If you are in digest
mode and want to reply to a post use ILUGC Gmane blog
interface.

Link:
http://blog.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

11. Search for answers for your questions/problems in
google.com or any other search engine before posting
your query to the mailing list.

If any of the above are not clear to you, Please read
the detailed list guidelines:

Link:
http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

12. Do not post messages in all capital letters. Mails
in CAPS is considered rude and is similar to shouting
during a conversation.

13. If you or your company is into GNU/Linux
migration, or you want help into GNU/Linux migration,
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/GNU_Linux_migration

14. If you are looking for GNU/Linux distro CDs please
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab

15. Following these guidelines could be helpful:
http://people.debian.org/~enrico/dcg/

16. Don't send season's greetings or birthday invites
to the group. Its not mailing list etiquette.

We must use the above guidelines to maintain better
readability, proper archives, efficient bandwidth
usage, etc. 

Thank you.

__________________________________________________

Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around 
http://mail.yahoo.com

> --- Balachandran Sivakumar <contactsbala@gmail.com>
> wrote:
>
> > Hello all,
> >
> >           Can anybody please suggest some good
> > books/resources/websites/ebooks for network
> > security.
> *) Applied Cryptography by Bruce Shneier (around 40$)
> (Bible of every cryptographer)
>
> *)Handbook of cryptography
> (http://www.cacr.math.uwaterloo.ca/hac/) Too
> mathematical - stay away from it! :-) But it is free
> to download.
>
> *) A simple google search will throw up lot of links.
> Many of which are good. I used to like the FAQ in
> www.rsasecurity.com
>
> Bear in mind that certain concepts like public key
> cryptography take a *lot* of time to understand and
> sink in.
>
> Even "The Code Book" by Simon Singh is good.
>
> For practical exposure to crypto I suggest you join
> openssl-users@openssl.org and install and try out
> www.openssl.org
>
> This comes standard with all Unices these days.
>
> You could also take a look at
>
> www.openbsd.org once you get really hooked onto
> crypto. They have a browseable CVS interface of the
> entire source tree and you will find lot of treasures
> there. Especially kernel crypto used for IPsec,
> hardware engines and so on.
>
> I think it is /usr/src/sys/crypto for crypto code.
>
> And IPsec is under /usr/src/sys/netinet
>
> But take one step at a time. It is a penance of
> several years.
>
> Wish you all the best!
>
> Crypto is the most fascinating topic and the smartest
> brains on the planet are at work in it!
>
> Best,
> Girish
> >
> > also please give some sites where network secutiry
> > related code can be
> > downloaded.

--- Hari <namasthe09@yahoo.com> wrote:

> 
>   Also Shneier is inaccessible and expensive. I read
> it
> only after a couple of years exp with crypto.
> 
> HTH.
> 
> Is it possible to have a session on this topic,which
> can serve as a launchpad into the topic .....One
> that will give an over all overview about the topics
> career prospects and stuff

Sure. I had given a talk on IPsec at IIT in March. You
should find the slides on the LUG website. 

I have hands on experience in various aspects of
crypto  but I need to know what topics you are
interested in.

Please collect your thoughts and needs. Whether you
want to do it offlist or otherwise you decide. We also
have to make sure people are really interested.

At least from whatever response I got from IPsec talk
I think people do have interest but it will help me
and you both immensely if you can tell me what topics
are of immediate interest and relevace.

I will get you started by whatever little I can do.

*) Intro to security ( symmetric and asymmetric
crypto, RSA, AES, DH, Blowfish, DES , hashing and
message digests(MD5, SHA*),HMAC, signatures,
authentication etc..)

*) Security protocols(SSL/TLS,IPsec, ssh, VPNs, MPLS,
auth protocols like challenge response, single sign
on)

*) Security toolkits (OpenSSL, kernel crypto, hardware
acceleration) 

*) Security programming (buffer overflows, key
management strategies,password hashing,storage, vm
encryption, cryptographic file systems)

*) PKI (X.509 certificates, web of trust, OCSP, CA,
CRL etc...)

*) Firewalls and spam control ( stateful and stateless
firewalls, TCP scrubbing, port forwarding, reverse
NAT, binat, TCP proxy) and spamassasin, mime-defrag,
vipul's razor ( I have no clue about commercial
alternatives)

*) Security power tools like nmap, nessus, nc

*) Career prospects for security 

Kindly select a subset from the above that is of
interest to maximum number of people. 

Please respond fast or else the interest will get
whittled away. 

We will fix up a date that is convenient for everyone
and proceed. 

What say? :-)

Looking fwd to meeting you all soon. :-)

Best,
Girish

SpikeSource Interview on the following places:

CHENNAI

HYDERABAD
Interview Dates: 19th Aug 2006 to 20th August 2006

Time: 9AM to 6PM
Please direct resumes to sjha@spikesource.com

Following are the list of positions:
===========================

Job Title		:	Associate Software Engineer

Job Responsibilities:
1.Monitor updates to open source components containing fixes for
critical security issues/functionality bugs
2.Develop and maintain test cases
3.Use and  improve, patch, test, and reporting tools/processes
4.Review/provide content for technical articles

Qualifications & Experience :
1. BE/ B-Tech or BS in Computer Science or equivalent
2. 1.5-3years of work experience in the software industry
3. Proficiency in one or more of Java/C/C++/Perl/PHP/Python.
4. Excellent verbal and written communication skills
5. Experience developing or testing Open Source Linux, Apache, JBoss,
Tomcat, MySQL, PostgreSQL, Geronimo, Axis, Struts, RedCarpet highly
desired.
6. Flexible and confident with strong interpersonal and communication skills

======

Job Title		:	Software Engineer

Job Responsibilities:
1. Ensure high quality and timely delivery of critical updates to customers
2. Responsibilities of Associate Software Engineer PLUS
3. Help develop fixes for high severity issues in open source
components and contribute them to the community
4. Integrate component updates in multiple code lines
5. Help improve internal build, patch, test, and reporting tools/processes
6. Provide expertise and leadership in 1-2 major components and languages
7. Write technical articles

Qualifications & Experience :
1. BE/ B-Tech or BS in Computer Science or equivalent
2. 3 - 5years of work experience in the software industry
3. Proficiency and experience developing and debugging in 1 or more of
Java/C/C++/Perl/PHP/Python.
4. Flexible, confident, and enjoy the challenges of a fast-paced
environment with strong interpersonal and communication skills
5. Highly motivated, self-starter who can manage many tasks and meet
aggressive deadlines.
Process-oriented & Customer-focused, Pragmatic, analytical, and adept
at prioritization and trade-off

Desirable:
1. Experience white-box testing and/or code-line maintenance for a new
startup in enterprise infrastructure software based on open standards
and emerging technologies.
2. Experience in shipping a successfully deployed production quality products

====
Job Title		:	Senior Software Engineer

Job Responsibilities:
1. Responsibilities of Software Engineer PLUS
2. Develop fixes for high severity issues in open source components
and contribute them to the community
3. Review and contribute to internal tools/process improvements
regarding their effectiveness and efficiency
4. Provide expertise and leadership in 1-2 major components and languages
Responsible for successful maintenance of 1 major release and a few
minor releases with high quality and timely updates.

Qualifications & Experience :
1. BE/ B-Tech or BS in Computer Science or equivalent
2. 5 -8years of work experience in the software industry
3. Proficiency and experience developing and debugging in 2 or more of
Java/C/C++/Perl/PHP/Python.
4. Experience in various aspects of software development life-cycle
(SDLC) including porting, white-box testing, debugging, building, and
packaging large code-lines.
5. Experience/Knowledge in one or more of version control, build, code
coverage, and test tools such as maven, ant, httpunit, cvs,
subversion, phpcoverage, junit, simpletest, testgen4web, jmeter.
6. Experience and Expertise with one or more of Linux, Apache, JBoss,
Tomcat, MySQL, PostgreSQL, Geronimo, Axis, Struts, RedCarpet.
Process-oriented & Customer-focused, Pragmatic, analytical, and adept
at prioritization and trade-off
7. Experience white-box testing and/or code-line maintenance for a new
startup in enterprise infrastructure software based on open standards
and emerging technologies.
8. Highly motivated, self-starter who can manage many tasks and meet
aggressive deadlines. Previous experience in shipping a successfully
deployed production quality products
9. Flexible, confident, and enjoy the challenges of a fast-paced
environment and multiplexing amongst multiple tasks and wearing
multiple hats  with strong interpersonal and communication skills

=====

Job Title		:	Staff Engineer/ Sr. Staff Engineer	

Job Responsibilities:
1. Responsibilities of Senior Software Engineer PLUS
2. Responsible for successful maintenance of multiple releases with
high quality and timely updates.
3. Responsible for coordinating work teams and providing technical
support to project team members
4. Responsible for enhancing tools and processes to improve the
quality and timeliness of critical updates while we offer new products
and services to customers
5. Identify, design, and implement processes and tools to improve
effectiveness and efficiency of monitoring for critical updates to
open source components, integrating updates in multiple code lines,
performing builds, and performing tests.
6. Provide expertise and leadership in 2-3 major components and languages
Mentor and train new hires

Qualifications & Experience:

1. BE/ B-Tech or BS in Computer Science or equivalent
2. 8-12yrs of work experience in the software industry
3. Ability to do deep-dive in any of the languages/platforms used at
SpikeSource including Java/C/C++/Perl/PHP/Python.
4. Thorough understanding and strong experience in various aspects of
software development life-cycle (SDLC) including porting, white-box
testing, debugging, building, and packaging large code-lines.
5. Expert in 2 or more of version control, build, code coverage, and
test tools such as maven, ant, httpunit, cvs, subversion, phpcoverage,
junit, simpletest, testgen4web, jmeter highly desired.
6. Expert in 2 or more of Linux, Apache, JBoss, Tomcat, MySQL,
PostgreSQL, Geronimo, Axis, Struts, RedCarpet.
7. Process-oriented & Customer-focused, Pragmatic, analytical, and
adept at prioritization and trade-off
8. Experience white-box testing and/or code-line maintenance for a new
startup in enterprise infrastructure software based on open standards
and emerging technologies.
9. Highly motivated, self-starter who can manage many tasks and meet
aggressive deadlines. Previous experience in shipping a successfully
deployed production quality products
10. Flexible, confident, and enjoy the challenges of a fast-paced
environment and multiplexing amongst multiple tasks and wearing
multiple hats  with strong interpersonal and communication skills
11. Prior experience leading porting, testing, or maintenance efforts.
12. Demonstrated expertise in a variety of the field's concepts,
practices, and procedures.


====
Job Title		:	Lead / Senior Engineer
Division		: 	QA

Job Responsibilities:
1. Architect, design, implement, and support automated test and
certification framework.
2. Support internal development staff, offshore development centers,
support group to successfully test, and certify product releases and
patches.
3. Work closely with developers, partners, and customers to define the
testing services required for applications development in a reliable
and scalable environment.
4. Evaluate and select emerging open standards and testing components
to complement internal efforts.
5. Create project resource estimates, define hardware/software
configurations; provide technical directions and creative testing
solutions.
6. Define metrics to manage and improve release processes, defect
reports, defect prevention, development efficiency, and quality.

Qualifications & Experience:
1. BS in Computer Science or equivalent, MS preferred.
2. 5+ years experience testing enterprise-class server products preferred.
3. Proficiency in Java/C/C++ , hands on experience with scripting
languages like Perl, Python and with shell scripting environments like
Csh, Bash, etc.
4. Ability to write testing specs and automation scripts.
5. Experience with unit testing tools, code coverage tools, GUI test
automation tools and release management tools like CVS, Makefiles,
Ant.
6. Experience with testing client-server or web-based business
applications desired.
7. Previous experience in testing and shipping successfully deployed
production quality products in startup environments.
8. Experience with Linux, Apache, MySQL, Oracle-PL/SQL or any other
RDBMS highly desired.
9. Strong interpersonal and communication skills

======

BUILD & RELEASE - Lead & Senior ENGINEERS

Job Responsibilities:
- Responsible for designing, implementing, and supporting build
environment/framework for next generation runtime for enterprise
applications.
- Collate build requests, schedule, co-ordinate and monitor builds.
- Version control and tagging of builds.
- Build planning, procedures, scripting and automation.

Qualifications & Experience :
1. BE/BTech/MCA/BS in Computer Science or equivalent
2. 4 - 8 years of work experience in the software industry
3. Proficiency in doing builds and build automation.
4. Shell scripting knowledge.
5. Knowledge of CVS, Subversion or any other configuration management tools.
6. Knowledge of ant and maven.

Desirable:
- Highly motivated, self-starter who can manage many tasks and meet
aggressive deadlines. Previous experience in shipping a successfully
deployed production quality products.
- Process-oriented & Customer-focused, Pragmatic, analytical, and
adept at prioritization and trade-off.
- Flexible, confident, and enjoy the challenges of a fast-paced
environment and multiplexing amongst multiple tasks and wearing
multiple hats with strong interpersonal and communication skills.

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> What is the standard procedure and the LUG way of
> doing this? 

start talking - and assume a basal level of zero among your audience if 
you need to.  and you can scale up or down from that as you need.

cover the basics first - good systems and network design, and then 
include where you can bring encryption in, to secure the transaction 
further (https, starttls etc for common traffic like http and smtp, to 
start with, ipsec, tunnels, vpns etc for regular traffic ..)

On Wed, Aug 02, 2006 at 06:44:51AM -0700, Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
>more about
>1) good network design
>2) corporate VPN use ( I know only VPN theory)

well - you'd talk about concepts like a bastion host, dmz, etc.

This is a firewall vendor (netscreen)'s whitepaper but does spell out a few
of the concepts in quite clear language. Dates back to 2001 but still ok
http://www.defconpics.org/other/Principles%20of%20Secure%20Network%20Design.pdf

Some cisco press books like this one -
network security basics
http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=170742

and this -
general design considerations for secure networks
http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=174313&rl=1

are also worth a read.

The linux NAG has quite a lot of decent resources in it. 

But by far the best book on this that I know of is "The Practice of System
and Network Administration" by Limoncelli and Hogan
<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?link_code=ur2&tag=tomontime-20&camp=1789&creative=9325&path=external-search%3Fsearch-type=ss%26index=books%26keyword=0201702711>

That amazon link is from http://www.everythingsysadmin.com - the authors'
website, and so I guess the authors get a commission if you buy that from
amazon.  Everythingsysadmin.com has some great articles in it, worth a read

>Or do you want to join me in the talk? I am somewhat
>weak in those topics. It will be great if both of us
>share a two hour slot. 

I may not be able to make it this saturday - out of town. Sometime in the
near future hopefully.

Thanks Suresh. But this much is very clear that there
is no way I am going to be able to talk about these
things just by "bookish" knowledge even if I do find
time to read whatever you sent. 

So whichever weekend you are free we can meet. No
issues. 

Here is a first cut "syllabus" for the talk. Please do
let me know if you find that ok. I am also zero in
spam and it will be wonderful to learn that as well.
Especially Bayesian filtering and stuff. :-)

Security 101

1) What is authentication? 
2) Difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric crypto
3) Threat model and various types of attacks
4) What is RSA? DH? AES? 3DES? Anatomy of ciphering
5) Security on the Internet (securing protocols like
DNS, SMTP, SNMP, HTTP, FTP etc.)
6) Security protocols like SSL,ssh, IPsec

Network Security architecture and design

1) Threat model
2) DMZ, firewalls, proxies
3) Worms, Denial of service attacks on the routers and
TCP/IP infrastructure, discussion about the "Iloveu"
worm(virus?) and few other recent attacks and how you
patched the vulnerabilities
4) VPN design and considerations- implications on
networking, tunneling etc.
5) Spam control theory, architecture of participating
peers and real world examples from Vipul's razor ,
Spamassassin etc...

How you can get started onto the security bandwagon

1) Learn how to use the OpenSSL tool
2) I will demo simple usages of the tool
3) Used for encryption, signing, hashing, keypair
generation, random number generation etc...

Security as a career

1) Where to start and what does the market need?
2) Why security programming will make you a sound
programmer?
3) Need to understand networking very well to
implement security protocols
4) Huge demand for *good* security engineers in the
market. PKI,VPN, networking and crypto knowledge: how
to develop them?

Suresh,

I think I will spend the first 40 minutes intro. Then
you can take over and talk for about 50 minutes. Then
I will demo OpenSSL toolkit and finally wind up with a
light discussion on career options which you should
help me of course. 

Friends,

Have I captured everyone's need? Did I miss anything?

Suresh,

Let us first prepare the slides and send them. That
way at least I will get some time to prepare and ppl
can come knowing what to expect and possibly also come
prepared as security waters are very deep...

My suggestion is let us prepare the slides offlist and
send it as one pdf. 

Bharathi,

Could you arrange sometime this month or at most early
next month when Suresh is free so we can meet? 

Thanks. 

warm regards,
Girish

<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?link_code=ur2&tag=tomontime-
20&camp=1789&creative=9325&path=external-search%3Fsearch-type=ss%26index
=books%26keyword=0201702711>
> 
> That amazon link is from
> http://www.everythingsysadmin.com - the authors'
> website, and so I guess the authors get a commission
> if you buy that from
> amazon.  Everythingsysadmin.com has some great
> articles in it, worth a read
> 
> >Or do you want to join me in the talk? I am
> somewhat
> >weak in those topics. It will be great if both of
> us
> >share a two hour slot. 
> 
> I may not be able to make it this saturday - out of
> town. Sometime in the
> near future hopefully.

Thanks Suresh. But this much is very clear that there
is no way I am going to be able to talk about these
things just by "bookish" knowledge even if I do find
time to read whatever you sent. 

So whichever weekend you are free we can meet. No
issues. 

Here is a first cut "syllabus" for the talk. Please do
let me know if you find that ok. I am also zero in
spam and it will be wonderful to learn that as well.
Especially Bayesian filtering and stuff. :-)

Security 101

1) What is authentication? 
2) Difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric crypto
3) Threat model and various types of attacks
4) What is RSA? DH? AES? 3DES? Anatomy of ciphering
5) Security on the Internet (securing protocols like
DNS, SMTP, SNMP, HTTP, FTP etc.)
6) Security protocols like SSL,ssh, IPsec

Network Security architecture and design

1) Threat model
2) DMZ, firewalls, proxies
3) Worms, Denial of service attacks on the routers and
TCP/IP infrastructure, discussion about the "Iloveu"
worm(virus?) and few other recent attacks and how you
patched the vulnerabilities
4) VPN design and considerations- implications on
networking, tunneling etc.
5) Spam control theory, architecture of participating
peers and real world examples from Vipul's razor ,
Spamassassin etc...

How you can get started onto the security bandwagon

1) Learn how to use the OpenSSL tool
2) I will demo simple usages of the tool
3) Used for encryption, signing, hashing, keypair
generation, random number generation etc...

Security as a career

1) Where to start and what does the market need?
2) Why security programming will make you a sound
programmer?
3) Need to understand networking very well to
implement security protocols
4) Huge demand for *good* security engineers in the
market. PKI,VPN, networking and crypto knowledge: how
to develop them?

Suresh,

I think I will spend the first 40 minutes intro. Then
you can take over and talk for about 50 minutes. Then
I will demo OpenSSL toolkit and finally wind up with a
light discussion on career options which you should
help me of course. 

Friends,

Have I captured everyone's need? Did I miss anything?

Suresh,

Let us first prepare the slides and send them. That
way at least I will get some time to prepare and ppl
can come knowing what to expect and possibly also come
prepared as security waters are very deep...

My suggestion is let us prepare the slides offlist and
send it as one pdf. 

Bharathi,

Could you arrange sometime this month or at most early
next month when Suresh is free so we can meet? 

Thanks. 

warm regards,
Girish

I had done some research on gaming options in Linux. I
also read an article about it in linuxjournal. 

I never play any game other than "fortune" which is
not really a game. :-) So my analysis could be wrong. 

MythTV project(www.mythtv.org) has managed to somehow
"emulate" the old graphical DOS games on Linux. I
haven't tried it, only read about it. There are
thousands of them, check it out!

I have seen folks play marvellous games with graphics,
sound effects and all the jazz reqd for game lovers in
Windoze. And multi player games and network based
games are also somewhat successful I think.

I have seen some games like quake and doom work well
in linux with all the sound effects. 

IMHO, it is a hard fact that the variety and richness
of games available in Windoze is a far cry from what
is avail in linux. And they cost lot of $$$$$

Linux does have some BSD games, GNOME games and KDE
games that have good "eye candy". But then there is no
denying that Windoze is a very big step ahead. 

Largely bcoz game programming is difficult and
strenuous and people don't want to give it away for
free. 

Anyway that is how things are and we have to live with
it. :-)

regards,
Girish

I installed sendmail and dovecot on my Fedora core 5 machine. I am
using this is my local mail server. It was worked properly but last
two days it's shows this error message while sending mail. "Relaying
denied. IP name lookup failed [192.168.134.16] Port 25 Secure (SSL)"
so I put the IP of windows machine into /etc/mail/access file now it's
sending but I can't receive the mails through outlook and it's not
showing any error message while receiving. Please help
From girish1729 at yahoo.com  Thu Aug  3 23:24:57 2006
From: girish1729 at yahoo.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Fri Aug  4 11:55:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sendmail problem on outlook
In-Reply-To: <a47498e50608032315s3f384d34ve9a5a267753f6db2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060804062457.58216.qmail@web35610.mail.mud.yahoo.com>



--- Saju A P <mail2saju@gmail.com> wrote:

> I installed sendmail and dovecot on my Fedora core 5
> machine. I am
> using this is my local mail server. It was worked
> properly but last
> two days it's shows this error message while sending
> mail. "Relaying
> denied. IP name lookup failed [192.168.134.16] Port
> 25 Secure (SSL)"
> so I put the IP of windows machine into
> /etc/mail/access file now it's
> sending but I can't receive the mails through
> outlook and it's not
> showing any error message while receiving. Please
> help

SMTP is for sending alone. Receiving is done thro'
POP3 protocol or rarely IMAP. It could be port no. 110
or 143 respectively. IMAP is not so popular, so in
most cases it is gonna be POP3.

Try from windoze cmd prompt
C:> telnet 192.168.134.16 110

If it connects and displays a hello message, it is
good news. 

You can also run an interactive POP3 session like this
and see if it works as it is a text based protocol. I
am attaching an example transcript.

C:>telnet 192.168.134.16
Connected to 192.168.1.2.
Escape character is '^]'.
+OK <1154672493.2873097136@xmailserver.test> [XMail
1.21 POP3 Server] service ready; Fri, 4 Aug 2006
11:51:33 +0530
>user girish
+OK Password required for girish@xmailserver.test
>pass password
+OK ...
>retr 1-5

Please note that whatever I have marked as 
">" are typed by the user.

HTH,
Girish

Date: Sat Aug  5 14:08:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reg bandwidth control

Message-ID: <20060805083812.72899.qmail@web35605.mail.mud.yahoo.com>



--- Varun Soundararajan <s.varun@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> On 7/26/06, Girish Venkatachalam
> <girish1729@yahoo.com> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> > AFAIK it is impossible to do that in any modern
> OS.
> 
> 
>  On the same lines, how does ISP say BSNL achieve
> bandwidth control for
> users (ie they sell 256kbps, 512kbps etc..)? Do they
> use different servers
> for each speed or some thing like that?
They use hardware bandwidth control; not software
bandwidth throttling. 

BSNL and other ISPs achieve it at a "per DSL link
level" or something like that. 

ADSL is a separate topic by itself. It stands for
Asymmetric Digital Subsciber Loop. The word asymmetric
means that the upstream and downstream bandwidths are
no identical. For instance at home I get a downstream
of roughtly 280 kbps but upstream is only around 64. 

This is a limitation imposed by the purity of copper,
the characteristics of the devices at the termination
end points etc.

For instance my modem can even scale upto Megabits.
But it is limited by exchange side equipment.

TCP detects the hardware limit and adjusts
accordingly.

It is a complex topic. So let me stop here. 

I hope I made myself fairly clear. 

regards,
Girish

> Regards
> Varun S

From raamanp at yahoo.co.in  Sat Aug  5 10:34:17 2006
From: raamanp at yahoo.co.in (Raman.P)
Date: Sat Aug  5 15:04:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Fedora not getting after install Debian
In-Reply-To: <a47498e50608050151j22328154v5b6324bddfeb7c6d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060805093417.11242.qmail@web7901.mail.in.yahoo.com>


--- Saju A P <mail2saju@gmail.com> wrote:

> I installed windows XP and Fedora Core 5 on my system. It was
> working
> properly but when I installed Debian sarge on my free partition I
> am
> not getting Fedora. When I try to load fedora it's reboot
> automatically I found some message something like SELinux on
> loading
> this so I try to update fedora but on that time It's showing this
> message.
> It contain two "/"(root label) first fix that problem and try
> again.
> Can I install Win XP, Fedora Core 5 and Debian sarge on one system?
> If
> so how I can overcome this problem. Please guide.

In fedora the /etc/fstab contains the LABEL= as the first field
instead of device file name like /dev/hda1. With LABEL=, fedora
searches for a partition with label /. It appears that two partitions
have lable named /.  There are two ways of rectifying

a. Change in /etc/fstab (under fedora) LABEL=/ with /dev/hdan, hdan
stands for the partition where root(fedora) file system resides. 

 Since you are not able to run fedora, run debian mount fedora root
partition somewhere and edit etc/fstab of the mounted partition.

b. Change the label using tune2fs



Raman.P

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Sun Aug  6 01:17:59 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] recommendation for CVS replacement
Message-ID: <92f9a9560608051247l386ca0c8wcb99adce80a5a321@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

I want to retire CVS as my version control system and move to
something newer.  Can someone recommend a version control
system that fits my requirement below?

My requirement is that I need to store source code, binaries,
and device files.  The system must also store the following file
meta data:  owner/group, mode, and soft/hard link information.
Preserving and recreating hard links is important as I expect
to have several.  Commits and updates need to be fairly fast
as the repository is expected to grow to ~100MB.

I'm considering subversion and gnu-arch.  I would like to hear
from anyone who has used either system.  Any other suggestions
are equally welcome.

Thanks in advance for your time and suggestions.

- Raja
From girish1729 at yahoo.com  Sat Aug  5 18:46:36 2006
From: girish1729 at yahoo.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sun Aug  6 07:16:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] recommendation for CVS replacement
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560608051247l386ca0c8wcb99adce80a5a321@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060806014636.89232.qmail@web35604.mail.mud.yahoo.com>



--- Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> I want to retire CVS as my version control system
> and move to
> something newer.  Can someone recommend a version
> control
> system that fits my requirement below?
> 
> My requirement is that I need to store source code,
> binaries,
> and device files.  The system must also store the
> following file
> meta data:  owner/group, mode, and soft/hard link
> information.
> Preserving and recreating hard links is important as
> I expect
> to have several.  Commits and updates need to be
> fairly fast
> as the repository is expected to grow to ~100MB.
> 
> I'm considering subversion and gnu-arch.  I would
> like to hear
> from anyone who has used either system.  Any other
> suggestions
> are equally welcome.
I am afraid I can't help you much but I will give my
two cents. 

What is wrong with CVS? The wire protocol is not
efficient. It is an aged program with few annoyances.
With all its merits , it still makes difficult things
difficult. 

What is good with it? It is very good at facilitating
code development with developers distributed over
geographic boundaries and time zones. 

It is useful enuf for an average user that needs
version control.

But the wire protocol is not efficient. 

Now let us come to subversion. It is brand new and
nearly every open source project has cut over to it.
Why? It gives you several options for using either
http, https along with webdav or even some other
protocol to be layered below it. 

And it gives u several other niceties too though I am
not sure if it has what you need. 

GNU Arch? No idea.

I can give u a few ideas though.
1)  Normally these tools are tailored for storing
source code. You can of course store binaries but if
you can derive it from the source, pls dont store it.
However things like firmware, pdf doc can be stored.
But it should only be around 5% IMHO. If you want to
backup and replicate binary data u can use several
other protocols like rsync . It will be better to
check the MD5 or SHA1 checksum everytime a xfer
happens. 

2) If you want high efficiency and speed in commits
and updates, you can use rsync as the underneath
protocol. And better make sure the backend DB is an
efficient one, maybe Sleepycat's Berkeley DB or
something. I know it is possible in CVS, dont know
about SVN.

3) You can run a cron job to update the repositories
every few hours using cvsup or something. That way u
can save time and latency when u run update or commit.

Sorry I don't know anything more than that.

But if I were you I would stick to SVN since others
have already made the decision for me. 

Best,
Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] Fedora not getting after install Debian
In-Reply-To: <a47498e50608050151j22328154v5b6324bddfeb7c6d@mail.gmail.com>

	<a47498e50608050151m7bcbf527ub283aeada89a842@mail.gmail.com>
	<a47498e50608050151j22328154v5b6324bddfeb7c6d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <5ef2113c0608052328u4465fe7ai348e009cbcee5606@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/5/06, Saju A P <mail2saju@gmail.com> wrote:
> It contain two "/"(root label) first fix that problem and try again.
> Can I install Win XP, Fedora Core 5 and Debian sarge on one system? If
> so how I can overcome this problem. Please guide.

I too had the same problem some time back, I solved it by simply
changing the menu.lst. I assume you have installed debian3.1 or less.
The problem with the debian3.1 is the grub is not doing the work
properly. Again I assume that you are able to login into your debian
system, and it should be. If so you just open your menu.lst in your
favourite text editor and then add the initrd image of FCx which you
have, if you want to know what is the initrd your FCx used just open
the grub.conf in your FCx partition and have a look at it.

This is a sample, note I use FC4:
initrd /boot/initrd-2.6.17-1.2139_FC4.img

Add the above line and reboot to your FCx system and it will go fine :)

-- 
--sen--

On 8/5/06, Raman.P <raamanp@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> In fedora the /etc/fstab contains the LABEL= as the first field
> instead of device file name like /dev/hda1. With LABEL=, fedora
> searches for a partition with label /. It appears that two partitions
> have lable named /.  There are two ways of rectifying
>
> a. Change in /etc/fstab (under fedora) LABEL=/ with /dev/hdan, hdan
> stands for the partition where root(fedora) file system resides.

Hmmm I too meddled with the above LABELs and things when I was stuck
up with the problem but the real thing lies in the initrd image not
mentioned for FCx system in the menu.lst which debian created :) May
be this will be solved in etch...

stalls for one full-day will be extremely exhausting.

LDD to be held on August 19-20, 2006. The timings for
the LDD to be announced as well.

students.

colleagues at work.

appropriately so it doesn't get mixed with you college
computers.

it on to any NRCFOSS/ILUGC volunteer in the premises.

new-comers, and we will know the update/status of the

From bhuvan at ubuntu.com  Sun Aug  6 13:18:32 2006
From: bhuvan at ubuntu.com (Bhuvaneswaran)
Date: Sun Aug  6 13:18:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] recommendation for CVS replacement
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560608051247l386ca0c8wcb99adce80a5a321@mail.gmail.com>
References: <92f9a9560608051247l386ca0c8wcb99adce80a5a321@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4dc6c9040608060048v4eebb47dub0a6508e1283824f@mail.gmail.com>

> I want to retire CVS as my version control system and move to
> something newer.  Can someone recommend a version control
> system that fits my requirement below?
>
> My requirement is that I need to store source code, binaries,
> and device files.  The system must also store the following file
> meta data:  owner/group, mode, and soft/hard link information.
> Preserving and recreating hard links is important as I expect
> to have several.  Commits and updates need to be fairly fast
> as the repository is expected to grow to ~100MB.

subversion. subversion.
There are many commercial and community sites using subversion. It is
not just to store source code but files belonging to different file
type can be stored here. It's more than the improved CVS. You can
access it via http, https, svn, file protocols. The subversion
development team is very active. You can use pre/post hook scripts to
highly customize the repository. The swig bindings for perl, python,
ruby & java are available if you need connectors for Subversion. The
gui client programs like tortoisesvn are available to access the
repository. The web based applications (viewvc) are available to view
the content of repository online.

You can check out[1] link for a comparison chart and you take a call!

http://better-scm.berlios.de/comparison/comparison.html
-- 
Regards,
Bhuvaneswaran
www.symonds.net/~bhuvan/

Hi people,
Here is the list of topics fixed for the stalls today. All comments 
welcomed :D

1.Development --> a. gcc,g++   b. IDE c.Scripting Languages - Perl, 
Python, Bash

2. Web Development - LAMP (PHP, Perl and Python)

3. Web Server - Apache and Squid

4. Servers - File server and Mail server

5. Virtualization using Xen

6. Visualization or Multimedia Development

7. Localization

8. LTSP

9. Linux Security - iptables and others.

10. Linux Kernel --> proposed by Aanjhan to be on GNU/HURD and EDA tools 
and will be conveyed to the students :)

11. Graphics

12. Editors

13. Desktop - GNOME, KDE, Window Maker and few others

14. DBMS

15. Browsers and Mail

16. Content Management Systems

17. CVS/SVN

18. Utilities - CD Burning, Printers, Scanning, Digital Cameras

19. Multimedia

20. Office Tools

21. Distributions

22. Educational Tools

23. Games --> not just playing, the technology behind to develop them also

24. Networking

25. Linux Clusters

26. Wireless (no volunteers as of now)

I forgot some 3 more.. Raman/Bhaskar/Saravanan please fill in.

Hi,

--- Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
> I
> too think HURD 
> would be too much an ask for n00bs. 

As how the organizers wish. They are only some
suggestions.

> And EDA tools, I
> am not sure how 
> much CS students will be willing. 

Its very important. 

1. FLOSS is _not_ only for IT and CS students. It is
useful to all other departments.

2. EDA is inter-disciplinary for students coming from
CS/IT/EEE/ECE/ICE backgrounds. Honestly, they don't do
much inter-disciplinary work.

It really doesn't matter whether you are from x or y
department in most engineering colleges in India, as
they hardly learn anything in the first place. So this
will be a good example. Nobody said a student from
CS/IT shouldn't do VLSI in the industry, if he/she is
really interested. Unfortunately it is not flexible
here in India. But, it is very much possible in US
universities. Anyways.

When you come to the industry you only work on
specific domains - Embedded (firmware, device driver,
kernel development) or VLSI (verification,
validation).

Did you know that there are students with a CS
background who also do chip verification?

Just my thoughts,

SK

On 8/6/06, Bhuvaneswaran <bhuvan@ubuntu.com> wrote:
> > I want to retire CVS as my version control system and move to
> > something newer.  Can someone recommend a version control
> > system that fits my requirement below?
>
> subversion. subversion.

Thanks to everyone for their suggestions.

Some two years ago, Venki from Collabnet spoke about SVN at the
lug meet.  He remarked that one of his colleagues who was a DB
developer had not only his code in SVN, but also the entire Oracle
installation including a test DB!

My current requirement is similar in that it comprises of part source
code and part binaries.  File permissions, ownership and hard links
must be versioned on the binaries.  I'm running svn 1.3.0 and am
unable to coax svn to version file metadata.  I have the following in
my ~/.subversion/config.

[auto-props]
* = svn:text-time=yes;svn:owner=yes;svn:group=yes;svn:unix-mode=yes

Any help is much appreciated.

- Raja

Hi,

On 8/6/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> Did you know that there are students with a CS
> background who also do chip verification?
>

My thoughts on the above is similar. The EDA development is more to do
with Data structures and ofcourse a fair/very strong hold on
Elelctronics. The Industry has reached a stage where there are a lot
of algorithms to improve the design but all these will become reality
only when it is implemented in the EDA tool and this is becoming a
challenging area and IMO has a very good research prospective. For
more on the FOSS EDA Tools you can check on the following
presentations/sites

Bandwidth is also controlled by software in the cases like hathway or other 
cable services.
Where a boot file is sent to the modem everytime it starts and logs into the 
network
the boot file restricts the bandwidth from the user side .
no wonder ppl uncap hathway modems to get speeks like 500 kbps  :)



>From: Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@yahoo.com>
>To: Varun Soundararajan <s.varun@gmail.com>
>CC: Chennai Linux User's Group <ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in>
>Subject: Re: [Ilugc] reg bandwidth control
>Date: Sat, 5 Aug 2006 01:38:12 -0700 (PDT)
>
>
>
>--- Varun Soundararajan <s.varun@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > Hi,
> >
> > On 7/26/06, Girish Venkatachalam
> > <girish1729@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > AFAIK it is impossible to do that in any modern
> > OS.
> >
> >
> >  On the same lines, how does ISP say BSNL achieve
> > bandwidth control for
> > users (ie they sell 256kbps, 512kbps etc..)? Do they
> > use different servers
> > for each speed or some thing like that?
>They use hardware bandwidth control; not software
>bandwidth throttling.
>
>BSNL and other ISPs achieve it at a "per DSL link
>level" or something like that.
>
>ADSL is a separate topic by itself. It stands for
>Asymmetric Digital Subsciber Loop. The word asymmetric
>means that the upstream and downstream bandwidths are
>no identical. For instance at home I get a downstream
>of roughtly 280 kbps but upstream is only around 64.
>
>This is a limitation imposed by the purity of copper,
>the characteristics of the devices at the termination
>end points etc.
>
>For instance my modem can even scale upto Megabits.
>But it is limited by exchange side equipment.
>
>TCP detects the hardware limit and adjusts
>accordingly.
>
>It is a complex topic. So let me stop here.
>
>I hope I made myself fairly clear.
>
>regards,
>Girish
> >
> > Regards
> > Varun S
> >
> > /* This mail was sent using 100% recycled electrons
> > */
> >

 New and Improved Yahoo! Mail - 1GB of free storage!
From solar345 at hotmail.com  Sun Aug  6 18:49:31 2006
From: solar345 at hotmail.com (Antano Solar John)
Date: Mon Aug  7 00:19:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] set a random desktop background
In-Reply-To: <20060806183455.96466.qmail@web8912.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <BAY12-F18DD25FD57F4A66B51E2C59E560@phx.gbl>


#!/bin/bash

export DIR='/home/user/Images/Wallpapers/' /*any directory where you have 
stored images be sure to save only images */
export NUMBER=$RANDOM
export TOTAL=0

for f in `ls $DIR`
do
    let "TOTAL += 1"
done /* ignore this loop and set the value of total yourself if you have 
other files than images in the directory and you know how many images you 
have "

let "NUMBER %= TOTAL"
export CURRENT=0

for f in `ls $DIR`
do
    if [ $CURRENT = $NUMBER ]
    then
        gconftool -t string -s /desktop/gnome/background/picture_filename 
$DIR/$f
        break
    fi
    let "CURRENT += 1"
done

this script will change the wallpaper for you , just shedule it every time 
you start or every 1 hour as you like :)

On 8/7/06, Gopalarathnam Venkatesan <gopal@gopalarathnam.com> wrote:
> I'm just curious to know why do you need to put binaries under version
> control.  How does it help?

Many of my binaries are not generated from local source, they are
binary only or come from other external sources.  A single release
must therefore contain a particular version of code and binaries.
Hence the fancy version control requirements.

> single release
> must therefore contain a particular version of code
> and binaries.
> Hence the fancy version control requirements.

I am sure you must be aware how version control sw
works internally. It stores only the diffs between
multiple versions. This works only with sources that
change thro' versions.

Whereas if you put multiple binaries, the version
control sw will choke since a one line change in the
source that produced the binary will be completely
different.

Girish

Message-ID: <4dc6c9040608062350p64ef49d0y821db6d5d4c54f5d@mail.gmail.com>

> My current requirement is similar in that it comprises of part source
> code and part binaries.  File permissions, ownership and hard links
> must be versioned on the binaries.  I'm running svn 1.3.0 and am
> unable to coax svn to version file metadata.  I have the following in
> my ~/.subversion/config.
>
> [auto-props]
> * = svn:text-time=yes;svn:owner=yes;svn:group=yes;svn:unix-mode=yes

You can do this with subversion using the propset, propget, proplist
commands. Subversion recognizes set of predefined special versioned
properties but it is not limited to that. It also recognizes the
unlimited arbitrary properties. For example, to version the file
permission you can run the following set of command:
$ svn propset permission '-rw-r--r--' your_binary_file.bin && svn commit

Similarly, to version the file group, you can run the following command:
$ svn propset file_group 'user_name group_name' your_binary_file.bin
&& svn commit

See, propset, propget, proplist, propdel commands for more details.
You can also refer[1] for more details.
[1] http://svnbook.red-bean.com/nightly/en/svn.ref.svn.c.propset.html
-- 
Regards,
Bhuvaneswaran
www.symonds.net/~bhuvan/

Raja Subramanian wrote:
> My binaries come from *external* sources,  ie. not compiled
> out of source that sits in the same repository.  Some files
> are binary only, and I don't even have the source for them.

Do you really need to store the binary itself?  Couldnt you store the 
binary in a directory / rename it so that it is tagged with its version 
number.  Or find a way to make it spit out its version number on the 
command line (binary --version or whatever).

Have a field in your repository that stores the actual version numbers 
involved.  The binary is not going to change very much .. just maintain 
all the possible versions of your binary like I said.  Call the 
appropriate binary based on the version # stored in cvs / svn.

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Mon Aug  7 14:40:14 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Mon Aug  7 14:40:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] how opensolaris differs from Linux
In-Reply-To: <4367206c0608070109t6a80fa0fr7a99a49975348187@mail.gmail.com>
References: <4367206c0608070109t6a80fa0fr7a99a49975348187@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560608070210q6955ef62w20a26da4bc479c44@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/7/06, Siva Prakash <linux.siva@gmail.com> wrote:
> please tell me what is the difference between Opensolaris and Linux.
> Because opensolaris also a OpenSource product.
> this is also a Unix clone.

Solaris *is* Unix.  See the Unix history chart at:
    http://www.levenez.com/unix/
    http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix

Last year Sun made the source code for various bits of Solaris 10
(and beyond) available to the community.  Sun released the code
under the CDDL license:
    http://www.opensolaris.org/os/about/faq/licensing_faq/

OpenSolaris offers a few excellent features:  DTrace, Zones, ZFS.


> i got confused, is it a another distro?or any other licenses issue?

Similar to Linux, 3rd party vendors have built distributions around
the OpenSolaris kernel and userland.  IMO, Nexenta (gnusolaris.org)
is the best OpenSolaris distro around. It combines a OpenSolaris
kernel with an Debian^H^H Ubuntu userland.


> Also please explain me,
> is there any difference to do a  java based developement in GNU/Linux
> platform and the Sun's own platform. (any Advantages?)

As far as the development goes, it's the same story with Java:  you
write once and debug everywhere.

Solaris has been traditionally strong on the multi-threading and scalability
end of things.  And this goes well with Java's heavily threaded nature.
I suppose today's Linux has closed the performance gap (if not surpassed
it already) so there's not much advantage in running Java on Solaris as
opposed to Linux.

- Raja

The whole solution is Linux based and uses the  controls of Linux.

Ok to give you some idea of what i know

A Linux system has to be setup with two Ethernet cards
One card should be connected to the backbone ( the 512 k /1 mb  or 2 mb line
you get from your isp)
The other card should be connected to the switch where all other systems are
connected.
now download the trail version of the software from the above site and
install it.
You will have the following options to control

1. restricting bandwidth ( like 64 k or 128 k for each of the client systems
on your network)
2. restricting the time to use the Internet browsing like only between 3pm
to 6 pm
3. restricting the max download ie like 2 mb or 3 mb per day
4 Accounting

different setting can be done for each of the local ip address ie each
system in your local network. it also works based on network login id if it
is dhcp.


This is used by a few isps for billing and some large Internet browsing
centers 250+ systems in india and many countries abroad.
This also works for  wireless isps hot spot / wifi wimax.
It is a c program on  linux os.

mail the developer for more details.
He is selling this package for 300 $.
If you happan to end up buying it , pl let me know.
I get a beer as referal commision from him.

	<92f9a9560608070219i3f0a69dfm99ba93a84a03c890@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4dc6c9040608070636j1db0177fvbf7a1b33583462b@mail.gmail.com>

> I fear that at some point in the future, I'll fail to run "svn propset ..." on
> some file and break things in weired and wonderful ways.
>
> Is there some way svn can automatically pickup file mode, user and
> group information on evey commit?  Ofcourse, svn also needs to
> automatically apply them on a checkout.  Or do I need to handle
> them through the hooks?

I understand, the requirement is specific to your WC. So, you may not be able to
run the pre-hook scripts from the repository. I see two things to do here:

1) Automate the process of setting these arbitrary properties for a file
2) Incorporate these changes when you commit

Solutions:

1) I guess, the way to go is to write a custom script to set these
properties for a file using propset command
2) You can set an alias for 'commit' (if it's ok) to run the custom
script and invoke the actual 'svn commit' command

Since, your requirement seem to be specific to your WC and no one else
may be interested to have this setup, i guess it would fit in your
need. If others do, set the alias for them as well!
-- 
Regards,
Bhuvaneswaran
www.symonds.net/~bhuvan/

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Aug  7 07:47:37 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Aug  7 20:18:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] regarding pci  vga card output with powerpc
In-Reply-To: <44D73621.1060809@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060807144737.77600.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Sudheer,

--- sudheer <urwithsudheer@gmail.com> wrote:
> I have
> connected the vga card 
> next to the  pci slot of my target processor on the
> baseboard.

Which one? Does the baseboard also have a keyboard,
mouse input?

> I have connected a monitor to the vga card.
> When i boot linux from minicom, i could see all the
> kernel log messages 
> on both the minicom and vga card monitor. 

You will be passing something like "video=" option to
the kernel command line.

> But on the
> vga monitor, i 
> could not see any messages after asking for login as
> below:

Usually, the hardware is designed such that the
keyboard/mouse on the baseboard functions with the
on-board VGA. Not sure which one you are using or
which Linux kernel you are using.

> Though i am entering my login and passwd at the
> minicom, nothing comes 
> on to the vga monitor. 

Because input/output goes to the serial port _and_ is
not redirected to the VGA.

> But i am able to write to vga
> monitor using the 
> following commands from minicom:
> # echo "Hello" > /dev/tty1

Sure, hardware is visible to all.

> My requirement is to get on the vga monitor whatever
> i am typing on the 
> minicom after logging into the linux like .

My question is "Why?". 

The baseboard is supposed to be converted to an
end-product. Serial port is only for developers. An
end-user will use the on-board VGA, keyboard, mouse to
use the system, rather than the serial port. But, if
you want to do it, you also need to redirect the
serial buffer data to the framebuffer driver.

Regards,

SK

Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

Hello Shakti Kannan,

I think i am not clear in the way i said about the setup.

The setup is
Target - Freescale MPC8360 (Host Mode).
VGA card sits on the pci bus of MPC8360.

The VGA card details are as follows.
Vendor ID=0x1002 Device ID= 0x4752
Name: ATI Technologies Inc Rage XL

MPC8360 is connected to x86 pc with a serial port for minicom.
A monitor is connected to vga card.

I have changed the following:
In the ramdisk file system
1. etc/inittab file, we added
:::respawn:/sbin/getty tty1 115200 vt1002.

 While configuring the linux, we have enable the Virtual Terminal option.

 From minicom, after booting the u-boot,
I have modified the bootargs to:
=> set bootargs console=tty1 console=ttyS0,115200

While booting linux, i could see all the kernel log messages on monitor 
connected to vga card that i get on the minicom, but could not see on 
the vga monitor once it asks for the login. Whatever i do on the minicom 
(after mpc8360 booting to linux), i need to get them on vga monitor also.

In the end product we dont have any keyboard, etc.

As you said, I will try with redirecting the serial buffer data  to 
frame buffer .

Thanks & Regards
Sudheer

On 8/7/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
>
>
> --- Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> > yes you  can  install n number of os in the same
> > hard disk , just make sure
> > you partition them properly , and also make the root
> > partitions bootable ,
> > you can use a simple partition manager tool to help
> > you like ranish boot
> > manager and if oyou fins it still difficult download
> > one of those easy to
> > use gui based boot manager :)
> >
> I was told the limit was 4, not n. I don't know
> whether it is a BIOS limitation. I think you can't
> have more than 4 different bootable partitions in an
> x86 box.


Literally You can make all your partitions bootable,
The limitation of 4 is for primary partitions , ie the no of partition
entries
 that can be there in the MBR.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_boot_record

This is not an X86 limitation but a standard followed .

From girish1729 at yahoo.com  Tue Aug  8 04:17:37 2006
From: girish1729 at yahoo.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Aug  8 16:47:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Fedora not getting after install Debian
In-Reply-To: <BAY12-F18544CECD4607D5AAE7D439E540@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <20060808111737.81352.qmail@web35609.mail.mud.yahoo.com>



--- Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com> wrote:

> true .... agree with you :)
Well actually this is what happened at my workplace
years ago.

Myself to Boss : So you can install as many OSes as
you want right?
Boss to myself : Yes, any number as long as it is less
than or equal to 4

I found it very hard to agree with him but I picked
myself up and moved on. :-)

There are several factors playing here. The OS has to
support booting from a point beyond the scary 1024
cylinder limit. OpenBSD is notorious for that. Though
I think they have fixed that now. 

In fact I will first make sure that I really am able
to boot more than 4 OSes by making 4 primary and
remaining logical partitions and test whether the nth
OS that is lying way off from the disk beginning is
able to boot. 

Boot loaders also have to support this of course.
These days grub seems to be really popular though grub
also is still lacking in certain things. 

Anyway if any of you are successful in booting more
than 4 OSes pls do let me know. 

But for all practical purposes I think this limit will
hardly hit us. 

regards,
Girish

>
>
>
> --- Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
> > true .... agree with you :)
> Well actually this is what happened at my workplace
> years ago.
>
> Myself to Boss : So you can install as many OSes as
> you want right?
> Boss to myself : Yes, any number as long as it is less
> than or equal to 4
>
> I found it very hard to agree with him but I picked
> myself up and moved on. :-)
>
> There are several factors playing here. The OS has to
> support booting from a point beyond the scary 1024
> cylinder limit. OpenBSD is notorious for that. Though
> I think they have fixed that now.
>
> In fact I will first make sure that I really am able
> to boot more than 4 OSes by making 4 primary and
> remaining logical partitions and test whether the nth
> OS that is lying way off from the disk beginning is
> able to boot.


Once if you have created 4 primary partition  you cannot create more than
that ,
your logical partition can be created only if you have atleast one extended
partition


Boot loaders also have to support this of course.
> These days grub seems to be really popular though grub
> also is still lacking in certain things.
>
> Anyway if any of you are successful in booting more
> than 4 OSes pls do let me know.


Literally it is possible to have more than 4 OS in different partitions,
but presently most of them doesnt consider the other operating system
which lies in the hard disk ,  every operating system wants its boot loader
code to be installed in the MBR ( except linux AFAIK)  , some of them needs
atleast a primary partition (eg MINIX) ,

But for all practical purposes I think this limit will
> hardly hit us.
>


Krishna P.
-- 
BLOG: http://gnubie.blogspot.com/

Think your X is not configured properly. Try fixing
your /etc/X11/XF86Config or /etc/X11/xorg.conf (  I
don't know which one is used by Slackware). XFree86 or
X.org? Most likely the former.

If you can get X running you can use the "xf86cfg"
command to fine tune your X installation. Are you
getting a good resolution? Or ugly looking large
windows?

I think slackware will have its own script for X
configuration. Run that.

If you send us the "lspci" output I think someone with
your video card will be able to give you hints on the
right parameters. 

If you can access the machine from the network it will
be best to kill X and access the virtual consoles.

Best,
Girish

On 8/7/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>
> I fear that at some point in the future, I'll fail to run "svn propset
> ..." on
> some file and break things in weired and wonderful ways.


Check out auto-props, which is a client-side configuration (
http://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.2/svn.advanced.props.html#svn.advanced.props.auto
).
It is possible to set the mime-type at import or add time. Set up auto-props
first, though.

There was a proposal for adding server-side configuration as well. From a
quick look at the CHANGES file (
http://svn.collab.net/repos/svn/trunk/CHANGES), it doesn't seem to have been
implemented yet. But confirm by asking on the svn-users mailing list or IRC
(#svn on freenode). Folks are friendly, if a bit terse.

Is there some way svn can automatically pickup file mode, user and
> group information on evey commit?  Ofcourse, svn also needs to
> automatically apply them on a checkout.


There is a branch and a patch to handle this last year, not sure if it got
into the general distribution. This email talks about it a little:
http://svn.haxx.se/users/archive-2005-12/0285.shtml

Note that if you control the working copies area for all the users, much of
this can be done as part of the project configuration. In that case,
Subversion simply uses whatever usernames and groups are already present in
the environment/filesystem.

If you are only worried about execute permission, set svn:executable on
those files or auto-props for regexes that match those filenames.

The primary issue with Subversion and binary files is the client-side
on-disk checkout version copy. It makes offline working trivial, but
increases the network transfer times. As of 1+ years back, svn developers
and power users didn't recommend it for storing large numbers of large
images. That said, Connectiva, IIRC, said it had all its production distros
in Subversion (ISO's, I presume).

HTH
Sameer

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0608081536340.2649-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

On 8/8/06, Bharathi Subramanian <sbharathi@midascomm.com> wrote:
> Anybody willing give a talk on this month ILUGC Meet, Plz mail back to
> me. This month meet is on Sat Aug 12 3PM 2006 in IIT-Madras.

I was very impressed with Gopalrathanam's Javascript talk last weekend.

Given sufficient interest, I would like to extend this a bit further and
volunteer to talk about how modern scripting languages are designed
and implemented.

Focus is on 3 areas:
  1. data types, introspection, memory and garbage collection.
  2. symbol tables, namespaces, lexical and dynamic scopes
  3. and end up with how 1,2 are used to implement closures and OO.

All this is primarily based on Perl (ofcourse!), but the most part should
equally well apply to Tcl, Python, Ruby, and (from what I found out
last week) Javascript.

Please let me know if you find this interesting...

- Raja

In-Reply-To: <a47498e50608092212q20520282n9680319df252097f@mail.gmail.com>

	<a47498e50608092211r683434c0hade75c148aa70677@mail.gmail.com>
	<a47498e50608092211icf0e43fx4f349cf6964bcdc1@mail.gmail.com>
	<a47498e50608092211x1a51375fg98cd61cbc038ac85@mail.gmail.com>
	<a47498e50608092212q20520282n9680319df252097f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060810055624.GB3566@localhost.localdomain>

hi,

> I installed debian sarge on my system. But I am not able to configure
> sound card. When I run alsaconf it's not selecting my sound card. How
> I can configure my soundcard.
> When I run #lspci it shows this as sound card device
> Multimedia audio controller: Slicon Integrated System [SiS] sound
> controller (rev 0f)


I had faced a similar problem on my Sarge(2.6.8) some time back.I have
a hda-intel soundcard and it was not supported out of the box.I
downloaded the drivers and other required tools(libs/utils etc) from
the http://www.alsa-project.org/ site.I built the driver for my card
against the kernel source and it was up and running.
I would suggest you to check the list of supported soundcard's at the
alsa site and the corresponding driver required.If the driver
exists,insert it,else follow the same procedure as mentioned
above.Googling will also provide a lot of info.

--
sughosh

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Thu Aug 10 16:54:59 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Thu Aug 10 16:49:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] NRC-FOSS is looking for research scientists
Message-ID: <2AD69820-8521-4FF9-9D6A-A6E1ACB5271C@thenilgiris.com>

hi,

no apologies for not tagging this as [commercial][OT] because it is  
not. NRC-FOSS at AU-KBC, MIT campus, Anna University Chennai is a  
project funded by the DIT for the pupose of development of FOSS in  
India. In addition to propagation of FOSS, we are now trying to build  
a world standard academic and research programme centred round FOSS.  
Backed by proven expertise of the AU-KBC centre in the fields of  
mathematics, cryptography, pattern recognition, life-sciences,  
wireless and bio-informatics, we are building certificate, diploma  
and postgraduate programmes centred around FOSS on one side and  
building and releasing FOSS applications in these fields on the other  
side. We invite interested people to join us. Details of the posts  
are at:

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/full/12/AN/

No, we dont offer multinational salaries. Yes, we believe in academic  
freedom, a relaxed atmosphere, 24/7 working labs and offices, no  
dress code, intellectual stimulation. (And, yes, again, this *is*  
happening in a Govt of India Project). Our goal is to produce FOSS  
code and train people to do this - and enjoy doing this. Our motto is  
'Foss is Fun'. Join the fun.

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/


From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Aug 10 17:27:34 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Thu Aug 10 17:23:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Aug Month ILUGC Meeting
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0608101711110.786-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

ILUGC Meet (Aug 12th):-
======================

Time : Sat Aug 12th 15:00 IST 2006 
Venue: ADI-TeNeT Seminar Hall,
       #CSD 320, ESB, IIT-Madras.

Visit: http://www.chennailug.org/location-tenet.php

Agenda:

Talk 1. LAMP - An Overview (45Mins)
        By Antano Solar John

This talk covers the basics of the LAMP developments.

Talk 2. Modern Scripting Languages - Design & Implementation (1Hr)
        By Raja Subramanian

This talk about "How the modern scripting languages are designed
and implemented?". Mainly focus is on 3 areas:

A. data types, introspection, memory and garbage collection.
B. symbol tables, namespaces, lexical and dynamic scopes.
C. how A,B are used to implement closures and OO.

HTH :)
-- 
Bharathi S

>   3. and end up with how 1,2 are used to implement closures and OO.
>
> All this is primarily based on Perl (ofcourse!), but the most part should
> equally well apply to Tcl, Python, Ruby, and (from what I found out
> last week) Javascript.
>
> Please let me know if you find this interesting...
>
> - Raja

Will you be uploading the slides? and if so, where can I find them?

Regards,
Senthil

From nagappan at gmail.com  Fri Aug 11 12:05:30 2006
From: nagappan at gmail.com (Nagappan A)
Date: Fri Aug 11 12:05:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] LDTP 0.5.0 Released!!!
Message-ID: <9d0602eb0608102335q513f23ccw91a5f62ba417b852@mail.gmail.com>

Issue VIII - 10 August 2006

We are provide to announce the release of LDTP 0.5.0. This release
features number of important breakthroughs in the history of LDTP as
well as in the field of Test Automation. This release note covers a
brief introduction on LDTP followed by the list of new features and
major bug fixes which makes this new version of LDTP the best of the
breed. Useful references have been included at the end of this article
for those who wish to hack / use LDTP.

LDTP developers had the privilege of participating in the Google Summer
of Code contest. Special thanks to the mentors of LDTP in the event
Varadhan and Emily Chen. We also thank Prashanth Mohan ('Casanova') for
his wonderful contributions acting as student developer for LDTP as part
of this event.

LDTP Planet has been set up by Prashanth Mohan ('Casanova') for sharing
information more effectively across the community. You can have access
to the planet through the
following link http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/planet/

About LDTP
==========

Linux Desktop Testing Project is aimed at producing high quality test
automation framework and cutting-edge tools that can be used to test
Linux Desktop and improve it. It uses the Accessibility libraries to
poke through the application's user interface. The framework also has
tools to record test-cases based on user events in the interface of the
application which is under testing. We strive to help in building a
quality desktop.

Whats new in this release...
============================

+ Recording using LDTP
This new version of LDTP features a recorder tool which would help in
generating automation scripts automatically by recording user events.
This would greatly reduce the time required for creating and maintaining
automation scripts. Thanks to Venkateswaran ('whacko'), Harishankaran
('sp2hari') and Theyagarajan ('Taggy') for making this happen. For more
information on this please refer to
http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/wiki/RecordHOWTO

+ Integration with Tinderbox - LDTP has been integrated with the GNOME
jhbuild. Using this feature one can execute test scripts automatically
at the end of successful
completion of package building using jhbuild. This was done as part of
Google SoC. Thanks to Prashanth Mohan ('Casanova') again for his
wonderful contribution.
Please refer to the following links for more information.
* http://prashblog.be/2006/07/27/ldtp-integrated-into-jhbuild/
* http://www.0d.be/2006/07/25/integrating-ldtp-into-jhbuild/
* http://tieguy.org/blog/2006/07/26/little-bits-of-awesomeness/

+ Automation scripts
* More than 70 new scripts for Gedit has been developed and is available
for download with this release. Kudos to Lakshmi Narasimhan
('narasim_7') and 'addict3d' for their excellent work. You can download
them from http://people.freedesktop.org/~prashmohan/gedit/
* New automation scripts for Evolution are being developed by Prashanth
Mohan ('Casanova') as part of his SoC contribution. These scripts can be
downloaded from http://people.freedesktop.org/~prashmohan/evolution/

+ Documentation updates
LDTP documentation section in the LDTP web site has been updated with
the latest list of automation APIs. Thanks to our maintainer Nagappan
('nags') for his contribution.

+ Bug fixes
This version includes loads of bug fixes to address important issues
like memory leak, API functionality etc., For a detailed list please
refer to release notes section of our project site hosted in
http://ldtp.freedesktop.org. Thanks to all the developers for their
contribution.

Whats in Store...
=================

+ We are very pleased with the ongoing work on porting LDTP to ARM
platform by people from Palm Source, China. One of their latest
contribution has led to an Object Oriented LDTP approach. It still under
development but you can have a taste of this new recipe by following
this link http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/wiki/Object_2oriented_20LDTP

+ With Google SoC in full steam, we are awaiting more breakthroughs by
our LDTP team participating in the same.

Downloads
=========

LDTP package for different platforms can be downloaded from the
following location http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/wiki/Downloads

References
==========

For detailed information on LDTP framework and latest updates visit
http://ldtp.freedesktop.org

For information on various APIs in LDTP including those added for this
release can be got from http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/user-doc/index.html

To subscribe to LDTP mailing lists, visit
http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/wiki/Mailing_20list

IRC Channel - #ldtp on irc.freenode.net

For suggestions to improve this newsletter, please write to
jpremkumar@novell.com

-- 
Linux Desktop Testing Project - http://ldtp.freedesktop.org
http://nagappanal.blogspot.com

On 8/11/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@yahoo.com> wrote:
> My upload however is a paltry 64 kbps, that too it the
> upper limit. Typical trouble with all ADSL providers.

The unlimited traffic plans from Touchtel and Tataindicom DSL
offer symmetric 256kbps up and down links.

In all, I recommend Touchtel because their call center staff
are clued in and well mannered.

Btw, TCP is not designed for async bandwidth links, and unless you
implement some QoS to prioritize ACK packets, during heavy uploads
your downloads will suffer.  Eg. On a 2mbps down 512kbps up connection,
running an upload will reduce the download speed to 600-800kbps.

- Raja

From codeshepherd at gmail.com  Fri Aug 11 12:22:48 2006
From: codeshepherd at gmail.com (Deepan Chakravarthy)
Date: Sat Aug 12 00:53:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ./configure  - what really happens
In-Reply-To: <20060811191000.10435.qmail@web8907.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <20060811191000.10435.qmail@web8907.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1155279168.3016.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sat, 2006-08-12 at 03:10 +0800, satheesh kumar wrote:
> when installing the s/w using source code we come
> across the stpes:
> 
> ./configure
> make
> make install
> 
> what really happens.. why cant we just go with 
> make install
> 
> how does it differ from installing using rpm/deb..
> 
when you install a software using rpm or deb u are just copying the
binaries to the specific place without compiling them. This is more
similar to make install. This is has the limitation that you cannot use
a binary for windows in linux or the other way. And a binary built in 64
bit will not work in 32 bit. 

Where as when you get source and do make, make install you actually
compile the source from scratch. 

./configure actually scans your system to find out if all the
requirements for your software are satisfied by your system. 

make compiles the source and creates binaries.
make install copies the binary files and other files to appropriate
place. 

If you want to get a better picture about ./configure , make and make
install you must google for "auto tools". Automake and autoconf are two
important packages used to automate the creation of configure script and
makefiles. 

Hope I answered you question
Thanks
Deepan
www.codeshepherd.com

first you must get the port number the host uses
then try to make a connection on each host to that port number
start from 198.58.0.1 till the last in the series
sore every ip from which you get a response
and that list will be the currently live hosts.

to learn more on checking open ports and making connections
donwload beejes guide to networking from the net

  Dear Amit,
   
  A simple script can do the trick ..initialise two varables x and y..run it in a nested 'for' loop,  increment for x and y ...run the ping command (ping 198.58.x.y) and store the output in a text file.I have tried it out(in windows scripting though !!!)...its reasonably faster too..
   
  If you want information on which ports are open then you need to go for tools like nmap or superscan(which is much faster than nmap and gives a good graphical output)...
