Subject: [Ilugc] Help me setting malayalam/tamil/hindi keyboard/map

Prakash Jose Kokkatt wrote:
> Hello,
> How can i set a keyboard in my local lang...btw i use Debian Etch
> GNU/Linux.I need this to write/edit articles in ml.wikipedia.org such a way
> that if i type malyalam in "English" it will show corresponding
> Malayalam/Tamil.I understand that it needs to setup keymaps for those
> LANGs.please help me ppl
>                                                      regards,
>                                        Prakash Jose Kokkattu

Hi,
Changing the keyboard layout and language settings will only enable a 
malayalam in keyboard to you. If you need to get malayalam when you type 
in english, i.e. phonetic keyboard then you have to install 'scim'

Use apt-get to download and install 'scim'. In additional u need 
additional packages to support scim. Important ones are: scim-uim, 
scim-m17n, scim-gtk2-immodule, scim-modules-socket, scim-modules-table 
and scim-tables-additional. The first 3 are very important.

Once you have these things installed, you should be able to get 'SCIM 
input method setup' in your preferences menu.

You have a couple of things more to do, before you can comfortably start 
typing in malayalam. I have written a procedure for making scim work for 
tamil. The same holds true for malayalam also. scim-tables-additional 
provides language tables for all indian languages. Here is my blog for 
you to refer, 
http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com/2006/07/16/the-birth-of-foss4mylang/

HTH :)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan ('technofreak')
------------------------------
Research Assistant @ NRC-FOSS and Python\PHP Developer
A Proud Tuxian and an Ubuntero

From binand at gmail.com  Sat Aug 19 18:33:55 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sat Aug 19 22:04:09 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help me setting malayalam/tamil/hindi keyboard/map

References: <44E72D9A.4030406@gmail.com>
	<20060819154735.90996.qmail@web35614.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610608190933v29c6e144t5f41b3fba5137123@mail.gmail.com>

On 19/08/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@yahoo.com> wrote:
> How do I ensure that ppl who open my document can read
> it? I don't want ppl to install any font.
>
> Do I have to go the unicode way?

I don't think what you want is possible in the most general case.
Unicode specifies only an encoding which encompasses most (all?) known
scripts in the world. How these characters are rendered will still
depend upon the font used (and if the source document's specified font
is not available on the destination computer, weird stuff will be
rendered).

PDF format addresses this by having a font-embedding system, which
allows fonts to be shipped along with the document, at a size penalty.

Binand

My dear brothers and sisters,

Please do not take what people write at face value. If
the guy says that he cannot play mp3 files, he does
not mean that he needs an mp3 codec. He just means
that he is not able to play any audio with linux. 

At least this is what I am guessing. What has Eric S
Raymond got to do with it? :-)

Many of us are spectacularly gifted when it comes to
communicating something wrongly. :-) I mean we want to
say something, ppl understand the exact opposite. Even
otherwise techspeak is Greek and Latin. On top of that
we have a communication gap...

Anyway I suppose he has to get his sound card working
somehow either by loading the appropriate module or
something else. I simply don't have details. 

And he has to use a simple player like mpg321 to test
it. 

Btw, mp3 decoding is open and has always been free. I
myself have worked on the libao and libmad source
code. 

It is only mp3 encoding that is proprietary. mp2
encoding is free I think...

Happy Weekend guys!

regards,
Girish

Noorul,

Please read the complete mail, spend a minute or two
digesting the contents and what the person is trying
to  say. When did I say that the howto is the solution
that  Airtel is going to use? 

In fact this is not a howto even. 

Anyway the surest way I can ensure that Airtel does
not buy this from me is to show them this procedure.
Already there is lot of prejudice against linux. If I
show them this complicated mumbo jumbo, they will
throw me out of the office. 

That is why I am making a livecd that works out of the
box to demonstrate it. Even that will not do. People
may not even want to install livecd to disk. They will
want their own linux distro. 

And each linux distro patches the kernel in their own
way. I cannot patch the kernel simply. For me to make
an install CD that has a point and click interface
like Windoze is a colossal task given the fact the the
linux market is so fragmented with no
standardisation...

So can't you see you were not comparing apples to
apples? I was saying that a Windoze like install CD
for linux can avoid the user the 4 points I discussed
above. 

That is, when software can simply solve the problem
without user intervention, why should Airtel go thro'
the rigmarole of replacing the modem? 

This howto is for hackers who want to learn and have
fun! And for those who enjoy doing things
themselves...

regards,
Girish

From girish1729 at yahoo.com  Sat Aug 19 23:10:05 2006
From: girish1729 at yahoo.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Sun Aug 20 11:40:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] What topics do you want me to cover?
Message-ID: <20060820061005.18950.qmail@web35602.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Dearest friends,

I have not yet started preparing slides for the
presentation I promised. Apropos of that I want some
inputs from you guys as to what topics will interest
you. 

Please remember that my idea is to help you students
and professionals either to get better jobs or to be
better programmers. So think from that angle and tell
me exactly what you want. No offlist replies will be
entertained!

Please get back to me at the earliest as I am running
out of time! 

Details about the logistics are awaited. As of now the
plan is to have a full two day course on networking
and security. Day 1 will be networking. Day 2 will be
security and spam. 

I am planning to screw up a weekend of yours! Hope
your girlfriend will understand! Ha ha! :-)

Here are the topics I have come up with for Day 1. I
am thinking of six hours of talking. This should be
sufficient to cover the following topics.

a)MAC and physical layer(802.3, 802.11, bridging,
repeaters and othe PHY concepts) 

b)TCP/IP stack, header fields, TCP and IP internals

c)IP routing protocols, OSPF, BGP, RIP

d)App protocols like SMTP,IMAP,POP3,HTTP,FTP,rsync,
ssh 

e)ppp,pppoe, pppoa, integration between telephone and
data networks

f)New age protocols, CARP, VRRP, MPLS, QoS concepts
like Intserv, Diffserv

g)VoIP concepts, mbone, Video on demand networks

h)peer to peer protocols, NAT , chat and presence
protocols like XMPP

i)VPNs and tunneling

I think you should start reading up Tanenbaum if you
have not already. Browse Cisco documents for
networking topics. I think IPJ has few good pointers. 

Please please come prepared or else I will be wasting
your time. 

I don't want to commit the date. Logistics will be
worked out later. I think you have a time of at least
three to four weeks. But start now and go to the
bookstore and start reading...

love,
Girish

> english content ] in a CD / DVD

> complete reference on most
> common topics.
> Eventhough "online" is the key factor in Wikipedia,
> i want it "off Line" which
> is suitable for my students.

Dear Sir,

Wikipedia content easily runs into several terabytes
even if you want only the English version. And a DVD
can store only 4.7 GB. You can however choose a few
categories or leave out certain categories. Things
like American history and obscure religious stuff
might not interest many students. 

If you want science, physics, math, computer science,
biology and current affairs, then you need to see how
big this will become. 

I think for math, wolfram.com is much better than
wikipedia. I am no math geek but I think lot of
efforts have gone into it. It is also totally free.

As to the tech part, I think you can go in for on the
fly compression like liveCD and use something like
squashfs that compresses files in the best way. 

Since your objective is a noble one I will gladly help
you out. Please contact me offlist and I will give you
exactly what you want. You may have to get me a DVD
burner though. I don't have one! :-)

regards,
Girish

From chaks.yoper at gmail.com  Sun Aug 20 15:32:16 2006
From: chaks.yoper at gmail.com (Chakkaradeep C C)
Date: Sun Aug 20 15:32:30 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How far we are going to Compromise ?
Message-ID: <a54a308e0608200302w5356e1a7oa7d270a360e0c00b@mail.gmail.com>

Hi all,

Before reading my mail, I would like you all to read Open Source guru
advocates ideological
shift<http://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/08/17/eric_raymond_linux_compromise/>

Thats running in my mind for more than 6 months. How far GNU/Linux is gonna
compromise on the Desktop Market ?

The people who are going to use GNU/Linux as their Desktop arent geeks(like
us). They do not even know what a "command line tool" and no way you can
make him/her to learn, as he/she would tell, why would he/she has to learn
!.

We do know that there are patent rights with Mp3,DVD etc., There are no
support for many plugin formats for the same reason too. If one needs such
things to be done, he/she is redirected to pages like ,

   - For Ubuntu <https://wiki.ubuntu.com/RestrictedFormats>
   - For Novell/SuSE<http://www.desktoplinux.com/articles/AT7527984757.html>
   - For RedHat<http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/ForbiddenItems#head-480f1c231662c4279ebc75f7298db407ee0a5593>

Dont these have to work out of the box if you really want it to be used by
the normal people ?

Yes, companies need to compromise and thats what M$ had done during the
start (Gud or Bad,one has to admit).

I would say this is one of the reasons, people fear of adopting GNU/Linux
into Desktops.

When companies like Novell,RedHat have decided their target are Desktop
Users, why would they not get exclusive rights like how M$ has ?. Sure,
there should be a way. If M$ is able to do things, why not WE.

Take a GNU/Linux Desktop Oriented Distro, list out things what would be
required to make it still better(in terms of out of the box support), let us
prepare the list, take survey, and submit online the results.This will help
the companies understand that there are quite large number of people needing
these requirements.(I am sure they would know already)

There are many other things also that we need to compromise. There are many
proprietary products in Linux itself (like, CrossOverOffice) which are great
deal for Desktop Users. If we neglect them,and just strive for only FREE(as,
Free of Cost), I think the situation would be the same and sure normal
people would not be able to use GNU/Linux.

Am not at all telling that GNU/Linux is not growing or there are only
pitfalls. These issues are something we need to keep track of.And my kind
advice would be to spread the word FREE as in FREE TO USE/REDISTRIBUTE and
not as in FREE OF COST. That leads into a different scenario.

We are doing a good job in spreading about GNU/Linux by conducting LDDs at
various institutions. Is there any way to conduct LDD for the normal public
?. If so, then , it would be great show and sure our voices will reach the
Public, Media.

One of the main reason for me to be with Freespire <http://freespire.org> ,
is their Vision on how to make GNU/Linux best in the Desktop Usage. They
have legal rights in giving out the restricted
formats<http://wiki.freespire.org/index.php/Summary_of_Proprietary_Components>out
of the
box.Please dont think am here to spread about Freespire. These things are
the basic needs for a Desktop User.

The future of GNU/Linux is good if we make GNU/Linux the best in Desktop
Usage as stated by Eric Raymond.
-- 
Regards,
C.C.Chakkaradeep,
Novatium Solutions Limited,Chennai.
http://chakkaradeep.livejournal.com/
http://www.yoper.com
http://wiki.freespire.org/index.php/Freespire_Community_Board_Home

From kums at gmx.net  Sun Aug 20 15:41:10 2006
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Sun Aug 20 15:41:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Undelete: impossible on ext3!
Message-ID: <44E8353E.7090007@gmx.net>

Hi,

I am running Ubuntu dapper and I have ext3 file system for my root 
partition. I accidentally deleted a whole bunch of my files, almost 2 
GB. I was looking for ways to restore the files when this one shocked me 
a bit..

http://lkml.org/lkml/2003/1/7/135

<quote>
..in order to ensure that ext3 can safely resume an unlink after a
crash, it actually zeros out the block pointers in the inode, whereas
ext2 just marks these blocks as unused in the block bitmaps and marks
the inode as "deleted" and leaves the block pointers alone.
Your only hope is to "grep" for parts of your files that have been 
deleted and hope for the best...
</quote>

Even assuming grep can help this way, I don't have any idea about the 
'parts' as most of the files are non-text.

Just when I almost felt like crying..I remembered (so much for my 
memory) those files were actually in a mounted fat32 partition and I did 
have a backup of about 50% of those on CDs. To cut the story short, I 
got back all my files using an undelete app in windows.

Call me lazy for not making frequent backups but most of us are really 
that lazy anyway. I just escaped this time but do people like me have a 
solution next time when a file gets irrevocably deleted from an ext3 
partition? Should I always keep my important files on a non-ext3 
partition (prolly fat32 for the number of undelete tools supporting it)?
How would you go about it?


Regards
Kumaraguru

was generally, FUD - since the Recycle Bin provides approximately
similar functionality (and there are several recycle bin

subscribers (part of its provisioning module).

From kbalavignesh at gmail.com  Sun Aug 20 20:51:35 2006
From: kbalavignesh at gmail.com (Bala Vignesh)
Date: Sun Aug 20 20:51:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Remastering Knoppix or Mepis ?
Message-ID: <bc3fff520608200821y1e0fd6a8x4d68db6002b3aec3@mail.gmail.com>

> On 8/17/06, Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Hi all,
> >
> > One of my client needs his requirement in the form of a distro and asked us
> > to remaster any distro.
> >
> > I think Knoppix and Mepis are good.But am unaware which I have to choose?
> >
> > Any inputs on this?

Hi !

    For Remastering

If you have more time, Go for

www.slax.org
It's good for Live-cd or Live-USB.
It's based on slacware and it uses unionfs filesystem.
While creating livecd , i have faced the following problem...
It can not be installable.(3 months before... , i think now too.)
If you want to add some more packages, u have to download tar files
and make it as modules.
(They give scripts for this.)

If you have more patients, Go for

http://www.knoppix.net/wiki/Category:Remastering_Knoppix

If you need very urgent, Go for

http://www.pclinuxonline.com
 Download iso and Install pclinuxos.
 If you have broadband, update packages what ever u need.
Finally, give 'mklivecd' command, then get iso ...and burn it.

(If u need help in creating bootsplash, i will give hints.)

Bye

bala

>FREE(as,
>Free of Cost), I think the situation would be the same and sure normal
>people would not be able to use GNU/Linux.
>

>advice would be to spread the word FREE as in FREE TO USE/REDISTRIBUTE and
>not as in FREE OF COST. That leads into a different scenario.

On 8/20/06, Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com> wrote:
> i love linux opensouce blah blah ........ but i still find it convinient to
> boot windows when i have to listen to music .............i cant convert to
> ogg my creative zen doesnt play that .......... and even after installing
> plugin for mp3 the features arn't on par with windows .....so i think we
> should stop the idea of trying to be pure ............... and i dont
> undertstand whats the problem with patent then why is winamp ,wm9 not
> getting sued ?

I dont know why u reboot to windows to listen to music. if u want to
creative zen to play ogg u should ask them and not blame / curse  GNU
/ linux tools lacking it. in that case, u should go to alternative
music system instead of creative. plugin for mp3 which u had installed
has basic stuff that play mp3 and not other effects. and i guess u r
wrong that u r expecting GNU / Linux to provide that. in that case u
do not understood what GNU / Linux provides.  If u need effects
equivalent to windows, then u must go for support oriented Linux / ask
creative to give binary drivers for linux.

FYI, i play these formats in my linux box  - mp3, wmv, avi, ogg, 3gp, mov.
i installed the needed software / plugins that is available in the
internet which are known to me.

for mp3 licensing check below links
http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/07/14/mp3_tenth_birthday/
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MP3
http://www.mp3licensing.com/help/index.html
http://www.iusmentis.com/copyright/nl/mp3/mp3legal/

and u could understand why distros not bundling mp3 supports. M$ have
paid to Thomson for  supporting since its wmv format didnt succeed
much. u could check the "Licensing and patent issues" column from the
url  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MP3

u could check the licensed companies list here
http://www.mp3licensing.com/licensees/index.asp

more over, till redhat linux 7.3, redhat was able to play mp3 by
default. but during the release of redhat 8, mp3 license have been
changed i.e even decoders have to pay licencse.

now i hope u would understand why winamp, Microsoft were able to play.

From mdshah82 at yahoo.com  Sun Aug 20 10:26:10 2006
From: mdshah82 at yahoo.com (Hassan)
Date: Sun Aug 20 22:56:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How far we are going to Compromise ?
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0608200302w5356e1a7oa7d270a360e0c00b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060820172610.64959.qmail@web30409.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

Hi Chaks,

 Great to see a post from you on desktop computing. 

My only concern is why does the linux community always tries to eat someone else' pie ? Desktop is/was/will be microsoft's arena - unless ofcourse someone like Redhat/Novell tried to build a worthy linux desktop - Frankly I don't see that happening anytime soon. 

Redhat is nothing short of a traitor - They gained immense popularity due to their free (as in cost & freedom) desktop version. But once they were under limelight, they abandoned their desktop users for their enterprise customers (If you think FC is any good - think again - it could have been the coolest distro - something that could have challenged MS - But not anymore). The truth is many adopt linux because it is free of cost and not because of its ideology.It is only the community that feels that way. To the normal user in India, it is just the cost factor that matters.


>> When companies like Novell,RedHat have decided their target are Desktop
>> Users, why would they not get exclusive rights like how M$ has ?. Sure,
>> there should be a way. If M$ is able to do things, why not WE.

As for this, all that I can say is no company is going to put money into a business that won't pay back. Lets assume Redhat (highly unlikely) buys all the rights for these patented technologies & releases it for no charge to the desktop users. So far so good. But what is Redhat gaining ? A great user base. But what is the point of an userbase that probably won't buy any of the desktop software - as there are free alternatives for almost everything else. 

Or maybe lets say Redhat releases the product and charges for each license (most of the patented techs expect royalties for each copy - so it is only natural)... do you think the average user will buy it ? No way. To him/her it is just  like paying for windows os. To them it really won't matter if it comes with source or not - After all how many average users have you seen who are willing to go in deep to the source level ? Maybe some in the linux community might buy a few copies to show solidarity.... Or maybe redhat could give the os for free and then run advertisements on your desktop :) But that would turn it into another MS.... 

My point is why at all are we targetting desktop computing at all. Linux' strength lies in the server market... and we have credible competitors there - AIX & open-solaris. That is the place where linux can outshine MS, IBM & Sun. 

Linux might become a victim of its own success. Concerted efforts in a specific direction yields better results than trying to progress in multiple directions.


regards,
Hassan


Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote: Hi all,

Before reading my mail, I would like you all to read Open Source guru
advocates ideological
shift

Thats running in my mind for more than 6 months. How far GNU/Linux is gonna
compromise on the Desktop Market ?

The people who are going to use GNU/Linux as their Desktop arent geeks(like
us). They do not even know what a "command line tool" and no way you can
make him/her to learn, as he/she would tell, why would he/she has to learn
!.

We do know that there are patent rights with Mp3,DVD etc., There are no
support for many plugin formats for the same reason too. If one needs such
things to be done, he/she is redirected to pages like ,

   - For Ubuntu 
   - For Novell/SuSE
   - For RedHat

Dont these have to work out of the box if you really want it to be used by
the normal people ?

Yes, companies need to compromise and thats what M$ had done during the
start (Gud or Bad,one has to admit).

I would say this is one of the reasons, people fear of adopting GNU/Linux
into Desktops.

When companies like Novell,RedHat have decided their target are Desktop
Users, why would they not get exclusive rights like how M$ has ?. Sure,
there should be a way. If M$ is able to do things, why not WE.

Take a GNU/Linux Desktop Oriented Distro, list out things what would be
required to make it still better(in terms of out of the box support), let us
prepare the list, take survey, and submit online the results.This will help
the companies understand that there are quite large number of people needing
these requirements.(I am sure they would know already)

There are many other things also that we need to compromise. There are many
proprietary products in Linux itself (like, CrossOverOffice) which are great
deal for Desktop Users. If we neglect them,and just strive for only FREE(as,
Free of Cost), I think the situation would be the same and sure normal
people would not be able to use GNU/Linux.

Am not at all telling that GNU/Linux is not growing or there are only
pitfalls. These issues are something we need to keep track of.And my kind
advice would be to spread the word FREE as in FREE TO USE/REDISTRIBUTE and
not as in FREE OF COST. That leads into a different scenario.

We are doing a good job in spreading about GNU/Linux by conducting LDDs at
various institutions. Is there any way to conduct LDD for the normal public
?. If so, then , it would be great show and sure our voices will reach the
Public, Media.

One of the main reason for me to be with Freespire  ,
is their Vision on how to make GNU/Linux best in the Desktop Usage. They
have legal rights in giving out the restricted
formatsout
of the
box.Please dont think am here to spread about Freespire. These things are
the basic needs for a Desktop User.

The future of GNU/Linux is good if we make GNU/Linux the best in Desktop
Usage as stated by Eric Raymond.

Hassan wrote:
> Hi Chaks,
> 
>  Great to see a post from you on desktop computing. 
> 
> My only concern is why does the linux community always tries to eat someone else' pie ? Desktop is/was/will be microsoft's arena - unless ofcourse someone like Redhat/Novell tried to build a worthy linux desktop - Frankly I don't see that happening anytime soon. 
> 
> Redhat is nothing short of a traitor - They gained immense popularity due to their free (as in cost & freedom) desktop version. But once they were under limelight, they abandoned their desktop users for their enterprise customers (If you think FC is any good - think again - it could have been the coolest distro - something that could have challenged MS - But not anymore).

This message seems confused.

If organizations change their product strategy to target a set of 
consumers which according to you would make sense better anyway, then it 
should be a bad idea to do just that while contributing to open source

http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/RedHatContributions

If the "linux community" shouldnt eat someone else's pie there isnt any 
need for Fedora Core to challenge MS. Note that there is a number of 
people out there who havent ever used computers and that number is 
currently larger than MS users. .

A project's success is evaluated against their objectives and Fedora 
Core's objectives doesnt include any ideas about competing against any 
vendors.

http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Objectives

Rahul

Hi,

Patents are evil in the sense that they block further innovations that extend the basic idea without the creator's consent. However they also protect the creator's ownership. So I would say they are a necessary evil :) We cann't untangle ourselves from it completely.

Hassan

On Sunday 20 August 2006 23:27, Antano Solar John wrote:
> cant stop accepting gifts (creative zen) lol .......... anyway thanks for
> the information on licensing , i used to think decoding was allowed in mp3
> without any license

Sure it is... In India!

AFAIK, we don't have anything in our laws allowing software patents. So, 
anything that Thompson wants to charge us is essentially illegal, because 
India doesn't recognize their patent to begin with! ;-)

Anyway, I have a Creative Zen (beautiful device, all other considerations 
aside), and I use libnjb (libnjb.sourceforge.net) and Amarok (amarok.kde.org) 
to keep it in sync with my system - in fact, I don't even use the Zen in 
Windows anymore, because libnjb and Amarok do everything I want them to do 
with it (well, most things, anyway - and I have only myself to blame for 
other things - I'm supposed to be the guy maintaining the Amarok NJB 
plugin :-) )...

I'd suggest that you use something like Amarok and the Xine engine to play 
mp3s. I haven't had any trouble with that particular front for years now...

Shash

From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul)
Date: Mon Aug 21 00:19:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How far we are going to Compromise ?
In-Reply-To: <BAY12-F2544DE9A0FBA12C0D281069E400@phx.gbl>

Antano Solar John wrote:
> corrct me if i am wrong ........... if i have a mp3 player (hardware 
> one) which used to decode mp3 ,manufactured before decoding of mp3 
> needed licensing then am i breaking license if i decode mp3 with this 
> old player ???? if no , then will i break license if i decode mp3 with a 
> software module written compiled and released even before mp3 decoding 
> needed licensing ??? if i dont ,,, then maybe we can bundle older 
> decoders that supported mp3 with our linux distro :)
> 

No, that wouldnt work. Patents are not tied to the software copyright 
licenses, authors or time of release. After a patent is filed and 
approved any software that uses the process described in the patent 
would be infringing it unless the implementation has a patent license or 
someone manages to overthrows the patent or until the patent expires.

Rahul

Hassan wrote:

I agree on this.. I think usability can be measured by the number of
times the user has to reach for the command line. The raw fact of life
is that windows and osx users rarely *have* to use the CLI, whereas
linux users always keep a terminal open at all times.

I realise the power of the CLI (and that is one of the reasons i prefer
linux to windows), but to a more general user, the CLI would hold little
interest.

But once they had enough corporate customers, they sidestepped their desktop users...

And to become "patriot", they must treat the fedora project on par with their enterprise distro and fund it accordingly...

Hi,

I don't have the exact figures (in $). I have to admit that. But I can provide links that clearly show how redhat alienated their user base. This is not the complete list. I will get back with many more links. For the time being, please check out this link:

 http://www.freesoftwaremagazine.com/articles/editorial_13
 
 A few interesting lines from the article:
 
 A number of things happened in the following years (1997 to 2005). Here are a few of them, in chronological order: the packaged version of Red Hat Linux flopped (why would anybody buy it, if you can download it? Plus, yes, it was overpriced...). Red Hat went public, and started having a number of investors that wanted to see good, realistic plans to make money?which meant focusing more on the corporate market. Then, the split: Fedora came along, but it was underfunded and the ?community involvement? was patchy and disorganised. Eventually, Red Hat effectively abandoned its desktop audience, to focus on the more lucrative corporate market.....

I am convinced that Red Hat is now starting to realise that losing their desktop users didn?t just mean ?losing the suckers who didn?t pay a cent anyway? (this is not a quote, by the way), because a lot of those ?suckers? were system administrators, who will soon have to decide between Red Hat Linux and Ubuntu Server. And when you use Ubuntu Server as your home system, the choice really can go either way.

Check out the following links where Fedora Project Lead Max Spevack tries hard to win back the user-community by saying that fedora was always production quality (even if not publicly declared by redhat from 2003)... Looks like Redhat is finally facing the heat from Ubuntu - not only in the desktop market but also server market (this is really great news for me - serves them right for sidestepping the desktop users...)

http://asay.blogspot.com/ (Aug 18 entry)...
http://interviews.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=06/08/17/177220&from=rss

And guess what ? Redhat is not planning to release fedora to the community as a separate foundation. They want to tightly keep fedora under their control - ofcourse they cite different reasons for the decision. Looks like they are finally seeing light at the end....

regards,
Hassan

From girish1729 at yahoo.com  Sun Aug 20 23:10:07 2006
From: girish1729 at yahoo.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Mon Aug 21 11:40:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] RH 9 - Hanging - virus?
In-Reply-To: <5fdc4a7b0608202246q6fdd6378x782798e2683c7003@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060821061007.36737.qmail@web35610.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

--- Sundar SM <mee.sundar@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi all
> 
> I'm Using RH9. Its getting hangup very often,
> particularly when i'm browsing
> (other times its not so). I feel it could be a
> problem created by any virus,
> warms or some thing like that.
> Can u give me a solution Please?
> 
> I've not yet seen any virus scanner for Linux yet.
> Which one is the best to
> kill all kind viruses?
> 
> Please Help me...
Sure! We are all here only to help!

Interesting to see that you attribute slowness or
"hanging" or freezing to viruses and worms. 

I have never heard of any virus in the UNIX world. Not
even once. There are however worms, trapdoors, Trojan
horses blah blah blah. 

Certainly not some Windoze like virus that slows down
the machine. In fact one of the main reasons folks
prefer Linux is for this fact; that it is completely
free of viruses.

Also mischief mongers don't want to hurt linux users,
so the possibility of there being future viruses also
is slim.

Worms are a totally different beasts however. They
usually cause havoc in the network like routers or
cause denial of service attacks. At best I think a
linux "virus" may hog your bandwidth, nothing more. 

Anyway to answer ur question, you should check whether
you have setup sufficient swap space, try using hdparm
for your hard disk(usually not recommended) or use a
lightweight browser like netscape or even galeon if
your machine is an old one. 

HTH,
Girish

Date: Mon Aug 21 12:38:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mapping Laptop Keys
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0608201151q5653f443va5661c9be69ed6fa@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060821070754.55964.qmail@web35606.mail.mud.yahoo.com>



--- Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi all,
> 
> I am pressing the [b]Internet Shotcut key[/b] in my
> laptop and the key is
> not being recognised. I want this key to open
> firefox when i press.The dmesg
> output is,
> 
> chakkaradeep@Chaks:~$ dmesg | tail
> [17187141.032000] atkbd.c: Unknown key pressed
> (translated set 2, code 0xa3
> on isa0060/serio0).
> [17187141.032000] atkbd.c: Use 'setkeycodes e023
> <keycode>' to make it
> known.
> [17187141.276000] atkbd.c: Unknown key released
> (translated set 2, code 0xa3
> onisa0060/serio0).
> [17187141.276000] atkbd.c: Use 'setkeycodes e023
> <keycode>' to make it
> known.
> 
> Where should i map these ?

All you have to do is set the appropriate keymap. I
think you can use the shell command kbdcontrol or
something similar. Do a "apropos kbd"

Basically what happens is when you press and release a
key, an interrupt is generated and the kernel reads
the scancode from the keyboard buffer(usually 16
bytes). In your case that is happening perfectly. So
it is good news.

However it should be read by a user space application.
There also seems to be a package called hotkeys which
may help you. The version I downloaded is 0.5.7.1.

I have not been there, done that. 

So this is what I can do at best!

regards,
Girish

My two cents would be that few months ago there was
some big furore over patents and media codecs or some
such thing in Europe and since mplayer is from Hungary
, there was a page citing that unless something was
done things would go wrong or anything. 

As far as I am concerned mplayer is the be all end all
of all media playing in any OS. It is a breeze to
compile if required and you can hack it though the
code is not so well written or organized.

But the bottom line is it can play any damn file on
earth, be it audio, video, television, creating
successive screenshots from videos, or making your own
mng video.. It is simply amazing, mind blowing!

There is no equivalent. 

Another program worthy of mention of course is ffmpeg.
It is so cool , you can convert any format to any
other with a simple command line, audio or video. 

mplayer has the sort of stance that I would take. I
don't care about patents or legalese, I am a hacker
and I can reverse engineer if reqd, I will give users
what they want....

So just read "man mplayer" and also its html
documentation. 

I am yet to find out what mplayer cannot do! :-)

The problem with RMS, ESR today is that they are old-war-generals with
no cause to fight for. When FSF/OSF was started they played a very
important role, but with FOSS becoming pervasive in today's computing
scenario and with the abundance of FOSS developers , the need for
strong-willed ethic/morality based visionaries has decreased.

Is it good or bad ? Well, that depends on what kind of a personality
one is. FOSS today needs more people like Linus, Miguel de Icaza and
Mark Shuttleworth. People who are fighting on purely
business/technological merits rather than on the "ethical" front.

I'm not saying we should compromise on ethics, just that the ethics
argument is now well accepted in the computing world and is no more a
cause to fight for. the GPL has withstood the test of time and FOSS is
no more a activity done by bearded-sandal wearing hippies.

In short, stop harping and stop coding...

-Toufeeq

I would have to disagree with that. There are few people who understand 
the complete details on either the ethical side or the technical 
arguments completely. Both of these are worth repeating to all the 
constant influx of new people flowing in.

Patents issues, DRM etc have become relatively major issues recently and 
unless you continue to reflect upon those changes in licenses and the 
community in general it has the potential to severely curb what Free 
software can do and it has already has in many instances.

If the industry can work purely based on technical arguments that might 
be a good thing but thats not where the competing interests play. If one 
ignore that they stand to lose.

Subject: [Ilugc] How far we are going to Compromise ?
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340608210040h666a771dt340cc025832ba380@mail.gmail.com>

	<c293dd340608210040h666a771dt340cc025832ba380@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44E96BEA.1080303@fedoraproject.org>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:

> 
> Agreed that it's not related to funding. The point I'm trying to raise
> is that of "importance". Fedora hasn't yet received the update to
> Firefox, whereas RHEL has.

Actually Firefox and Thunderbird received the updates on the same day 
the "rant" was posted and the updates were being prepared even before 
the mailing list discussion started.


  The problem is that there is just *one* guy
> who is taking care of mozilla related packages (that includes Firefox
> and TB) for all distro-variants from redHat(including FC). Fedora has
> a huge community(probably the largest) , why can't the maintainership
> of the firefox/thunderbird packages be given to the community members
> if RH feels it's being under-staffed and their developers overworked.

Thats a pretty fair question but it requires you to understand more of 
the details. So here we go.

There are number of related issues.

Fedora Core is Red Hat maintained and has 2000 plus packages which is 
provided in the media (CD/DVD).

Fedora Extras has 3000 plus packages the larger community has access 
towards and maintain. It is not available in media and has a rolling 
updates model.

Fedora Core shares the build system with RHEL right from the Red Hat 
Linux days and the buildsystem happens to be pretty much tied to the 
rest of the Red Hat development infrastructure.

When Fedora Extras needed a buildsystem, Dan William from Red Hat (who 
originally wrote and maintains Network Manager) wrote up a mock based 
buildsystem.

http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Projects/Plague

Fedora Core recently moved into a mock based build system too called 
"brew" and since it is available on media a release has to be made and 
brew does more than just build packages. It also takes care of many of 
the details around release management and unless the community has 
access to these details, patching and building a new package in Fedora 
Core needs to be done within Red Hat.  Firefox and Thunderbird are 
particularly tricky packages since upstream doesnt work with vendor 
security on many occasions and patches needs to be hand picked and 
rolled out.

Moving Firefox to Fedora Extras is not a option since it is the default 
browser for Fedora and needs to be in Fedora Core for now.


> 
> The problem is that RH doesn't want to give up control of Fedora.
> 

Not really. The real issue in this instance is how to get community to 
do maintenance within Fedora Core? If you read the thread you cited 
further, this was discussed there.

Moving more of the packages into Fedora Extras gets them community 
access and this is being over the last few releases. Moving them is not 
easy since end users using a previous release need a upgrade path. 
Fedora Extras was not available during installation time for previous 
releases. Fedora Core 5 Anaconda switched to using Yum internally. In 
Fedora Core 6, Anaconda will have the ability to access any Yum software 
repository during installation including Fedora Extras so now users have 
a more easy upgrade path even when packages move from Fedora Core into 
Fedora Extras and vice versa.

KDE for example is one of the packages planned to be moved into Fedora 
Extras for better community access

http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/UnleashKDE

More work is being done on getting the community to access the build 
system and release management infrastructure so external maintainers can 
work in Fedora Core.  A related thing is moving into a distributed 
source code management into of CVS and the details are available at

http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Infrastructure/Schedule
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Infrastructure/VersionControl

Hang on. We will get there within a release or two.

Rahul

> source code management into of CVS and the details are available at
>
> http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Infrastructure/Schedule [10]
> http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Infrastructure/VersionControl [11]
>
> Hang on. We will get there within a release or two.

ACK.

Thanks for the open-reply. Good to see RH steady on the community path.
Wish you luck.

Subject: [Ilugc] How far we are going to Compromise ?
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340608210202n25cb08d4x887fe962305d06a2@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d2a92d610608201235s71e550b0n82bbed912be66be0@mail.gmail.com>

	<44E956A4.50104@fedoraproject.org>	
	<c293dd340608210040h666a771dt340cc025832ba380@mail.gmail.com>	
	<44E96BEA.1080303@fedoraproject.org>
	<c293dd340608210202n25cb08d4x887fe962305d06a2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44E98196.5040907@fedoraproject.org>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:

>> Fedora Core shares the build system with RHEL right from the Red Hat
>> Linux days and the buildsystem happens to be pretty much tied to the
>> rest of the Red Hat development infrastructure.
> 
> The problem the way I see it then is Fedora is tied down to RH's build
> system _currently_ . But aren't the software-package versions on FC
> and RHEL different ? How does the build system manage this ?

Not all of Fedora. Just Fedora Core. Fedora Core and Red Hat Enterprise 
Linux are just different branches and there are different versions of 
Fedora Core and Red Hat enterprise Linux managed by the same system. 
Heck, managing all the differences in versions and details are what the 
build systems *is* supposed to do anyway. No big surprises there.

> I guess this is where the friction is currently. Isn't it possible to
> get (secured) access for community maintainers into Fedora Core ?

Not currently. There is no china wall between Fedora Core and Red Hat 
Enterprise Linux in the way the build system works and it is not easy to 
set that up while not making it more difficult for people who work on 
Fedora within Red Hat. It is not just infrastructure issues. For 
example, Red Hat cant disclose sensitive details like NDA and business 
contracts associated with Red Hat Enterprise Linux to be known to the 
external community (which would be in violation of agreements) and these 
details are associated with the build system since there are very 
complex US laws (Sarbanes-Oxley commonly referred to as SOX compliance) 
that require you to keep a record of say all source code changes 
developed under a contract and things like that.

In short, the easier way out is to setup external build system machines 
for Fedora not associated with other products. It was deemed too 
disruptive to consider with the release of both Fedora Core 6 and Red 
Hat Enterprise Linux 5 in progress. The plan is start tackling this for 
Fedora Core 7.


> 
> * Will community-maintainership be restricted to only Fedora-Extra's ?

Beyond bug reports and patches to bugzilla, currently yes.

> * Can replication of package-building take place where a clone-build
> is done on Fedora-Extra's for firefox/thunderbird and then placed in a
> "testing" zone for the community to try it out. The FC(RH) maintainer
> can then use that as the Fedora Core package if he is comfortable with
> the test.

Wont work out currently since Fedora Core along with Red Hat Enterprise 
Linux is build on more architectures such as IBM mainframes though 
Fedora for mainframes is not a public release. Red Hat does that for 
continuity between releases. The community of course doesnt have easy 
access to large and costly mainframes and the build system doesnt have a 
easy way to exclude architectures.

http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.advisory-board/352

It is based on the idea that using the exact same source to build 
binaries for all architectures would be better for QA and release 
management but such restrictions would mean that what builds on Fedora 
Extras doesnt necessary build in Fedora Core though vice versa is true.

  I guess this was what was suggested on the discussion but
> giving community access to the build machines for security-related
> packages would also be beneficial. 

In the case of security issues it is thorny because these usually go to 
a relatively closed group first called vendor-sec before the details are 
released to the public after sometime. These vendors then coordinate and 
release fixes. This arrangement is called "responsible" disclosure.

For Fedora, Red Hat acts as the gateway in vendor-sec and gets early to 
security issues. However vendor-sec wont work with random community 
members and the agreements prevent any vendors working within the group 
to let anyone outside it have access to the details for a particular 
time period.

The biggest concern here is about not wanting people to not turn around 
and create exploits with sensitive security issues instead of fixing 
them.  There are ways around that. When Fedora has a history of 
community people working on and fixing security issues these maintainers 
can be setup up to directly work with vendor-sec and take care of Fedora 
security issues.

Some of these efforts are in progress at 
https://www.redhat.com/mailman/listinfo/fedora-security-list

Details at http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security

I guess rawhide is there for the
> unstable-purpose but I'm not sure if the community is involved there ?

Community people test and report bugs but if we are talking about 
package maintainers,  Fedora development tree (Rawhide) is maintained by 
the same developers as Fedora Core (and even Red Hat Enterprise Linux in 
most cases). Similarly between Fedora extras-devel and extras.


> 
>> KDE for example is one of the packages planned to be moved into Fedora
>> Extras for better community access
>>
>> http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/UnleashKDE [9]
> 
> ACK. Go GNOME!
> Not interested in starting flame-wars..

This move would benefit KDE too since the main maintainer taking over is 
Rex Dieter (Primary developer behind http://kde-redhat.sf.net 
repository). He is a also a fellow board member and is in the Fedora 
Packaging and Fedora Extras steering committee's and already maintains 
several KDE related packages in Fedora Extras.

http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/RexDieter

Rahul

Sending mails are very easy. You can either use a
local MTA or use a remote MTA. Local MTA is easy to
setup.

Figure out how to install exim, postfix or sendmail
for Suse.

Then make sure it is running with 
nc localhost 25

If it greets u u r set.

however receiving mails will not work. 

Sending is easy, get that right first. We will
worry about recving later.

On 8/21/06, Rahul <sundaram@fedoraproject.org> wrote:
> Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
>
> > I'm not saying we should compromise on ethics, just that the ethics
> > argument is now well accepted in the computing world and is no more a
> > cause to fight for. the GPL has withstood the test of time and FOSS is
> > no more a activity done by bearded-sandal wearing hippies.
> >
> > In short, stop harping and stop coding...

TYPO: it's "stop harping and start coding"

> > -Toufeeq
>
> I would have to disagree with that. There are few people who understand
> the complete details on either the ethical side or the technical
> arguments completely. Both of these are worth repeating to all the
> constant influx of new people flowing in.

Is it a necessity that when a new linux user is born he is told the
whole Mahabharata and Ramayana ?

> Patents issues, DRM etc have become relatively major issues recently and
> unless you continue to reflect upon those changes in licenses and the
> community in general it has the potential to severely curb what Free
> software can do and it has already has in many instances.

These don't effect the joe-desktop-user at all. Today's catch phrase
seems to be "It just works and I don't care how it works!".

> If the industry can work purely based on technical arguments that might
> be a good thing but thats not where the competing interests play. If one
> ignore that they stand to lose.

There has to be a well defined path on how the battle will be fought
depending on the occasion. If the adversary needs to be conforted on
ethical issues then we need to shift into ethical mode. If the
technology/business mode is required we need to shift into it
correspondingly. The thing is, today's battles on FOSS are shifting
more towards the tech-mode rather than the ethics mode. Basically, we
have played the ethical card multiple times (and at times scared
people away). It's now time to play the tech-cards and those will give
us better results(user-base) than the ethics-cards.

-Toufeeq
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
>> I would have to disagree with that. There are few people who understand
>> the complete details on either the ethical side or the technical
>> arguments completely. Both of these are worth repeating to all the
>> constant influx of new people flowing in.
> 
> Is it a necessity that when a new linux user is born he is told the
> whole Mahabharata and Ramayana ?

The analogy doesnt fit. Free software and the ideas surrounding it is 
not religious epics. On the other hand if you a student studying 
religions it would be a pretty good to know these epics rather than 
discard them as useless artifacts of age old minds. In general its a 
good idea to understand how things has evolved especially if you are 
directly benefiting from those ideas. We dont study history as students 
for nothing.


> 
>> Patents issues, DRM etc have become relatively major issues recently and
>> unless you continue to reflect upon those changes in licenses and the
>> community in general it has the potential to severely curb what Free
>> software can do and it has already has in many instances.
> 
> These don't effect the joe-desktop-user at all. Today's catch phrase
> seems to be "It just works and I don't care how it works!".
> 

Setting aside the fact that every user is affected by different set of 
things and so called "joe desktop user" is a mythical non existent 
caricature, DRM is something that does affect typical desktop users 
playing videos or listening to songs (Why am I being restricted that the 
songs I brought can only being played 5 times in a year?). Patent issues 
do too indirectly (why cant I play mp3 or watch encrypted DVD's?). Our 
value systems are not tied to what typical desktop users care about and 
doing so is a very narrow view point . Linux is flexible enough to a 
broad variety of needs.


> There has to be a well defined path on how the battle will be fought
> depending on the occasion. If the adversary needs to be conforted on
> ethical issues then we need to shift into ethical mode. If the
> technology/business mode is required we need to shift into it
> correspondingly.

Right. It is just that ignoring political issue like software patents or 
trying to solve them technically doesnt work.  Legal problems might very 
well render Free software unusable in several places. If you dont care 
about that you drive yourself into a niche.


  The thing is, today's battles on FOSS are shifting
> more towards the tech-mode rather than the ethics mode. Basically, we
> have played the ethical card multiple times (and at times scared
> people away). It's now time to play the tech-cards and those will give
> us better results(user-base) than the ethics-cards.

In principle if you are scared by ethical arguments then you need to 
understand that aspect better rather than question people whose value 
systems are different than yours. A large amount of the community has 
got involved got into it because of the ethical side of the argument. 
Sure, there are technical side effects of the system and that has its 
place. One shouldnt brush off the technical benefits but its only fair 
to take into other beliefs into consideration especially when there are 
more and more non-technical issues affecting Free software.


Rahul

We have been discussing these things in two threads :)

If you ask me, today , people are expecting Solutions. They are more
inclined to the nature that , If they insert DVD/VCD/MP3 disc/Audio CD it
just has to play. They are not even bothered of DRM or patents. They are
asking for out of the box support. If you tell them about DRM and other
stuffs, they are not going to listen to us. I have faced such problems with
many people :(.

But yes, how far GNU/Linux can come down to these patents and other stuffs
is still a mystery.

From chaks.yoper at gmail.com  Mon Aug 21 17:30:10 2006
From: chaks.yoper at gmail.com (Chakkaradeep C C)
Date: Mon Aug 21 17:30:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Is this option available in Linux Servers?
Message-ID: <a54a308e0608210500m5279c74ar2f9d28ff3318d9f@mail.gmail.com>

Hi all,

We host Thick Servers and Thin Clients.We had planned a lot with Linux
Servers but now we have to deploy in Windows Server 2003.However, next month
the same deployment is going to be started in Linux(most probably, we will
be getting SLES).

I was checking in Windows Terminal Services and one point hit me directly
and i dont know how we are going to implement in Linux as we havent found a
solution for this till today.

Here is an extract from Microsoft Terminal Service Document,

Terminal Services is a technology that lets users run Microsoft(r)
Windows(r)-based applications on a remote Windows Server 2003-based computer.
In a Terminal Server-based computing environment, all application execution
and data processing occur on the server. In a load balanced environment, a
farm of terminal servers have incoming session connections distributed in a
balanced manner across the servers in the farm. The session directory (SD)
keeps a list of sessions indexed by user name, and allows a user to
reconnect to the terminal server where the user's disconnected session
resides and resume that session.

Now, in Linux, we do have VNC(with several encoding algorithms) and one
problem is solved.What about the Session Management?. We have not got a
simple solution on this. Its like this,

   - User logs into the Server
   - User gets the login screen and he enters his username and pwd
   - Server checks for the last login and saved session
   - If any saved session, start the saved session
   - If there is no any saved session, start a new session

In Windows we are actually opening Sessions across many Terminal Servers
which are put up in a single Server Cluster with Network Load Balancing
enabled.

I would be happy if people could give me input on the above and I need to
implement this in Linux, mainly Session Management.Somehow, it works
directly in Windows Server 2003 ;(

Thanks.
--

Chakkaradeep C C wrote:

> 
> We have been discussing these things in two threads :)
> 
> If you ask me, today , people are expecting Solutions. They are more 
> inclined to the nature that , If they insert DVD/VCD/MP3 disc/Audio CD 
> it just has to play. They are not even bothered of DRM or patents. They 
> are asking for out of the box support. If you tell them about DRM and 
> other stuffs, they are not going to listen to us. I have faced such 
> problems with many people :(.

Products produce "solutions". You are free to cater to such people 
moving into short term benefits but claiming that everyone is expecting 
such solutions or that only technical arguments are the valid ones while 
taking other aspects of the system as granted are going to create *more* 
issues like the above.  There is no way to implement a Free software 
player for a proprietary codec restricted by patents.  There is no way 
to solve issues like software patents in a technical way since it is 
fundamentally not a technical problem at all. If your "solution" is to 
include non-free software, go ahead. Good luck to you.

Rahul

We need both technical and ethical. They are two sides of the same
coin. For those who don't care about ethical issues please look at
the piracy rate especially among academics. All those who use illegal
copies are technically staisfied with them. What is wrong in talking
about ethical issues and advocating shifting to FOSS?

In the end I feel each user should see FOSS in his/her own angle -
may be cost, may be technical or may be ethical.

From solar345 at hotmail.com  Mon Aug 21 12:21:51 2006
From: solar345 at hotmail.com (Antano Solar John)
Date: Mon Aug 21 17:51:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mapping Laptop Keys
In-Reply-To: <20060821070754.55964.qmail@web35606.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <BAY12-F11A5C32CC6E292A69967A89E410@phx.gbl>

there is something called interrupt vector table and i think the keyboard 
interupt is either 8 or 9 . you need to place your function in memory and 
change the address to in the ivt to your fuctions address and then when a 
key is pressed check the scancode if it is anything other than the key you 
want to monitor call the function stored in the previous ivt space for the 
particular interrupt  , otherwise perform the function that you wanted your 
key to perform....

interrupt and ivt are bios concepts so i think it must work on linux also  
but i havent tried it.

> > [17187141.032000] atkbd.c: Use 'setkeycodes e023

>
>All you have to do is set the appropriate keymap. I
>think you can use the shell command kbdcontrol or
>something similar. Do a "apropos kbd"
>
>Basically what happens is when you press and release a
>key, an interrupt is generated and the kernel reads
>the scancode from the keyboard buffer(usually 16
>bytes). In your case that is happening perfectly. So
>it is good news.
>
>However it should be read by a user space application.
>There also seems to be a package called hotkeys which
>may help you. The version I downloaded is 0.5.7.1.
>
>I have not been there, done that.
>
>So this is what I can do at best!

I think Solaris Sparc machines directly supported
session resumption with a keyboard key in the CDE
desktop environment. One day my friend demonstrated it
to me. I have also been able to save sessions in
Windowmaker. It is trivial to do in others also, but
there are complications like saving passwords for
restarting sessions with remote machines or even for
the root user.

There are also thin client implementations for FreeBSD
and I saw a recent thread in that list. But that is by
exporting the display alone, they weren't actually
bothered by session management. 

IOW, nothing that Windows 2003 server can do exists
tha t linux cannot. :-)

HTH,
Girish

From stylesen at gmail.com  Mon Aug 21 20:15:37 2006
From: stylesen at gmail.com (Senthil Kumaran S)
Date: Mon Aug 21 20:16:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] linux installation-problem
In-Reply-To: <4a8ca98f0608210439n5b620fe7v7d0660242f7bc3a1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <4a8ca98f0608210439n5b620fe7v7d0660242f7bc3a1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <5ef2113c0608210745h38502f58u2059c693f673b90f@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/21/06, vinodh kumar <vinstce@gmail.com> wrote:
>          i have a problem in installing debian 3.1  sarge in my computer
> ...   problem is linux doesnot detect my harddrive...

Why don't you try the default kernel ie., 2.4. I had the same problem
yesterday when I tried to install debian in a Dell inspirion 6000
laptop which had and ATAxxx type 80 G harddisk. After going through
many forums and lot of googling I found that debian install without a
glitch if we try the 2.4 kernel ie., the default one, in dell
inspirion and it worked. Also I found from many forums that support
for ATA type hard disks was somehow broken in the development tree
after >2.4.27 kernel development... May be it may be resumed in some
latest kernel development trees.

Also I met with the same problem some one year before while I was in
college trying to install debian in newly procured HP desktop machines
which had SATA harddisks. Then also we used 2.4 kernel from the debian
installer and the installation went smoothly ie., the SATA disk was
detected.

Its always easy to compile 2.6 kernel from this point once you have
your 2.4 kernel installed.

Another problem was when I found it difficult to install debian in a
HP ML350 machine some 4 months back which is a server grade machine.
This time the problem is different everything went fine and it failed
in the last step ie., during the grub installation. This was basically
due to the naming convention which HP followed for naming the raided
disk, they call it something like this /dev/cciss0, /dev/cciss1, etc.
Due to the above naming convention grub searched for /dev/hda which
was unavailable. I was trying hard to get a solution for the above and
I got one which involved getting into the terminal during the
installation changing the device.map file to point to /dev/cciss for
hd0. Some time later the easiest solution I got was to get the latest
installer build by the smartest and fastest working debian community,
which solved the naming convention problem introduced by HP.

So I ll suggest 2 solutions:
1) Try installing with 2.4 the default kernel shipped with Debian 3.1
2) Else go for downloading the latest installer from debian.org

I would recomend 2) because for every new type of hardware that is
available in market debian guys comes with a fix in a month or two. So
give it a try :)

From kums at gmx.net  Mon Aug 21 20:21:10 2006
From: kums at gmx.net (Kumaraguru)
Date: Mon Aug 21 20:21:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Undelete: impossible on ext3!
In-Reply-To: <BAY12-F214B143E2AC14B2584FAFC9E410@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY12-F214B143E2AC14B2584FAFC9E410@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <44E9C85E.7040501@gmx.net>

No..no..no! this is not a Linux Vs Windows thing at all. You have 
misunderstood me.. I think you missed the quote from ext3 developer that 
I had given in my very first mail. For your convenience..here it is 
again (from http://lkml.org/lkml/2003/1/7/135)

<quote>
..in order to ensure that ext3 can safely resume an unlink after a
crash, it actually zeros out the block pointers in the inode, whereas
ext2 just marks these blocks as unused in the block bitmaps and marks
the inode as "deleted" and leaves the block pointers alone.
Your only hope is to "grep" for parts of your files that have been 
deleted and hope for the best...
</quote>

As he clearly explains, ext2 will maintain pointers to deleted blocks 
while ext3 will not. That means, we know where the deleted blocks are 
and there's a way we can differentiate them from the unused blocks that 
never had any data before. fat32 has a similar way. So there is a 
logical possibility to undelete. As ext3 doesn't maintain such pointers 
to deleted blocks, there's no reliable way we can know where the deleted 
blocks are. I hope you see the difference now.

Another thing..if your ext3 partition is fragmented then you won't be 
able to retrieve your file completely by reading the partition 
contiguously. One part of your file may be in one place and another 
somewhere else.

From girish1729 at yahoo.com  Mon Aug 21 07:55:12 2006

Date: Mon Aug 21 20:25:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] linux installation-problem
In-Reply-To: <D7200A6B-0438-41B4-AA7B-D0346501132C@thenilgiris.com>

--- Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:

> 
> On 21-Aug-06, at 6:22 PM, Binand Sethumadhavan
> wrote:
> 
> >> If your BIOS doesnt detect it debian wouldnt
> either
> >
> > I don't think this is correct. Linux does its
> hardware probing on its
> > own and does not rely on the BIOS to tell it what
> hardware you have.
> 
> for example my bios finds my network card - debian
> doesnt

Well guys, what I meant was that if the cables are
properly inserted and jumpers properly set, then first
you have to ensure that the BIOS sees the disk. 

Remember that it is the BIOS that assigns most of the
IRQs and detects the hard disk, its capacity etc...

In your case of network card not getting found, what
do you mean by "Not found"? 

Of course, debian will find the network card
everytime, it may not be able to use it either due to
IRQ clash(not likely), or NIC problem or memory not
getting mapped. 

If you try googling for the output of dmesg|grep -i
net

then you may get some hints.

As to the interaction between BIOS and linux drivers,
well once linux loads, it doesn't use the BIOS. But
there are exceptions. Every OS uses the BIOS for
certain purposes though no OS relies on it like DOS.

BIOS is very critical and the dependency on BIOS even
after the OS is running is unlikely to get removed.

This is true with all modern OSes, *BSD, linux and
Windoze...

In principle, yes; BIOS drivers have nothing to do
with linux drivers.

regards,
Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] Undelete: impossible on ext3!
In-Reply-To: <44E9C85E.7040501@gmx.net>

oh thanks i didnt know this difference exits between ext2 and ext3


>From: Kumaraguru <kums@gmx.net>
>To: Antano Solar John <solar345@hotmail.com>
>CC: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
>Subject: Re: [Ilugc] Undelete: impossible on ext3!
>Date: Mon, 21 Aug 2006 20:21:10 +0530
>
>No..no..no! this is not a Linux Vs Windows thing at all. You have 
>misunderstood me.. I think you missed the quote from ext3 developer that I 
>had given in my very first mail. For your convenience..here it is again 
>(from http://lkml.org/lkml/2003/1/7/135)
>
><quote>
>..in order to ensure that ext3 can safely resume an unlink after a
>crash, it actually zeros out the block pointers in the inode, whereas
>ext2 just marks these blocks as unused in the block bitmaps and marks
>the inode as "deleted" and leaves the block pointers alone.
>Your only hope is to "grep" for parts of your files that have been deleted 
>and hope for the best...
></quote>
>
>As he clearly explains, ext2 will maintain pointers to deleted blocks while 
>ext3 will not. That means, we know where the deleted blocks are and there's 
>a way we can differentiate them from the unused blocks that never had any 
>data before. fat32 has a similar way. So there is a logical possibility to 
>undelete. As ext3 doesn't maintain such pointers to deleted blocks, there's 
>no reliable way we can know where the deleted blocks are. I hope you see 
>the difference now.
>
>Another thing..if your ext3 partition is fragmented then you won't be able 
>to retrieve your file completely by reading the partition contiguously. One 
>part of your file may be in one place and another somewhere else.
>
>

Looks like we were barking up the wrong tree then.
This is a very simple problem easily fixed. Your MBR
has got corrupted. Get a Debian rescue floppy or CDROM
or even a Windoze floppy or whatever and install an
MBR.

It is in Windoze
C:> fdisk /mbr

Under linux you have to use lilo or grub. Though the
particular command I don't recollect. 

Is that a new disk? Or old one? Did you install
something else already? Since in a new disk the odds
of such a thing happening are one in a million.

vendors, even though they are part of the

Linux is a kernel, not an operating system.

--- Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> --- Girish Venkatachalam <girish1729@yahoo.com>
> wrote:
> > linux kernel is
> > buggy. its network drivers don't support many
> cards.
> 
> Let's get to the basics. 
> 
> Linux kernel development is separate from driver
> development. Network drivers are usually provided by
> vendors, even though they are part of the
> kernel-space.

Drivers form the most critical part of an operating
system no matter whether in kernel or user space. And
most of the ethernet card drivers are written by Alan
Cox(or someone like that :-) and are open source, only
for few cards binary blobs exist.

Whereas OpenBSD has taken the approach of never
putting a binary blob and always making their code,
documentation , everything completely open. Remember,
OpenBSD's licensing is one of the most open and
business friendly. They don't distribute their ISOs
but other than that, you cannot point out any selfish
interest there.

In fact I feel OpenBSD is the best operating system
when it comes to cleanliness of design and lack of
politics. It is amazing how much a lone warrior called
Theo de Raadt has achieved with just a bunch of
hackers.

In fact if I get commit access to OpenBSD code base I
will consider myself blessed.

The kernel I know the most is the OpenBSD kernel and I
simply love its coding style, elegance and simplicity.

NetBSD seems to be the grand daddy of driver design
and architecture. They even have portable drivers with
each layer clearly separated. I have not yet seen
NetBSD kernel code, so I can't comment here.

Coming back to linux, which is a kernel as u rightly
mentioned, there is not much cohesion between the
various kernel components possibly owing to the huge
number of ppl working on it and Linus's lust for
control. 

If linux had a set of several committers to take in
changes like FreeBSD, things could have been better. 

Hence many folks who submit patches to the linux
kernel are disappointed since their patch may take
months to get noticed.

Whereas with the BSDs , a patch is accepted or
rejected immediately.

Moreover linux kernel has several design deficiences
to begin with. 

Ok now, I don't want to get alienated from the group
for speaking the truth. :-)

Some ppl attach a certain childish religious fervour
to these things and get offended for silly reasons.

When we get too attached , we become resistant and
defensive when someone points out faults.

Truth suffers in the process. For most of us truth is
what we want to believe. :-)

You can argue that just bcoz I say something it is not
truth and brush it aside that it is just my "opinion"
but then I welcome you to form an opinion for
yourselves.

I am just presenting my observations here. 

regards,
Girish

Apropos of session management I got a few new
thoughts. 

For me at least what I care the most when I have a
power outage is losing the open windows in firefox.

It is lamentable that despite being recent, firefox
hasn't learnt from Opera that session management
should be enabled be default. Even galeon has it. 

Anyway with the tabmix plugin everything works like a
charm, even the page offsets are preserved.

Now, if I have ten xterms or wterms or whatever, in
each of them I will have a different state. I will be
reading a man page, "less somethign.txt" , or vim
file1, file2 , file3.

How to save and restore these things? This presents an
interesting problem. I guess you have to go into the
application level and make changes. 

In this context it may not be inappropriate to talk of
journaling file systems. How they support saving and
restoring state also may be explored though I wonder
if it directly relevent to what we are talking.

regards,
Girish

Harish,

On 8/22/06, ttharish <tt.harish@gmail.com> wrote:
> i have a system with the following configuration..
>
>
>    - AMD ATHALON 64 bit PROCESSOR
>    - ASUS 8VMX MOTHER BOARD
>    - 160 GB SATA HARD DISK
>    - 1 GB HEINIX RAM
>
> and plus all the other stuff..
> the problem is that if i want to install linux my system is getting booted
> up but halfway after the process ie at the time of partition its giving me a
> message as NO HARD DRIVE FOUND...
> i dont know why it happens.. but a live cd is workin very well..
> pls help me ..
> is there any problem with SATA drive....

You need to provide more information:

Which distro did you try?
There are some issues with SATA drives with old distros, but the
latest ones must support them. And some BIOSes provide a way to
disable SATA and make them look like PATA(IDE). If you have such a
BIOS, enable PATA emulation and retry the installation. If you are
successful in installing the system like this, you may later try and
enable SATA. Sometimes the kernels used in the installers are older
than the ones in the distros that they install.

Shuveb Hussain.

From sundaram at fedoraproject.org  Tue Aug 22 10:51:09 2006
From: sundaram at fedoraproject.org (Rahul)
Date: Tue Aug 22 10:51:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How far we are going to Compromise ?
In-Reply-To: <20060822001611.90922.qmail@web30405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20060822001611.90922.qmail@web30405.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <44EA9445.9040603@fedoraproject.org>

Hassan wrote:

> Well I don't understand what is being implied by "Going back to a 
> product line that didnt work out well is not patriotism" ?

Dropping a product or creating new products has absolutely nothing to do 
with patriotism in any organization. So lets cut the drama and 
concentrate on the facts.


  Do you mean
> Redhat 8.0 & 9.0 didn't rock - well I was under the impression that 
> these two were the prime reasons why Redhat gained media glare in the 
> first place. 

The product line was absolutely good. It just didnt work well as a 
business. Good products are not always good business. There are multiple 
reasons for that in the case of Red Hat Linux. One of them is that the 
retail world simply doesnt not respond well to releases every six 
months. End users would see Red Hat Linux 6.0 boxes on the shelfs long 
after RedHat Linux 8 was released, buy it out for say 40 dollars and 
call up Red Hat for support. Since the customer brought the product 
thats natural however that particular version had a lifecyle of usually 
an year and would have long since been EOL'ed leaving everyone frustrated.

There is also the fact that selling Free software on CD's works only 
when users dont have access to broad band connections which was 
increasingly not the case world over. (FSF made relatively good business 
long back selling emacs on CD's for example).

Fedora is again on a six month release cycle and a year or more worth of 
updates for every release however it side steps the "retail model" 
problem for Red Hat since Red Hat just let local vendors directly 
download redistribute it. It also lets contributors external to Red Hat 
participate and drive  the development of a distribution in various ways 
beyond just reporting bugs.

Red Hat Enterprise Linux isnt a retail product either. It is a 
subscription. You register, pay and download or get it from local vendors.


Correct me if I'm wrong. Secondly, "Going back" ?

I meant going back to a retail model. Like I said both Fedora Core and 
Red Hat Enterprise Linux are not off the shelf products and it doesnt 
depend on retail vendors to play catch up to latest versions available 
solving that problem in different ways for both the consumer and the 
vendor.


  So you do
> accept that redhat didn't give the necessary attention to FC ? And the 
> very idea of splitting FC from the redhat EL shows that.

Fedora Core has a very similar set of engineers within Red Hat to 
product it as much as Red Hat Linux did. It is just developed in a more 
open fashion with community contributors. Like I said bandwidth alone 
for the project costs Red Hat a couple of million dollars every year and 
more resources are being spend every day. So I cant see where there is a 
lack of "attention".

As for the reasons for the split and various other details, see the 
general overview by me at http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Presentations


> 
> Redhat shot itself in its foot by not capitalizing on the desktop 
> version of RH. They could have with some effort made it a worthy 
> competitor to windows (in terms of usability to the average user). 

A few mails back you were arguing that trying to work on the desktop 
market is eating other people's pie, there was money to be made on the 
desktop and vendors should focus just on the servers.  Anyway there is 
both client and server side products from Red Hat. Things will get 
better one step at a time.


As
> for the concept of patriotism, I guess thats what they are trying to do 
> now... 

Again there is no question of patriotism anywhere in this discussion.


Now that Ubuntu has become the popular desktop distro and people
> (sys admins & biz decision makers) are starting to consider Ubuntu for 
> corporate use as well.  
> http://www.freesoftwaremagazine.com/articles/editorial_13

Editorial with a lot of hyperbole about how the sky is falling. 
Everybody could write one.

> 
> However it is amazing to see such support for RH in this forum. I won't 
> loose hope - maybe with the sheer support of guys like you FC might 
> become a quality desktop distro. Hoping for the best.

no thats right because though linux does hardware probing on its own what 
assigns the io addresses is the bios ..... so unless bios assigns a irq and 
other stuff like that linux cant probe through but its not the other way 
ruond ...... if bios detects doesnt mean linux has to detect


>From: "Binand Sethumadhavan" 
>To: "Girish Venkatachalam" 
>CC: "Antano Solar John" , vinstce@gmail.com, 
>ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
>Subject: Re: [Ilugc] linux installation-problem
>Date: Mon, 21 Aug 2006 14:52:30 +0200
>
>On 21/08/06, Girish Venkatachalam  wrote:
>>If your BIOS doesnt detect it debian wouldnt either
>
>I don't think this is correct. Linux does its hardware probing on its
>own and does not rely on the BIOS to tell it what hardware you have.
>
>Binand

I have several systems where the bios is too old to recognize the larger capacity hard-disks now available (pentium III systems) and the hdd's being ~40 to 80GB IDEs.  Linux has no problems detecting these disks once they are labeled as 'none' in bios - i.e. disable bios checks on these disks.  Of course to boot you need a disk which is recognized by the bios (or is there a work around for this?) and so I use older smaller disks for this on the primary partition.  

Regards the original poster's problem regarding sata detection - maybe he could check if the disk is recognized with a live-cd...

Shashi

Subject: [Ilugc] WebService in Perl
Message-ID: <20060822120252.16628.qmail@web8403.mail.in.yahoo.com>

        Hi,
 
 I am trying to create a small webservice using Perl. 
 
 I have 2 files : temp.pl and temper.cgi ( as specified in http://www.perl.com/pub/a/2001/01/soap.html).  When i try calling ,  "$ perl temp.pl" , i am getting the following an error after a gap of around 3-4 minutes: 500 Can't connect to abc:80 (connect: timeout) at temp.pl line 6
 
 Has anyone any previous experience with creating Web-Services using Perl?
 
 Regards,
Venkat
 
 $ cat temp.pl
 #! /usr/local/bin/perl
 BEGIN {push @INC,"/home/xxx/yyy/SOAP/install/lib/5.8.1";}
 
 use SOAP::Lite;
 
   print SOAP::Lite
     -> uri('http://abc/cgi-bin/pqr/venky_temp/Temperatures')
     -> proxy('http://abc/cgi-bin/pqr/venky_temp/temper.cgi')
     -> c2f(37.5)
     -> result;
 
 $ cat temper.cgi
 #! /usr/local/bin/perl
 BEGIN {push @INC,"/home/xxx/yyy/SOAP/install/lib/5.8.1";}
 
 use SOAP::Transport::HTTP;
 
   SOAP::Transport::HTTP::CGI
     -> dispatch_to('Temperatures')
     -> handle;
 
   package Temperatures;
 
   sub f2c {
       my ($class, $f) = @_;
       return 5 / 9 * ($f - 32);
   }
 
   sub c2f {
       my ($class, $c) = @_;
       return 32 + $c * 9 / 5;
   }

abc shud be substituted with the name of the SOAP
server to connect to. i.e., 

print SOAP::Lite>      ->
 uri('http://abc/cgi-bin/pqr/venky_temp/Temperatures')
      ->
 proxy('http://abc/cgi-bin/pqr/venky_temp/temper.cgi')
      -> c2f(37.5)
      -> result;

should read

print SOAP::Lite>      ->

uri('http://www.perl.com/cgi-bin/pqr/venky_temp/Temperatures')
      ->
 proxy('http://abc/cgi-bin/pqr/venky_temp/temper.cgi')
      -> c2f(37.5)
      -> result;  

Of course if you have a proxy you should change that
as well or just leave it out.

HTH,
Girish
PS:- In this case I have used www.perl.com, you should
use your SOAP server.
