On 8/21/06, kannan manoharan <scuffy_tomy@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
>  Is there any command or any solution for this ?

Just a small python script which retrives the URLs from the access.log file:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import re
import sys

file = sys.argv[1]
myfile = open(file, 'r')

p = re.compile(r'.*\"(.*)\".*',re.S)

for linestr in myfile.readlines():
    m = p.match(linestr)
    if m == None:
        pass
    else:
        print m.group(1)

    linestr = myfile.readline()

myfile.close()
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The above will filter only the URLs from access.log and prints. Pass
access.log file's localtion as command line argument to this script :)

--

Sorry I can't help you here as I have no prior exp.
There are folks out there who are better than me. Hope
they will help you out.

AFAIK SOAP is XML tunneled over HTTP. And I don't
think there is a client server architecture here, so I
think what I meant by SOAP server is actually "SOAP
peer" or something.

Already I am talking thro' the hat, so let me stop
right here. :-)

My advice to you would be to learn the SOAP protocol
by browsing. There are lot of excellent resources on
the web. You can go thro' the official specs at w3c I
think.

I have taken months to get certain things working. For
instance I spent one month to get my TV card working
perfectly under linux. I don't care bcoz I care only
about learning.

The more you learn on your own, the more confident you
become, the younger you get and above all the more fun
you have!

Sometimes I feel that if something works first time I
don't learn much. 

In fact if you take the time to solve the problem on
your own, the advantage is that you can become
efficient at what you are doing and proceed much
faster later. So taking time now is actually an
investment, not a waste of time. The best investment
that you can make is not money but your brain and hard
work. :-)

However if you are in a hurry google is your best
friend and relevant documentation of course.

Sorry again that I am not able to help you any
further.

regards,
Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Debian mirror woes (again!), but problem found!
In-Reply-To: <20060822152730.GA7788@localhost>

On Tue, 22 Aug 2006, Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> Again, I am having trouble with the Debian mirror. However, I have
> been able to pinpoint the error exactly this time.
> the Packages.gz file is shown to be updated at 22-Aug-2006 00:56
> Now, reading this file shows that the latest version of, say
> libgtk2.0-dev 2.8.20-1. So, that package deb must be present in
> /pool/main/g/gtk+2.0. Now, they ARE NOT present in our mirror,
> http://10.65.0.42/debian/pool/main/g/gtk+2.0/, and 2.8.18-1 is the
> version present there. But they ARE present in
> http://http.us.debian.org/debian/pool/main/g/gtk+2.0/

well, this is the reverse of the problem reported earlier wherein the
packages were new version but the packages.gz file listed the older
versions. i believe the problem is upstream of us and this is now reported
in the debian-mirrors mailing list. you have indicated that the packages
ARE present in http.us.debian.org. actually, they are not. well, maybe.
http.us.debian.org (or ftp.us.debian.org) resolves into several addresses
and one of the addresses has a broken mirror (its the 204.x address that
is broken). this means that anyone mirroring from ftp.us.debian.org (this
means mamy mirrors including ours) has a finite chance of hitting this bad
server and ending up with a broken mirror.

sriram
From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Wed Aug 23 09:16:16 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (Prof. P. Sriram)
Date: Wed Aug 23 09:16:19 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Debian mirror woes (again!), but problem found!
In-Reply-To: <20060823011943.GA5161@localhost>
References: <20060822152730.GA7788@localhost>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0608222307230.7834@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<20060823010656.GA4522@localhost> <20060823011943.GA5161@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0608230903040.10137@gateway.ae.iitm.ac.in>

On Wed, 23 Aug 2006, Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> And surprisingly, the packages are there now! They have come in during
> the night, I guess!

yes, updates run nightly, so things may get fixed overnight. however, this 
does not mean the problem is solved. since ftp.us.debian.org points to 
multiple addresses and one of these is a broken server, it may just 
be that yesterday we updated from the broken server while today we shifted 
to a good server. till the upstream broken server is fixed, this problem 
will continue to periodically show up.

> However, I have a doubt that the date and time on 10.65.0.42 is not
> right; for the very packages I reported as missing yesterday seem to
> be there with 16th August as their date.

(10.65.0.2 is the on campus address of ftp.iitm.ac.in) the time stamps are
not ours. we replicate the time stamp on the upstream mirror. if everyone
follows this, the time stamp on each individual file will be the same
irrespective of where and when it was mirrored. debian uses the
project/trace directory to store actual repository update time stamps.
this directory will (should) contain files that indicate the mirror path
from ftp-master.debian.org. so, all mirrors should have a file
ftp-master.debian.org. sites that directly mirror from the master site
will have only this file - this would be most of the primary mirror sites.  
we are a secondary (leaf) mirror site - so, our repository will have
additional files and time stamps in this directory corresponding to the
intermediate site(s)  from which we actually mirror. i am also using the 
other common method of putting a last-updated-on file indicating the last 
update (local) time on our mirrored content.

-- 
sriram

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Aug 23 14:25:57 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

Subject: [Ilugc] udev and hotplug
In-Reply-To: <20060823080420.74696.qmail@web35603.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20060823080420.74696.qmail@web35603.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <44EC181D.2020105@frodo.hserus.net>

Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> Then can you tell me how the firmware is downloaded? 
> 
> For instance, just refer to my howto and tell me how I
> can replace hotplug.

/etc/udev/rules.d/80-programs.rules

# This file causes programs to be run on device insertion.
# See udev(8) for syntax.
#
# "Hotplug replacement" is handled in 90-modprobe.rules;  this file only
# specifies rules for those programs that are shipped in the minimal
# Ubuntu system, programs outside of that may ship their own rules.

# Load firmware on demand
SUBSYSTEM=="firmware", ACTION=="add", RUN+="firmware_helper"

You get firmware_helper when you compile udev with:

make EXTRAS=extras/firmware

The 90-modprobe.rules is like this ..

# This file causes modules to be loaded for inserted devices.
# See udev(8) for syntax.
#
# This file should only specify rules that cause modprobe to be called,
# programs that configure or activate hardware should be called in
# 80-programs.rules

ACTION!="add", GOTO="modprobe_end"

# Load S/390 ccw modules using the old-fashioned grepmap
SUBSYSTEM=="ccw", PROGRAM="/sbin/grepmap --udev", \
                                        RUN+="/sbin/modprobe -Qba $result"

# Load IDE class modules based on the media type
SUBSYSTEM!="ide", GOTO="ide_end"
IMPORT{program}="ide_media --export $devpath"
ENV{IDE_MEDIA}=="cdrom",                RUN+="/sbin/modprobe -Qba ide-cd"
[snip other ide-* modules]
LABEL="ide_end"

[snip]

# Load PNP modules with a helper that iterates the device ids
SUBSYSTEM=="pnp", PROGRAM="pnp_modules $devpath", \
                                        RUN+="/sbin/modprobe -Qba $result"

[snip]

LABEL="modprobe_end"

Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote: On 8/21/06, kannan manoharan  wrote:
>  Is there any command or any solution for this ?

Just a small python script which retrives the URLs from the access.log file:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import re
import sys

file = sys.argv[1]
myfile = open(file, 'r')

p = re.compile(r'.*\"(.*)\".*',re.S)

for linestr in myfile.readlines():
    m = p.match(linestr)
    if m == None:
        pass
    else:
        print m.group(1)

    linestr = myfile.readline()

myfile.close()
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The above will filter only the URLs from access.log and prints. Pass
access.log file's localtion as command line argument to this script :)

On 8/23/06, kannan manoharan <scuffy_tomy@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> error is :
>
>
>  =:           cannot open `=' (No such file or directory)
>  sys.argv[1]: cannot open `sys.argv[1]' (No such file or directory)
>  squid: line 5: syntax error near unexpected token `('
>  squid: line 5: `myfile = open(file, 'r')'

Find where is your access.log file generated by squid. In debian I
think it will be in /var/log/squid/

Am not sure about your distro where squid will generate the log. If
you have compiled squid from source and using it am sure you have
edited the squid.conf file. If it is so then just see where have you
specified the localtion for access.log.

Once you got the location of access.log say for example
/var/log/squid/access.log
Then in your terminal run the following:

$ python geturl.py /var/log/squid/access.log

The above command works fine, but I would suggest you to use the following:

$ python geturl.py /var/log/squid/access.log | less

since the access.log file will be fairly huge and if you need to see
the URLs clearly.

I assume that you have copied the above script in a file called
geturl.py. If you dont understand my above explanation please feel
free to ask the question again, am ready to explain it more
elaborately.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Aug 23 20:09:09 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Wed Aug 23 20:09:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Spam Filters -SQLgrey
In-Reply-To: <edd8ce540608230642l121d2b3fqb2d96c86287c590d@mail.gmail.com>
References: <edd8ce540608230642l121d2b3fqb2d96c86287c590d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44ec688d.6Eae/3MBV4M7dZ+G%linux@frodo.hserus.net>

~adarsh~ <vpadarsh@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> Do anybody has hands on experience in using SQLgrey as spam filter.
> How effective is this in filtering the mails.Also please comment on
> DSPAM.
>

Graylisting is well .. kind of effective. But it has some interesting side
effects (that translate to massively delayed email) when it comes up against
another popular spam filtering method called "callbacks" where the receiving
mailserver connects back to the mailserver for the sending address, tries to
send a test mail to verify if the addess exists, before accepting mail.

[that callback thing is one of the defaults on cpanel and i think also plesk -
popular webhosting control panels .. and also used by some large isps like
verizon]

But aside from that, both graylists and "banner delays" are remarkably useful,
and "cheap" methods to cut down spam.

DSPAM, like Spamassassin, is a fairly cpu / disk etc heavy software that
assigns weighted scores to various spam characteristics. Normally - for regular
mailservers where you usually have far more capacity on the server, than you
have users, it should work just fine (you just have to keep tuning it to your
needs, and regularly updating it - its not a hero honda style "fill it, shut
it, forget it" thing). 

For busy mailservers / very large installations you need to do something
different - concentrate on cheaper to implement solutions (well chosen smtp
blocklists, helo checks, banner delays etc)

Long story, that .. and it is not possible to give you a specific answer
without knowing a lot more details - and without your asking specific questions
(more specific than "how effective is technique X and software Y")

	srs

> assigns weighted scores to various spam characteristics. Normally - for regular
> mailservers where you usually have far more capacity on the server, than you
> have users, it should work just fine (you just have to keep tuning it to your
> needs, and regularly updating it - its not a hero honda style "fill it, shut
> it, forget it" thing).
>
> For busy mailservers / very large installations you need to do something
> different - concentrate on cheaper to implement solutions (well chosen smtp
> blocklists, helo checks, banner delays etc)
>
> Long story, that .. and it is not possible to give you a specific answer
> without knowing a lot more details - and without your asking specific questions
> (more specific than "how effective is technique X and software Y")
>
>         srs
>
>

Thanks a lot for the quote.I am trying to implement a spam filter
mechanism on a mailserver with abt 300 users and with lots of traffic.
I have tested the dspam stuff in the basic but not statisfied with the
performance(surely due to lack of tuning).

Thanks & Regards
Adarsh
"Unless you change direction, You are likely to arrive at where you are headed."

 for linestr in myfile.readlines():

Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote: On 8/23/06, kannan manoharan  wrote:
> error is :
>
>
>  =:           cannot open `=' (No such file or directory)
>  sys.argv[1]: cannot open `sys.argv[1]' (No such file or directory)
>  squid: line 5: syntax error near unexpected token `('
>  squid: line 5: `myfile = open(file, 'r')'

Find where is your access.log file generated by squid. In debian I
think it will be in /var/log/squid/

Am not sure about your distro where squid will generate the log. If
you have compiled squid from source and using it am sure you have
edited the squid.conf file. If it is so then just see where have you
specified the localtion for access.log.

Once you got the location of access.log say for example
/var/log/squid/access.log
Then in your terminal run the following:

$ python geturl.py /var/log/squid/access.log

The above command works fine, but I would suggest you to use the following:

$ python geturl.py /var/log/squid/access.log | less

since the access.log file will be fairly huge and if you need to see
the URLs clearly.

I assume that you have copied the above script in a file called
geturl.py. If you dont understand my above explanation please feel
free to ask the question again, am ready to explain it more
elaborately.

From stylesen at gmail.com  Thu Aug 24 10:50:17 2006
From: stylesen at gmail.com (Senthil Kumaran S)
Date: Thu Aug 24 10:50:28 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Proxy
In-Reply-To: <20060824044413.82612.qmail@web8405.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <5ef2113c0608230615y4cdd634h1e867999c9c0dbc1@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060824044413.82612.qmail@web8405.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5ef2113c0608232220w62eaddffsbce4f24d5d46700d@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/24/06, kannan manoharan <scuffy_tomy@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
>  If i ran "python geturl.py /var/log/squid/access.log | less" it says :
>
>  Complete blank page and in end of the page "lines ?-?/? (END)"
>

Yeah I understand your problem. This needs some more insight about
your squid.conf. Just open your squid.conf file and see whether there
is a line called

"emulate_httpd_log on"

If the above is present then your log format will be "common log file
format" in squid terms which will look like this

remotehost rfc931 authuser [date] "method URL" status bytes

For the above format my script works.

If you have not enabled emulate_httpd_log then your log file format is
called "native log file format" which is the default for squid.conf
and it looks like this

For squid 1.0:
time elapsed remotehost code/status/peerstatus bytes method URL

For squid 1.1:
time elapsed remotehost code/status bytes method URL rfc931
peerstatus/peerhost type

And for squid 2.0 there is a small difference in the content.

So when it is this case my script fails. Another easy way to achive
the same thing which my script does is by use of a command :

$ tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log | awk '{print $7}'

The above command is generic enough and works fine for both common and
native file formats. So I would prefer if you use the above command
then you will get what you expect.. Just kick it off and let me know..
Still if you are unable to get the output am ready to help you.

PS: Since I used common log file format based access.log so my python
script failed to perform for native log file format.

-- 
--sen--

Brilliant idea! Let me elaborate . What you want cannot be achieved on some
systems bcoz if the app uses the setsockopt SO_REUSEPORT, then it
won't recv the error. However for the majority of apps, you can make do with
just this on the command line.

$ nc -l 3306
or
$nc -l -p 3306

I am typing from my OpenBSD machine. So the second one might be
relevant for u. Also bear in mind that sometimes, it listens at
127.0.0.1 instead of ur NAT or global IP. So u need to explore that as
well.

HTH,
Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Aug 24 13:43:37 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel size
In-Reply-To: <5fdc4a7b0608232323y818b6cchf363245e035707a4@mail.gmail.com>

I have very little kernel exp. But I will answer some of the queries.

On 8/24/06, Sundar SM <mee.sundar@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi Friends
>
> 1) What is the range of the running kernel stack in main memory?

Kernel has many threads running, each thread has its own stack, and of
course there are interrupt handlers and bottom halves. So kernel as
such has
several contexts and each context requires a stack
though the kernel runs as one single process...

>
> 2) How can you find out size of kernel sapce and user space in your main
> memory?

Usually the virtual mem is divided into 1 GB - 3 GB or 2 GB - 2 GB
halves, one occupied by kernel
and one by user processes.

Remember this is virtual and not real mem. Even RAM + swap space is
hardly 3 GB. This is just a
ballpark figure ,that is all.

top output gives you certain idea about user space processes. But
since the system is so dynamic with processes being born and dying
constantly, even top finds it somewhat hard to give u this info.

Maybe Shakthi can tell u how to figure out kernel mem.
>
> 3) How to find the avialable kernel / user space and used kernel / user
> space? is there any shell command to see that?
>
I told u about top. You could also use the proc filesystem. man proc.

I think you might get some hints looking at /proc/sys/kernel or
something. I don't have access to linux now.

sysctl -a also is your friend. man sysctl.

HTH,
Girish

Netcat will quit after one connection (I haven't seen any option in
the Linux default one to behave as a forking server), so a better
option might be to use xinetd/discard service on the ports you want to
disable.

Hi
 
 Option in my squid.conf :
 
 #  TAG: emulate_httpd_log       on|off
 #       The Cache can emulate the log file format which many 'httpd'
 #       programs use.  To disable/enable this emulation, set
 #       emulate_httpd_log to 'off' or 'on'.  The default
 #       is to use the native log format since it includes useful
 #       information Squid-specific log analyzers use.
 #
 #Default:
 # emulate_httpd_log off
 
  shall i mail the option enable ?

 Kannan M
 
Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote: On 8/24/06, kannan manoharan  wrote:
>  If i ran "python geturl.py /var/log/squid/access.log | less" it says :
>
>  Complete blank page and in end of the page "lines ?-?/? (END)"
>

Yeah I understand your problem. This needs some more insight about
your squid.conf. Just open your squid.conf file and see whether there
is a line called

"emulate_httpd_log on"

If the above is present then your log format will be "common log file
format" in squid terms which will look like this

remotehost rfc931 authuser [date] "method URL" status bytes

For the above format my script works.

If you have not enabled emulate_httpd_log then your log file format is
called "native log file format" which is the default for squid.conf
and it looks like this

For squid 1.0:
time elapsed remotehost code/status/peerstatus bytes method URL

For squid 1.1:
time elapsed remotehost code/status bytes method URL rfc931
peerstatus/peerhost type

And for squid 2.0 there is a small difference in the content.

So when it is this case my script fails. Another easy way to achive
the same thing which my script does is by use of a command :

$ tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log | awk '{print $7}'

The above command is generic enough and works fine for both common and
native file formats. So I would prefer if you use the above command
then you will get what you expect.. Just kick it off and let me know..
Still if you are unable to get the output am ready to help you.

PS: Since I used common log file format based access.log so my python
script failed to perform for native log file format.

On 8/24/06, padma priya <pipri123@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi,
>  Can anyone please give me some pointers on how to take linux system backup.
> Thanks in advance
man dd

for ex,

dd if=/dev/hda1 of=firstharddisk bs=1024

dd if=/dev/hda3 of=homefilesystem bs=1024

This is a raw copy that bypasses the file system. This is
sometimes called disk "ghosting".

There is a very good chance this is not what you are looking for. In
which case you should be more specific.

IOW, accurate answer for the question, but possibly irrelevant for u.

Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] Proxy
In-Reply-To: <20060824094303.94946.qmail@web8413.mail.in.yahoo.com>

	<20060824094303.94946.qmail@web8413.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <5ef2113c0608240314p7a44994eg991012b14d266b40@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/24/06, kannan manoharan <scuffy_tomy@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
>  Is there any posibility to check with date and time ?

Yes of course it could be done. I ll let you explain in detail so that
you can do it..
You have native log file format in a squid which is >= squid 2.0, so
your log format will be like the following:

time elapsed remotehost code/status bytes method URL rfc931
peerstatus/peerhost type

If you are using the follwing command:

$ tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log | awk '{print $3 "\t" $7}'

in the above you ask to print the 3rd and the 7th parameter as in the
native log file format. So if you see the third and seventh are remote
host ip and URL respectively as in the naitve log file format. So if
you want to print the time (which includes date too I suppose) then do
the following:

$ tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log | awk '{print $1 "\t" $3 "\t" $7}'

I think that explains how it works :)

>  And, is there any posibility to block the url by using squid proxy ?

Yes this is very well possible. You should install squidGuard to do
the above. Its again simple to install in that you have different
files in a db folder in which you can specify what are the URLs you
want to block.. As simple as that...

Subject: [Ilugc] System Backup
In-Reply-To: <f789e6550608240159n51538c7cuf7983d06aef6704c@mail.gmail.com>
References: <f789e6550608240159n51538c7cuf7983d06aef6704c@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/24/06, padma priya <pipri123@gmail.com> wrote:
>  Can anyone please give me some pointers on how to take linux system backup.

I use http://www.nongnu.org/rdiff-backup/.  It provides incremental, snapshot
backups that are space and bandwidth efficient.  You can run your backups
on remote machines, or local/removeable disk.

I have ~3 TB sitting on this stuff, and highly recommend it to anyone who's
looking for a disk based backup solution.

- Raja

Hi,

You can do that in the GUI itself.

Go into Applications > System Settings > Security Level

In that, you will have two tabs firewall and SELinux.

Enable the Firewall and whatever configuration you want.

On 8/24/06, Sundar SM <mee.sundar@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi Friends
>
> 1) What is the range of the running kernel stack in main memory?


look at /proc interface.

cat /proc/iomem | grep -i 'kernel data'. You would get the address range.


2) How can you find out size of kernel sapce and user space in your main
> memory?


Do u mean virtual memory? if yes just check this code


main()
{
   char *ch = getenv("HOME");
   if((unsigned long)ch > (unsigned long)(0x7FFFFFFF))
      printf("3/1 GB split\n");
   else
      printf("2/2 GB split\n");

}



you can enable memory_accounting option in kernel configuration. User space
memory can be calculated using sum of (pmap <each pid from /proc> | grep -i
'total'). U can write a small script to calculate the total user space. But
remind it will not give you the actual size.

If u want to write a kernel module , then u can do like...by manipulating
(task_struct,mm_struct,vm_area_struct). You could pass the PID from /proc
interface
as a parameter and manipulate the total size.



3) How to find the avialable kernel / user space and used kernel / user
> space? is there any shell command to see that?



cat /proc/meminfo


I am also learning kernel programming.  if i do mistake please correct me.

Any idea? Please lets share.
> --
>
Thanks
Suman

Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote: On 8/24/06, kannan manoharan  wrote:
>  Is there any posibility to check with date and time ?

Yes of course it could be done. I ll let you explain in detail so that
you can do it..
You have native log file format in a squid which is >= squid 2.0, so
your log format will be like the following:

time elapsed remotehost code/status bytes method URL rfc931
peerstatus/peerhost type

If you are using the follwing command:

$ tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log | awk '{print $3 "\t" $7}'

in the above you ask to print the 3rd and the 7th parameter as in the
native log file format. So if you see the third and seventh are remote
host ip and URL respectively as in the naitve log file format. So if
you want to print the time (which includes date too I suppose) then do
the following:

$ tail -f /var/log/squid/access.log | awk '{print $1 "\t" $3 "\t" $7}'

I think that explains how it works :)

>  And, is there any posibility to block the url by using squid proxy ?

Yes this is very well possible. You should install squidGuard to do
the above. Its again simple to install in that you have different
files in a db folder in which you can specify what are the URLs you
want to block.. As simple as that...

From: Philip Hallstrom <freebsd@philip.pjkh.com>
Date: Aug 23, 2006 10:04 PM
Subject: Re: Cluster mail system using FreeBSD
To: bsd <bsd@todoo.biz>
Cc: Liste FreeBSD <freebsd-questions@freebsd.org>


> I am looking for the best possible solution in order to setup a High
> availability mail cluster using FreeBSD (smtp/imap/pop server with 1000
> accounts).
>
>
>
> Selected software are as followed :
> -----------------------------------
>
> - Postfix
> - Amavisd-new
> - SpamAssassin
> - Courier Imap
> - DCC-DCCD
> - Clamav
> - a web mail (not yet selected but probably horde)
>
>
> The idea is to offer a simple and very efficient solution in order for the
> server to have a 100% uptime under any circumstances.
>
> I would like (if possible) to stick to software available in the ports (for
> ease of maintenance).
>
>
> I was first thinking about using Linux-HA aka. "heartbeat" and syncing the
> two boxes using rsync ?
>
> What other solution would you think of ?

Can't really help with the HA aspect, but I'd take a look at:

http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/url.cgi?ports/mail/postfix-policyd-weight/pkg-descr

"Policyd-weight is (as the name says) a weighted policyd for Postfix.
It uses HELO, MAIL FROM and the MTA IP address for scoring their
correctness. It also uses definable DNSBLs and RHSBLs in a scored
fashion."

I've been using that instead of spamassassin (which can be a memory hog)
and very little spam makes it through.  It's nice in that it doesn't even
have to accept the message body to do it's thing.

Also, consider, clamsmtp

http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/url.cgi?ports/security/clamsmtp/pkg-descr

for tying clamav into postfix without having ot use amavisd...

And lastly, you might take a look at roundcube for webmail...

http://roundcube.net/

> > 1) What is the range of the running kernel stack
> > in main memory?
>
> Its 8k for each process.


i think it depends on architecture. It must fit into two pages of
memory.ifis or 32-bit x86 architecture and also 64-bit x86
architecture,linux
implements 4k page size.So it is 8kb.correct.
But ,linux implements multiple page size for some other architecture like
for arm(4kb,16kb,32kb), for sparc64(8kb) etc...in that case kernel stack
size would  be varry.....

for 32-bit x86
if i see the PAGE_SIZE macro in /include/asm/page.h, it is like
/*PAGE_SHIFT determines the page size */
#define PAGE_SHIFT      12
#define PAGE_SIZE       (1UL << PAGE_SHIFT).

for sparc64
  #define PAGE_SHIFT   13
 #define PAGE_SIZE    (_AC(1,UL) << PAGE_SHIFT)
 #define PAGE_MASK    (~(PAGE_SIZE-1))

http://lxr.linux.no/source/include/asm-sparc64/page.h?a=sparc64

But it could be configurable during the kernel compilation.

> > I am looking for the best possible solution in order to setup a High

> > Selected software are as followed :
> > -----------------------------------

> > - Postfix
> > - Amavisd-new
> > - SpamAssassin
> > - Courier Imap
> > - DCC-DCCD
> > - Clamav
> > - a web mail (not yet selected but probably horde)
> >
> >
> > The idea is to offer a simple and very efficient solution in order for the
> > server to have a 100% uptime under any circumstances.
> >
> > I would like (if possible) to stick to software available in the ports (for
> > ease of maintenance).
> >
> >
> > I was first thinking about using Linux-HA aka. "heartbeat" and syncing the
> > two boxes using rsync ?

> > What other solution would you think of ?
>
> Can't really help with the HA aspect, but I'd take a look at:
>
> http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/url.cgi?ports/mail/postfix-policyd-weight/pkg-descr
>
> "Policyd-weight is (as the name says) a weighted policyd for Postfix.
> It uses HELO, MAIL FROM and the MTA IP address for scoring their
> correctness. It also uses definable DNSBLs and RHSBLs in a scored
> fashion."
>
> I've been using that instead of spamassassin (which can be a memory hog)
> and very little spam makes it through.  It's nice in that it doesn't even
> have to accept the message body to do it's thing.
>
> Also, consider, clamsmtp
>
> http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/url.cgi?ports/security/clamsmtp/pkg-descr
>
> for tying clamav into postfix without having ot use amavisd...
>
> And lastly, you might take a look at roundcube for webmail...
>
> http://roundcube.net/
>

Hi Parthan and others,

--- Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
> myself have
> had asked some 
> questions related to support for nvidia video card
> some 1.5 yrs back and 
> got no reply :( )

You never ask support questions on a developers'
mailing list.

For any project, there are usually two mailing lists
(in general). 

A users' mailing list and a developers' mailing list.
All discussions on development, submission of patches
goes into the developers' mailing list.

You should use the users' mailing list for asking
questions how to use feature X or Y with the software
or for general use of the software.

Thanks to Suman, Shakthi and Parthan for the advice.

The way I plan to go about learning kernel programming is first take
up something that I want done, for instance, right now my TV
remote is not working. I have to get that working first. Since I
have a pressing need for that I will automatically learn whatever is
reqd to do the job. At the same time I take  care not to put any
deadline. It may take a month or two, so what?

Next, I would read the documentation and spend some time reading
websites like what you guys pointed me to.

After that I will use a cscope like tool to index the source and
generally go about getting my feet wet as to what is where and
gain familiarity with the code organization.

Then I would try to get into device driver development solving some
real life problem.

Mailing lists and books may somewhat help but largely I think they
don't fit into the scheme of things here.

Bcoz I have never relied on mailing lists for learning anything.

I will also keep an open ended time frame like six months or so.

I will never force myself.

Do you guys follow something similar or different?

regards,
Girish

Hi,

Linux has many different flavors  known as  distributions. Examples are
RedHat, Fedora, Ubuntu, Suse, Gentoo etc. First decide which
distribution you want to use. Each of the distributions have some
differences. Some are easy to use for a new user's point of view, some
are very stable to be run as servers, some need to be compiled from
source etc. (this is what I've learned in my 2 month stint with Linux.
The gurus (I see there a quite a few of them here) please correct me if
I'm wrong)

I'd suggest Ubuntu Linux (http://www.ubuntu.com/). It is easy to install
and use. You can download the CD image from any of the sites mentioned
here - http://www.ubuntu.com/download . The site also has torrent files,
if you want to use BitTorrent. You can also order free CDs from - 
https://shipit.ubuntu.com/. They usually take a month or two to reach you.

On 8/25/06, Girish Venkatachalam


Compiling the kernel in FreeBSD is dead simple. So if it is just
> the question of enabling an option in the kernel I could help
> you out.



'make  world'  builds  the  whole system  (userland,  libraries  etc.)
excluding the kernel.

'make kernel' builds and installs a new kernel.

'make release' will  build a release (bootable ISOs  etc.) given a CVS tag
and a CVS repository.

I would also add that freebsd documentation is fairly good and easy to
follow.  man intro, security, firewall, tuning etc are straightforward
guides.

> excluding the kernel.

One of the reasons this works is bcoz FreeBSD is a real operating
system with tightly integrated libc, shell, X window etc..

It is not some sphagetti like linux kernel + GNU tools as is the case
with linux distros

IOW, when I say FreeBSD 6.0, everybody understands what
I mean precisely. To a reasonable level of accuracy the versions
of software I run will be identical.

Whereas when I say I run linux, there are 100s or possibilities.

Even say , something like udev and hotplug which is kernel
related stuff, Debian does it differently from Ubuntu which does
it differently from Gentoo which again is different from RedHat
and so on.

I have run into situations when I compile a simple helloworld program
in C which does not run on a different RedHat release
on the same arch.

Whereas you compile a userland app in linux, copy it to a FreeBSD box
and just run it.

It runs. Why? Bcoz FreeBSD has a linux emulation layer that
dynamically detects the ELF header and invokes the appropriate
emulation subsystem...

It works so well that I can run the closed source  skype which
was built for linux perfectly under FreeBSD.

If you don't believe me, come home and you can talk to your
friend in the US.

And remember that my FreeBSD machine is a 233 MHz Pentium II machine
with broken hardware.

If these reasons don't convince u to try FreeBSD then I don't know
what will. :-)

regards,
Girish

> Linux has many different flavors  known as  distributions. Examples are
> RedHat, Fedora, Ubuntu, Suse, Gentoo etc. First decide which
> distribution you want to use. Each of the distributions have some
> differences. Some are easy to use for a new user's point of view, some
> are very stable to be run as servers, some need to be compiled from
> source etc. 
Try out more than one flavor of GNU/Linux distros. Start with Ubuntu, 
try Fedora, try Suse, try Knoppix, try Mandrake... after you have tried 
with a few (atleast a two) adopt one. Each one have their own features, 
it depends upon what suits you. We have our Ubuntu Dapper systems as our 
development boxes. So, as far as an average user is considered most 
distros will fit into your requirements.

(this is what I've learned in my 2 month stint with Linux.
> The gurus (I see there a quite a few of them here) please correct me if
> I'm wrong)

If you ask people out here, 99% of them don't themselves consider to be 
Linux-Gurus. We are User's with wide range of experience and we are here 
as a Community to share our experience for mutual benefit and for the 
spirit of community. Everyone can be a guru to you at some point of time ;)

> here - http://www.ubuntu.com/download . The site also has torrent files,

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Aug 26 03:30:36 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sat Aug 26 16:00:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] RFC: Grooming new speakers for FLOSS events
Message-ID: <20060826103036.59715.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

With the rising number of GNU/Linux User Groups in
colleges, there is a very high demand for
workshop/seminars. As much as I'd love to go to the
colleges where I have already been, there is still
more work to be done at colleges/universities where
students/faculty are still unaware of education and
FLOSS. This is the ultimate challenge.

With your help, we can groom more students/faculty
from various colleges who have already enjoyed the
FLOSS experience to speak/advocate FLOSS.

I request the NRC-FOSS members to have a new link in
their wiki, similar to the Mentors page:

http://nrcfosshelpline.in/code/wiki/FellowshipMentors

for new speakers interested in advocating FLOSS and
sharing FLOSS knowledge. The page can have four
columns: Name, topic(s) of interest, contact details,
availability. Availability is to check if you are
available on a particular day for a workshop or not.

As a speaker, it doesn't matter if you are a
student/faculty/industry person, or if you can speak
good English or not. As long as you know your FLOSS
stuff, you are passionate about it, and you can
express yourself, you should be fine. Grammar/accent
doesn't matter.

Appreciate any feedback on this,

Thanks,

SK

Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

As a first step I would suggest to give them the view of the vastness of
Opensource and how they can use it in their day-to-day life. I remember one
friend of mine who was doing a project in speech processing and analysis was
so excited to hear about Perl and its regular expressions. Until then he
used to do all stuff in C which was not much suited for that kind of
project. The point I am trying to make is before trying to teach them
perl/python we should educate them on various tools available and their
usefulness and create an interest in them. Then separated them in to groups
according to their taste and teach the right tool to the right person. How
many c programmers will not be interested to hear about the deadly
combination of "vi + ctags + cscope"?

On 26/08/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> One of the reasons this works is bcoz FreeBSD is a real operating
> system with tightly integrated libc, shell, X window etc..
>
> It is not some sphagetti like linux kernel + GNU tools as is the case
> with linux distros

I don't understand what you are trying to say. What is different in
FreeBSD's integration of libc, shell, X Windows etc. when compared to
say, Fedora Core's? As far as the sphagetti is concerned, do you know
that FreeBSD and Linux distros share quite a lot of code? GNU Bash,
X.Org etc. are all common to both FreeBSD and Fedora Core. Why does
one becomes sphagetti and the other, tightly integrated?

> IOW, when I say FreeBSD 6.0, everybody understands what
> I mean precisely. To a reasonable level of accuracy the versions
> of software I run will be identical.
>
> Whereas when I say I run linux, there are 100s or possibilities.

You are comparing apples and oranges. If you are talking of FreeBSD
6.0, then you should talk of Fedore Core 5 or RHEL 4 or Opensuse 10.
If on the other hand, you want to talk of Linux, then talk of the
BSD's in general - not just FreeBSD.

> Even say , something like udev and hotplug which is kernel
> related stuff, Debian does it differently from Ubuntu which does
> it differently from Gentoo which again is different from RedHat
> and so on.

And it happens identical in the BSD world - FreeBSD does it in one
way, OpenBSD in another, NetBSD in a third way and so on.

> I have run into situations when I compile a simple helloworld program
> in C which does not run on a different RedHat release
> on the same arch.

Anecdotal evidence notwithstanding, I'm curious to hear which two
releases of Redhat you are talking about here. There have been
situations when this might have happened (when they moved from libc to
glibc, or from a.out to ELF), I find it hard to believe that a "simple
helloworld program" could have caused such grief in any recent
Redhat/Fedora versions.

> It runs. Why? Bcoz FreeBSD has a linux emulation layer that
> dynamically detects the ELF header and invokes the appropriate
> emulation subsystem...
>
> It works so well that I can run the closed source  skype which
> was built for linux perfectly under FreeBSD.

So? Does this prove anything?

> If these reasons don't convince u to try FreeBSD then I don't know
> what will. :-)

On my desktop, I still prefer Windows XP Pro. On my servers, Redhat Linux.

Binand

*ABSTRACT*



*This is a career counseling software which will conduct an computer
adaptive psychometric test (computer adaptive test here means that the same
question will be asked after some time in different contest, if a person is
true to himself the answers will be same or otherwise the person writing the
test is simply manipulating the answers, in this case some more questions
will be asked and if the answers are manipulated the user will be told that
the test is being manipulated and it will ask the user to take the test with
sincerity) for analyzing a persons nature and attitude. Based on the result
this will suggest some careers, which will suit the person. The career
suggestions will contain the following:*

?         *Job profile*

?         *Career path (beginning from higher secondary in a flow chart
format)*

?         *Various institutes offering the course (including study abroad
options)*

?         *Details about the course*

?         *Pays and perks*

?         *Video or audio if necessary*

?         *Experts comments or video clippings pertaining to the career*

?         *Application format*

?         *Links in the world wide web (for reference)*

?         *And many more (open for ideas)*



*Buy using this software the user would get whatever details is required in
one place and the other option here will also be getting information even
without taking the test.*

On 8/26/06, Prashanth Mohan <prashmohan@gmail.com> wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
>
> Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> > You are comparing apples and oranges. If you are talking of FreeBSD
> > 6.0, then you should talk of Fedore Core 5 or RHEL 4 or Opensuse 10.
> > If on the other hand, you want to talk of Linux, then talk of the
> > BSD's in general - not just FreeBSD.
> >
>
> Forgive my Ignorance but aren't each of the BSDs considered a seperate
> OS? The kernel doesn't share any code base unlike different linux
> distros do they?

Bah! Don't be apologetic when you know what you are talking. :-)

You are right, though all BSDs share a common ancestry, the kernel
 code is completely different and so is the userland. You will
understand it well if you take a look at a couple of kernel files.

Though the same mbuf networking packet data structure is used by
all BSDs, and a few other common constructs, mainly scheduler algos
and data structures like queues and stacks, the rest is quite different.

I really don't know how much is the similarity and how much the difference
but I am sure of this. That OpenBSD kernel is roughly 1/10th the size
of FreeBSD kernel, both if you compare the source as well as the binary.


As I have mentioned before I have not played enough with NetBSD yet.

For instance, though all BSDs support cryptographic file systems,
NetBSD's cgd is different from GDBE of FreeBSD which is again quite
different from OpenBSD's svnd.

However the ALTQ networking subsystem for QoS and other things must
be somewhat similar. I am guessing this.

A lot of cross polination happens among the BSDs , but the difference
among them is certainly much more than the difference between linux
distros. It is a little subjective, so let me stop here.

Refer to my reply to Binand's mail for further details.

On 8/26/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> I don't understand what you are trying to say. What is different in
> FreeBSD's integration of libc, shell, X Windows etc. when compared to
> say, Fedora Core's? As far as the sphagetti is concerned, do you know
> that FreeBSD and Linux distros share quite a lot of code? GNU Bash,
> X.Org etc. are all common to both FreeBSD and Fedora Core. Why does
> one becomes sphagetti and the other, tightly integrated?

First of all I am very glad that there is a healthy difference of
opinion. Let me try to do my best to clear things up. But please
remember that neither Jordan K Hubbard nor Theo de Raadt is paying me
for this. :-)

And regrettably my knowledge of the kernels of these OSes is not as
good as I wished. If that were true then you could have given more
credence to what I am saying.  As such my replies are only based on
"impressions" and not real technical knowledge. That said, I will do
my best to give an unbiased view.

I probably used too strong a word "sphagetti" though I don't regret it
now since it is definitely close to reality. :-)

No, you are mistaken. *BSD OSes do not rely on GNU tools. They do use
GNU tools, yes; but they don't rely on them. BSD has its own libc(very
different from glic), its own make, its own compiler though these days
nobody uses anything other than gcc.

And BSD has true UNIX roots. Games like fortune and tetris existed on
BSD long ago. csh is the default shell on BSD systems. csh is a really
horrible shell, so it is nothing to be proud of.

And tools like tar,cp, ls etc.. all have a BSD version and a GNU
version. Since GNU version is recent, they are usually much better
than the rusty old UNIX versions. But  then it has also lead to a
certain feature bloat and code expansion.

BSD tar doesnt have a -j option, so it is irritating. But then BSD
also gives you GNU tools with a  g prefix. gtar is the GNU tar and so
on.


>
> > IOW, when I say FreeBSD 6.0, everybody understands what
> > I mean precisely. To a reasonable level of accuracy the versions
> > of software I run will be identical.
> >
> > Whereas when I say I run linux, there are 100s or possibilities.
>
> You are comparing apples and oranges. If you are talking of FreeBSD
> 6.0, then you should talk of Fedore Core 5 or RHEL 4 or Opensuse 10.
> If on the other hand, you want to talk of Linux, then talk of the
> BSD's in general - not just FreeBSD.

Ok. This is not my opinion. This was actually told by Jordan K Hubbard
in an interview. I think the biggest weakpoint of linux is its too
much hype and popularity and lack of focus. Different distros have
different things as focus and there is no common regulatory authority.
It has almost become like different OSes. This is not a good thing.

This is what has brought about interoperability problems and market
fragmentation.

Somewhat subjective why I say it is not a good thing since different
choices for the end user is good but then energy is scattered away in
multiple directions instead of collected in one and focused.

So the tendency of bugs and integration issues increase greatly since
developers don't know who to submit a patch to when they fix a bug.

>
> > Even say , something like udev and hotplug which is kernel
> > related stuff, Debian does it differently from Ubuntu which does
> > it differently from Gentoo which again is different from RedHat
> > and so on.
>
> And it happens identical in the BSD world - FreeBSD does it in one
> way, OpenBSD in another, NetBSD in a third way and so on.

Hmm, they are completely different OSes. Other than the common parts
in the kernel I spoke about above and some parts of userland, they are
all quite different.

Some of the shell commands and man pages are very similar though. I
find a lot of similarity bet NetBSD and OpenBSD.

>
> > I have run into situations when I compile a simple helloworld program
> > in C which does not run on a different RedHat release
> > on the same arch.
>
> Anecdotal evidence notwithstanding, I'm curious to hear which two
> releases of Redhat you are talking about here. There have been
> situations when this might have happened (when they moved from libc to
> glibc, or from a.out to ELF), I find it hard to believe that a "simple
> helloworld program" could have caused such grief in any recent
> Redhat/Fedora versions.

Well, ask this on a mailing list and they will tell you why this
happens. Though I am not technically competent to comment on this. All
I can say
is that lack of cleanliness in linux design hurts us sooner or later. This
is only one instance in which linux falls on the face. There are
numerous other but then FreeBSD also has several stupid bugs, so I
think we are not comparing apples and apples here.

In general FreeBSD has sufferred in recent times due to the pressure
to compete with linux and hence, it has lost some of its old charm
,but then
I hope things get better. One of the reasons I have decided to dump
FreeBSD and go in for Net or Open for my products...

Btw, one of the main advantages BSDs have is in their performance and
compatibility on any old hardware. You will be quite surprised to know
that the machine from which I am typing this mail is only 350 MHz and
I can do whatever I want with it. Even watch full screen video with
mplayer.

Redhat cannot install , but Debian certainly would.:-)

>
> > It runs. Why? Bcoz FreeBSD has a linux emulation layer that
> > dynamically detects the ELF header and invokes the appropriate
> > emulation subsystem...
> >
> > It works so well that I can run the closed source  skype which
> > was built for linux perfectly under FreeBSD.
>
> So? Does this prove anything?

Yes, it does of course. I wonder why you don't see that cleanliness
and simplicity of design has achieved something seemingly impossible.

I think this is fantastic; I feel it instinctively though I am not
able to substantiate it with reason. I think if you think for a while
you will get what I mean...
>
> > If these reasons don't convince u to try FreeBSD then I don't know
> > what will. :-)
>
> On my desktop, I still prefer Windows XP Pro. On my servers, Redhat Linux.

Well, Binand, normally ppl prefer to run *BSD on mail servers,
routers, firewalls etc. and run linux or Windoze on their desktops.

But I use OpenBSD on my desktop and I find it eminently usable and
blazingly fast.

It is purely personal choice buddy. Nobody on earth dare comment on
what any of us choose.:-)

Anyway I am not too happy with this treatment and I do certainly
regret the fact that I don't have inside information; I mean kernel
hacking experience and general anecdotal evidence to support my
claims.

I think it is pertinent to mention that ssh came from OpenBSD, that tc
QoS came from AltQ, that devfs was adapted from BSD, that epoll was
adapted from kqueue and so on.

Even when linux copies from the BSD pioneers, linux often gets it
somewhat inelegant and counterintuitive.

Having said all this, nobody can gainsay the fact that linux enjoys
the sort of popularity, mindshare and focus like no other OS. And it
has several cutting edge features and drivers for nearly every single
hardware on earth.

Let me stop here. :-)

regards,
Girish

Cool idea man! :-)

I am sure there are some Ajax studs over here who will willingly lend you
a helping hand.

How to make the static map first? I don't know. Maybe inkscape, gimp or
blender or xfig? or Openoffice?

I may be offtrack but not orthogonal to what you want.

I would not use a database bcoz the datasize is too small. You are not
changing anything, so you don't need transactions.

KISS. Keep things simple and stupid.

If I were you I would just use a hashtable in C or a file or some such
thing.

For zooming you got to use some cool truetype fonts or something.

Something that doesn't break under the weight of heavy zooming in.

Ok, I have run dry. Someone else should jump in now.

hosting Usenet discussions from 1981 and their Google Groups is a web
front end for that

archive here -

Hi Kumar,

On 8/27/06, Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:

> Kumar Appaiah wrote:
> I have a few ISO images of various GNU/Linux and BSD installer CDs
> (minimal). I was wondering whether I could use GRUB to boot them from
> my existing GNU/Linux system, avoiding the need to burn them onto a CD
> to start the installation procedure. Is there a way to do this?

How about using Qemu?
http://fabrice.bellard.free.fr/qemu/

Its as simple as this. If you have a iso image say GnoWare.iso
$ qemu -cdrom /media/hda8/GnoWare.iso -boot d

From vijairaj.r at gmail.com  Sun Aug 27 21:27:02 2006
From: vijairaj.r at gmail.com (Vijairaj)
Date: Sun Aug 27 21:27:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Boot ISOs wthout buring them
In-Reply-To: <20060827120638.GA5026@localhost>
References: <20060827120638.GA5026@localhost>
Message-ID: <5d0d0e310608270857v367a2438xb370f77c35250675@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/27/06, Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
>
> Dear ILUGC,
>
> I have a few ISO images of various GNU/Linux and BSD installer CDs
> (minimal). I was wondering whether I could use GRUB to boot them from
> my existing GNU/Linux system, avoiding the need to burn them onto a CD
> to start the installation procedure. Is there a way to do this?


Definitely possible, I have installed that way many times.
The procedure is like this:
1. loop mount the iso image and copy the kernel, ramdisk image, and the
modules to some partition accessible from grub.
2. Find out the options to be passed to the kernel. Its listed in
isolinux/isolinux.cfg in the dapper iso image, it might be differet for
others.
3. Reboot the system and enter the grub command prompt.
4. Boot the kernel with the options noted down in step 2.
eg:
root (hd0, 6)
kernel /iso/vmlinuz boot=casper ramdisk_size=1048576 root=/dev/ram rw quiet
splash --
initrd /iso/initrd.gz
boot
5. After booting, the kernel will probe for cdrom devices and will fail and
will probably drop you in a rescue shell.
6. From the rescue shell, you can use losetup to link the loop device to the
iso image and then create a link /dev/cdrom pointing to the loop device. You
might require to insmod the 'loop' module if its not already present.
7. Continue with the installation.

This procedure worked for Debian & Ubuntu atleast but it should be possible
with others as well. You can always customize the ramdisk if needed.
--
Warm Regards,
Vijairaj

On 8/27/06, Krishna P <mail2krish@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 8/27/06, Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> >
> But this will be applicable to Linux I am not aware of  *BSD.
>
BSD world doesnt use grub, you can use but ppl normally avoid and
moreover only FreeBSD understands grub's command line passing to the
kernel. Since each BSD has its own boot loader, grub is not normally
used.


I use the command,

qemu -m 256 -cdrom freebsd.iso

But bear in mind that qemu is only an emulator and it only shows you
how things look and work. There is no way you are going to know if
things really work on the hardware you plan to install.

Someone gave a lengthy procedure of loop mounting, copying to hard
disk etc. It will be great if the reboot cycle could be avoided.
Otherwise the approach seems to be somewhat fine.

Can u use user mode linux or chroot for it? I wonder.

But qemu seems to be the best way.

Or u can boot it from a USB key. But the iso can't be copied. USB key
boot code is similar to floppy's though I wonder if it is the same. It
might be.

With some minimal change, you can loop mount the iso and run syslinux
to change El Torito (for CDROM) to floppy format and boot from USB.

For BSDs, not much info is there on the web on how to do the USB
thing. I am sure I will figure it out soon...

regards,
Girish

Hi,

Joomla day is a day to show case "Joomla" one of the most  comprehensive
easy to build website through cms. It has many relevance to software freedom
day. Generally we say "Linux Demo day" as a premier model of any open source
event. Like the LDD , Joomla day is a day where events are organised to
popularise the use of Joomla CMS.

Joomla Day will have lot  of importance for audience for reasons Joomla is a
tool for Non Tech guy to publish maintain his content and  happily run
his/her show , for Tech guys joomla  has many facets one of which is
breading ground for learning MVC style code which may be helpful in learning
the other MVC like phpcake, phpsymfony, rails.. etc.

More info at
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joomla


I rest for now

Cheers

Thyagarajan Shanmugham

Q1> what importance does joomla has with SFD
ANS) Open source matters

From: sripriyanc at amiindia.co.in (Sripriyan C)
Date: Mon Aug 28 15:18:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Enabling Framebuffer
References: <20060828044925.28BC21DB26D@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <00ad01c6ca86$bbd49f20$5c00000a@sripriyan>

Hi all

I am using RH linux 7.1(kernel 2.4.2-2). And i want to enable
Framebuffer(FB) in my kernel. I enabled FB in the kernel as mentioned below,
  a.. Code maturity level options --->
    a.. Prompt for development and/or incomplete code/drivers
(CONFIG_EXPERIMENTAL=Y)
  b.. Console drivers --->
    a.. VGA text console (CONFIG_VGA_CONSOLE=Y)
    b.. Video mode selection support (CONFIG_VIDEO_SELECT=Y)
      a.. Frame-buffer support --->
        a.. Support for frame buffer devices (EXPERIMENTAL) (CONFIG_FB=Y)
        b.. VESA VGA graphics console (CONFIG_FB_VESA)
        c.. Advanced low level driver options (CONFIG_FBCON_ADVANCED=Y)
        d.. Monochrome support (CONFIG_FBCON_MFB=Y)
        e.. 2 bpp packed pixels support (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB2=Y)
        f.. 4 bpp packed pixels support (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB4=Y)
        g.. 8 bpp packed pixels support (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB8=Y)
        h.. 16 bpp packed pixels support (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB16=Y)
        i.. 24 bpp packed pixels support (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB24=Y)
        j.. 32 bpp packed pixels support (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB32=Y)
      With the above .config file i ran,
      b.. make dep
      c.. make bzImage
      d.. copied the bzImage into /boot dir
Then i included the line ` append="vga=791" ` in my lilo.conf.

After rebooting i found that frame buffer is not enabled.

this additional info could help,

# fbset
open /dev/fb0: No such device
# ls -l /dev/fb0
crw--------    1    root    root    29,    0    Mar    24    2001
/dev/fb0
# cat /proc/fb
#

I understood that the above fbset and cat /proc/fb commands din't respond as
expected. Could it be because of my PC configuration(intel845, samsung
samtron 45Bn)? Can anyone throw some light on it ?
Thanks and Regards

Sripriyan C

installed boot loader, kernel support for your hardware,

description, etc.) nobody will be able to help you.

On 8/28/06, Sripriyan C <sripriyanc@amiindia.co.in> wrote:
> Hi all
>
> I am using RH linux 7.1(kernel 2.4.2-2). And i want to enable
> Framebuffer(FB) in my kernel. I enabled FB in the kernel as mentioned below,
>   a.. Code maturity level options --->
>     a.. Prompt for development and/or incomplete code/drivers
> (CONFIG_EXPERIMENTAL=Y)
>   b.. Console drivers --->
>     a.. VGA text console (CONFIG_VGA_CONSOLE=Y)
>     b.. Video mode selection support (CONFIG_VIDEO_SELECT=Y)
>       a.. Frame-buffer support --->
>         a.. Support for frame buffer devices (EXPERIMENTAL) (CONFIG_FB=Y)
>         b.. VESA VGA graphics console (CONFIG_FB_VESA)
>         c.. Advanced low level driver options (CONFIG_FBCON_CFB32=Y)
> Then i included the line ` append="vga=791" ` in my
lilo.conf.
>
I am not sure if this is necessary since I have never passed a single
option to the kernel so far and I have got my framebuffer working.

> After rebooting i found that frame buffer is not enabled.
>
> this additional info could help,
>
> # fbset
> open /dev/fb0: No such device
> # ls -l /dev/fb0
> crw--------    1    root    root    29,    0    Mar    24    2001
> /dev/fb0
> # cat /proc/fb
> #
Well, what you have enabled are the software abstractions for the
framebuffer interface and fonts. There is no need to choose so many of
them. Just one would be sufficient.

But the main thing is the framebuffer driver that drives the hardware.
That is the tricky part. I don't know if Intel845 is supported by the
kernel you are using. Just google for it.

If that doesn't work then you might be lucky and vesafb might do the
trick. Enable that also.

Also it might be better to run 2.6.x kernel...

Best,
Girish

On 8/28/06, Sai Kiran <saikiranrgda@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 8/27/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> > On 8/27/06, Krishna P <mail2krish@gmail.com> wrote:
> > > On 8/27/06, Kumar Appaiah <akumar@ee.iitm.ac.in> wrote:
> > > >
> > Can u use user mode linux or chroot for it? I wonder.
>
> May be UML might be made to run from it. but not chroot.

Well, this page says otherwise.
http://wiki.lunar-linux.org/index.php/Installation:No_CD

With just three commands, you can do wonders.

losetup /dev/loop0 lunar-1.5.1-i686.iso
mount /dev/loop0 /mnt -o ro
chroot /mnt /sbin/lunar-install

Just replace the /sbin/lunar-install command with an appropriate one,
that is all.

chroot is very powerful! In fact you can run linux  inside linux very
easily using chroot
whereas uml is somewhat painful.
> This is possible in distros like fedora, where u can use the usb to
> boot from a USB. Fedora comes with a USB boot image. if such a image
> exists just dd the image into a USB and lo u have a bootable USB, by
> passing certain arguments to the kernel u can install of the ISO
> images on the HDD.

Debian also gives a very easy procedure for USB keyflash boot. It is
really very straightforward.

I am looking out how to do it for *BSD.

regards,
Girish

On 8/28/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On 8/28/06, Sripriyan C <sripriyanc@amiindia.co.in> wrote:
> > Then i included the line ` append="vga=791" ` in my
> lilo.conf.
> >
> I am not sure if this is necessary since I have never passed a single
> option to the kernel so far and I have got my framebuffer working.


AFAIK this option is necessary, because the video mode has to be selected
using the BIOS calls and this can only be done before the kernel enters into
the real mode. So the kernel should decide in a very early stage if it
should enter text mode/graphics mode - This decision is made based on the
boot parameter.

--
Warm Regards,
Vijairaj

May I politely interject here? Thanks.

I know that you are only quoting from an ancient thread but we should
stop talking about or even thinking about Minix.

It is an academic project by Tananbaum. He may be a great teacher and
an academician but one should remember that he is not an engineer.

We are engineers and hackers and we want things that work and work
well in the real world.

So let us safely lock Minix in the old rusty trunk box in your bedroom
and go try, the BSDs and breathe some fresh air.

Nobody is stopping you from writing your own device drivers for these
successful open source operating systems used by large corporations
with millions of dollars.

Don't waste your time doing projects of academic interest.

My two cents.

regards,
Girish

U shud remember the ugly row bet Linus and Tanenbaum.

Tanenbaum was suggesting a modular kernel. Linus is not a guy
who minces his words.

He clearly told him to keep quiet. He is a professor and let him
attend to teaching.

And who won the game? Linus or Tananbaum?

One can sit and talk theory and write books. But to make
a product succeed in the real world is an altogether ballgame.

That is what we should be interested in.

Anyway forget Tananbaum.

Understand my idea clearly. I want everyone to get practical.

Close your textbooks, unlearn some of what your professors
taught you, forget stuff like multithreading is the way to go and
that databases should be used for storing records and all that.

Go, look at the source code of well written programs that work
well in the real world. Understand the design. Try to fix bugs,
improve things and experience it.

Experience is the only way to learn.

Subject: [Ilugc] Enabling Framebuffer
In-Reply-To: <00a301c6cb38$8198f510$5c00000a@sripriyan>
Message-ID: <20060829074910.31712.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Sripriyan,

--- Sripriyan C <sripriyanc@amiindia.co.in> wrote:
> 1. Output of  fbset -fb /dev/fb0
>     open /dev/fb0: No such device

Because you don't have the driver?
 
My test machine has Intel Corporation 82865G
Integrated Graphics Device (Rev 02).

cat /path/to/kernel/source/.config | grep FB:

# CONFIG_BLK_DEV_OFFBOARD is not set
CONFIG_FB=y
# CONFIG_FB_RIVA is not set
CONFIG_FB_CLGEN=m
CONFIG_FB_PM2=m
# CONFIG_FB_PM2_FIFO_DISCONNECT is not set
CONFIG_FB_PM2_PCI=y
CONFIG_FB_PM3=m
# CONFIG_FB_CYBER2000 is not set
CONFIG_FB_VESA=y
CONFIG_FB_VGA16=m
CONFIG_FB_HGA=m
CONFIG_FB_MATROX=m
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_MILLENIUM=y
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_MYSTIQUE=y
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_G450=y
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_G100=y
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_I2C=m
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_MAVEN=m
# CONFIG_FB_MATROX_PROC is not set
CONFIG_FB_MATROX_MULTIHEAD=y
CONFIG_FB_ATY=m
CONFIG_FB_ATY_GX=y
CONFIG_FB_ATY_CT=y
CONFIG_FB_ATY_CT_VAIO_LCD=y
CONFIG_FB_RADEON=m
CONFIG_FB_ATY128=m
CONFIG_FB_INTEL=m
CONFIG_FB_SIS=m
CONFIG_FB_SIS_300=y
CONFIG_FB_SIS_315=y
CONFIG_FB_NEOMAGIC=m
CONFIG_FB_3DFX=m
CONFIG_FB_VOODOO1=m
# CONFIG_FB_TRIDENT is not set
# CONFIG_FB_VIRTUAL is not set
# CONFIG_FBCON_ADVANCED is not set
CONFIG_FBCON_MFB=m
CONFIG_FBCON_CFB8=y
CONFIG_FBCON_CFB16=y
CONFIG_FBCON_CFB24=y
CONFIG_FBCON_CFB32=y
CONFIG_FBCON_VGA_PLANES=m
CONFIG_FBCON_HGA=m
# CONFIG_FBCON_FONTWIDTH8_ONLY is not set
# CONFIG_FBCON_FONTS is not set

for 2.4.21-4 on x86. You need to enable a VGA driver
for your kernel (modular or built-in).

hi Girish,

On 8/28/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:

> Well, this page says otherwise.
> http://wiki.lunar-linux.org/index.php/Installation:No_CD
>
> With just three commands, you can do wonders.
>
> losetup /dev/loop0 lunar-1.5.1-i686.iso
> mount /dev/loop0 /mnt -o ro
> chroot /mnt /sbin/lunar-install

if i am not wrong, he is copying the iso on a partition and and using
a boot loader to boot it.  The chroot part is done by the kernel right
after kernel initialization.

Infact this step is done by all the distros that i have come across.
this script is generally placed in the initrd img file that we
genrally pass to the kernel.

remember if u want to do the above, u shouldn't have any other kernel
running. two kernel cannot run at the same time unless u go for  XEN
or UML( both of which requires kernel recompilation.)




my two cents.
kiran

Oh my God! I never intended to hurt anyone!

If it happened inadvertently just pardon me and move on.

My apologies to one and all. I think there are too many of
them, so I am not able to enumerate here.

What I am aiming for is a healthy marriage of academia
and industry. The two have differring goals and have to
work with each other instead of one without the other.

Both are required. Without teachers and professors teaching
us stuff, we can never become engineers.

And without engineers doing real world work teachers cannot
test their hypotheses.

And I find too much academic discussions on this list. I
read this here, that there. Few ppl actually talk from
their experience. My humble intention was only that
and nothing else.

I apologize for all the hard feelings. I know I cannot
make up for it, but at least I can try.

And the reason I asked ppl not to waste time on academic
projects is not asking ppl not to do academic projects.

OTOH, take up a real life problem, solve it. Make it an
academic project. Who is stopping you from that?

I never meant to break or hurt anything. I don't believe
in revolutionary approach. Things have to happen slowly
by way of evolution.

Sorry again. I never meant to break anyone's heart!

regards,
Girish

On 8/29/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On 8/28/06, Vijairaj <vijairaj.r@gmail.com> wrote:
> > On 8/28/06, Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > > chroot is very powerful! In fact you can run linux  inside linux very
> > > easily using chroot
> >
> > True. In case of some 64bit distros chroot is the only option to run
> > java/flash/openoffice.
>
> Please pardon my ignorance. I cannot afford 64 bit machines.
>
> Please pray tell me how and why this is needed. Won't they
> work under 32 bit emulation? Is it a shared lib problem?


64 bit versions of  java/flash/openoffice were not available when I last
tried a 64 bit distro, so I had to install 32 bit versions of these
applications. 32 bit applications needs 32 bit versions of the libraries
(libc, pthread, gtk, ...) and multi lib support was not availabe (i.e, 32
bit and 64 bit libraries cannot co-exist) so these applications were
installed on a separate partition along with the dependent 32 bit libraries.
32 bit applications can now be executed after chrooting to the new
partition. All the mess can be avoided when multilib will finally be in Edgy
eft. I guess Gentoo already supports mixed libraries.

strangely enough, although philosophicaly i dont agree with Girish,  
in practice, in the Indian context I do. The problem here is the  
'scratch my itch' philosophy, which implies two things. One is that  
we prefer to start our own project rather than contribute to existing  
projects. And, secondly, we do not look to see if the project is  
useful before starting. Why does government implement so little FOSS?  
One reason is that there is no one available to write FOSS code. We  
have got a govt project to implement completely in FOSS (maybe first  
time in India), but can we get people to code for it? At govt  
salaries it is impossible to get good inhouse coders - and  
unfortunately, those who can do it are too busy scratching their itches.

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Aug 30 11:27:15 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Aug 30 11:27:26 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Take on Minix & Linux by Giris
In-Reply-To: <20060829143201.30732.qmail@web7611.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <20060829143201.30732.qmail@web7611.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <7938ae610608292257r4c5d1653qb028a8a40f694c23@mail.gmail.com>

On 8/29/06, amit saha <dandolls@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> For Girish
>
> With all due respects , girish I ask you one simple q what do u mean when u say " dont do projects of academic interest " ? cud u plz enlighten me  who ur intended audience is wen u say somthn so "irresponsible" like that ? What kind of projects should a student do ? What should be his goal? Money,fame or to learn something new. To learn something which his text books didnt teach. I dnt know abt u ,whether a stud or a prof...wat ever ! but at som point of time u must hav been a student (i hope i am not making assumptions)...n then what did u do projects for ? to learn....or for som thn else...neways..if u thnk otherwise( wich i presume u do)..do let me know abt projects u did wen u wer a student... I wud like to learn a few thns frm u then !

Amit,

You have asked too many questions here.

Pls understand that my words were interpreted out of context and
sentimentally analyzed. Nobody took the time to understand what I am
feeling deep inside when I spoke those words.

Of course my words were incendiary in nature and I had taken an
extremist stance which I now regret. Extremism does do good but it
leads to lot of bloodshed in the short term.

I personally have no anathema againt anything or anybody. In fact I
love Win XP for its stability , the applications supported by it and
ease of use. There was a time when I used to hate Microsoft and used
to love UNIX. But after several years I realized that any religious
allegiance or hatred only does harm and no good.

At the same time when MBA folks tell me that technology doesn't
matter, only result matters; I disagree with them vehemently bcoz
unless you use the right technology and the right tools you cannot
achieve your end.

And you cannot become good at something by being technology agnostic.

For now, to answer the most important question as I understand at the
top of your mind, here goes.

By "projects of academic interest" , I dont mean academia or industry.
There are several real life projects developed in universities. google
is an academic project, TCP/IP was developed in UCB and SUN is
Stanford University Network.

So ppl will laugh at me if I say that academia should only teach and
engineers should only do real life projects.

What I mean by "academic interest" are the sort of futuristic research
done by IBM T J Watson research center, AT & T Bell Labs and MIT media
lab projects. No, I dont mean to make a blanket statement here.

What I mean is many of these things dont matter at all to the common
man. They are done for pure research purposes.

This is what I don't like. No, I have nothing against research. But
from whatever I have observed about India and the Indian mind all
these years I feel that everyone goes into R & D mode at the drop of a
pin taking shelter in theory alone.

At the same time I have also met a lot of very good coders who start
coding at the drop of a pin.

What I think works is a proper balance of the two.

You need a solid conceptual and theoretical grounding first. On top of
that you build a product and then, once people start using it, you
will understand that what people want is really very different from
what you started with.

And you will have to make lot of changes for portability, for bug
compatibility, do ugly things like use the sleep statement for getting
it to work or put in hacks to make it not fail under certain
circumstances.

IOW, I mean to say that even if you have the brain of Albert Einstein,
unless your product is proven in the crucible of the real world, when
thousands of people use it in situations that Einstein himself couldnt
imagine(largely bcoz Einstien is not as stupid as an average Joe user
:-), until then, the product cannot be trusted.

i.e, I mean to say that a product should become truly idiot proof and
you should fix corner cases and other bugs that crept in due to your
assumptions which no longer hold good in the real world.

Now, coming to Minix, the statement sent by Roshan that Minix really
gave folks a chance to write device drivers... This might have been
true in the early 90s, when nobody knew about the open source
phenomemon. At that time, nobody had access to any kernel code. Only
employees of Sun , Novell , IBM, DEC etc...

But now, a lot of water has flown under the bridge. Today open source
has moved out of academia and hacker's hobbies and become more
mainstream than any other thing.

It came as a deluge and every single company in the world today should
owe a certain gratitude towards the great people who wrote open source
programs.

Believe me, I have seen some of the best companies in the world taking
open source code, only slightly modifying it, throwing in some masala
and then making products out of it. Very few of them actually follow
GPL laws. In fact many companies don't even acknowledge that they use
open source.

Whereas BSD licensing is very very business friendly. You can use the
code and do whatever you want with it. Moreover BSD code is also rock
solid unlike linux. Linux may have 1000s of features but when it comes
to doing something and doing well , nobody can beat BSD.

So it is only in this sense that I said that talking about Minix two
decades after it was born , especially when Minix has transmogrified
into linux and since Minix is hardly used is braindead to put it
euphemistically.

At the same time if you have nostalgia about something like the TCP/IP
stack or C or basic UNIX shell commands like  cat or vi, then that
makes sense.

Bcoz though equally old, these programs have weathered real life use
and proven themselves. The fact that TCP/IP or cat has hardly changed
speaks very highly of the foresight and the brilliance of the
designer.

Hope I make myself clear now.

regards,
Girish

PS:- Very sorry for writing such a long mail and wasting your time!
From srini.it at gmail.com  Wed Aug 30 11:28:45 2006
From: srini.it at gmail.com (Srinivasan Sundararajan)
Date: Wed Aug 30 11:28:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Take on Minix & Linux by Giris
In-Reply-To: <20060830040549.40878.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <e0900f3e0608292020q7bf7476aq6deebf7c7d47f682@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060830040549.40878.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <328077850608292258w646489b3j63eb90d8a6fe1211@mail.gmail.com>

> --- Rajagopal Natarajan <rajagopal.n@gmail.com> wrote:
> > But if students
> > do implementation
> > projects as their final year projects, it wont be
> > respected when it comes to
> > either academia or any *non-service based*
> > companies.
>
This is a self-imposed myth which has been made into reality. Students
doing implementation have been accepted by some of the examiners
provided the output is something worthwhile. Most of the time, some
screenshots and simulations are shown which naturally gives further
boost to the notion of "ban on implementation projects".
>
> > Students may do FOSS
> > projects for their own interest but not for their
> > final year project,
>
One major reason is the time factor. In my discussions with variuos
LUG members and academia, we have been trying to work out a via media
: divide the project into two parts -- one part for submission to the
univ and then proceed to comeplete the rest. Of course, the notion is
just a year or two old. Students (and univesity) need time to
understand and nurture this.

However, if we liberalise the definition to " using open source tools"
which could be put in FOSS, the number has been increasing
significantly. Before I joined NRCFOSS, I had 3 groups of students
working in what I could call the FOSS arena. There are a number of
colleges -- TEC, Sona, Kongu, Jaya, Muthayammal, Jerusalem .. under
Anna Univ (and I am sure some more in other univesities) -- who have
already made a beginning.
>
> > which
> > should be a project of academic interest for the
> > wellbeing of the student.
Should I make a protest of "child labor"? In the college we should
train the student to get used to examples, guided development which
enables him or her to contribute later. The tone of our interactions
here seem to seek only the "Prashant Mohans". While I welcome them I
would also like to seek 20-30 average but enthusiastic & committed
students for each Prashant Mohan.

> Because most academic institutions in India don't
> collaborate with the industry, the so-called
> "engineering student" doesn't know what is happening
> in the industry. So, your intention is primarily to do
> what your seniors did.
>
If the "seniors" who are now out in the industry guide their juniors
with worthwhile ideas, this can change -- and is changing, let me say,
5 to 10 % every year. The students need lot of handholding, but I am
not sure how many mentors have that much time or patience. From my own
experience at Arunai,  guys like Sudarsun (Checkatronix), Nagappan /
Varadhan (Novell) -- I know a few more in the industry but not in FOSS
-- have done this and are doing it.

Srinivasan, NRCFOSS.
