On 8/30/06, Rajagopal Natarajan
> > strangely enough, although philosophicaly i dont agree with Girish,
> > in practice, in the Indian context I do.

I  am only bothered about India right now. There is really nothing
else working in my brain.

How to make India stand shoulder to shoulder with the West is my only
problem today. When countries like Israel and Ireland can do it , then
why not India?

Though we have technical superstarts of International calibre, we are
not able to make a single commercial product or an open source
project.

Why? It is bcoz of several reasons. It is really not possible to
enumerate my thought process in a single email bcoz the problem is a
deep one and I have only begun to find the solution. Most importantly
I really have no practical experience in solving the problem.

And also I have not succeeded in my endeavor. My success lies in your hands. :-)

I will be brutally frank bcoz we are a mature race and we can take any
amount of criticism. I am willing to take any amount of brickbats from
you also. I really don't care as I have no vested interest here, only
love for India...

1) Companies like Infosys, Wipro, TCS and the media attention recd by
folks like Narayana Murthy have done 100 times more harm than good.
Why?

How do you think these companies make money? Is it by intellectual
efforts trying to prove that they have the best ppl or the best
product?

No, no and no.

They go and say, " Dear America, don't worry. We Indians are here to
wash your floor, to wipe your car clean and make you happy. We are not
fair skinned like you, so we cannot create products. We can only obey
you. "

Then HCL goes and says, " Hey , Infosys quoted 100 $ per hour. We in
Chennai get much better ppl than Blore at the fraction of the cost. So
give the project to me"

And so on and so forth and the problem continues.

What happens to you and me? Nobody gets time to build domain expertise
or self confidence. Already we are very low on self esteem. On top of
that you are switched from project to project depending on the needs
of the client. And you are made to work for long hours bcoz the client
puts pressure on you.

Tell me something. How will your brain be creative if you work for 18
hours a day that too doing junk work?

It kills your individuality and you become a vegetable.

What is the way out? You take a H1B visa and go to US or Europe or go
for higher studies? Is that picture rosy?

No. In fact one of the most successful guys is Vipul Ved Prakash,
famous for the anti spam software Vipul's razor.

And is he an IITian? Is he an engineer even? No,he is a dropout from
college. What does this prove?

The best place to do worldclass technical work is India. Today nobody
can say, "Oh India is a poor third world country, we don't have good
infrastructure and access to technology. We have brains and we put in
hard work but then we are at a disadvantage."

Wrong. It is just a lame excuse. The sort of thing that your grandpa
can say. Not you, with the freshness of youth about you.

You , my dear students are the future of our country. Today in what
way are you disadvantaged ? Don't you have access to a computer? Or
Internet? In fact broadband is cheaper than electricity in Chennai.

My dearest students, my appeal to you is very simple. Be bold, have
faith in yourselves. That you have all it takes to brave the world.
Whoever told you that you are second to someone? You are second to
none.

Stand up and work with all your energies and have fun. The amount of
fun you can have solving real life problems that you and I face are a
1000 times more than the fun you have in talking and learning abstract
theory.

Nobody can talk about this but me since I used to be a very very
theoretical person myself. I used to revel in designing, concepts and
flying above 30,000 feet. In fact I used to touch base with reality
only on an as needed basis. :-)

I distinctly remember how I used to feel those days. I always longed
for support. I always wanted someone else to support me. I couldn't
code myself, so my ego grew saying that coders are doing junk work.

And it is after a long protracted battle of around a year and after
facing failure in my career that I really got down to trying small C
programs, exercising the brain to solve technical problems instead of
just read and think.

And slowly as time passed by, month after month, my confidence started
increasing. Without my own knowledge.

Today after five years I feel that I am really second to none. Bcoz I
can very easily verify where I stand. All I have to do is send a patch
to an open source project or develop an open source program myself.

Anyway I have rattled on. I have work to do.

regards,
Girish

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Aug 30 13:47:34 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Aug 30 13:49:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Projects for students
Message-ID: <7938ae610608300117x3d40eb0byd9eeae5c2030cea6@mail.gmail.com>

My dear students,

   Here are the list of practically relevant solutions for issues
   that people are facing. If you come up with good implementations I think
   some LUG members with the right contacts could even put you on to
investors who can turn your prototypes into products for the Indian
and International market. No, I am not an investor. :-)


   First the computer science problems.

   1) Develop a simple, easy to use command line RSS reader for UNIX
systems. By RSS I mean RSS feeds. Don't do it in Java. I want C. Or
perl,python or ruby.

   2) Noorul Islam (noorul.islam@gmail.com also on LUG) is currently
working on developing a new generation split program. Read the man
page of split. It has several deficiencies. If you come up with a good
implementation, I suggest improve upon the existing code if reqd, then
it can have lot of value. Even simple things like splitting at a
particular offset, or at a particular %, or splitting into n parts are
not supported. I have looked for alternatives,  I found none.

  This has lot of application in audio, video processing.

 3) Develop a simple VoIP application that can work across NAT and
firewalls. This is not difficult. Refer to my article in linuxjournal
or LinuxForYou of  Aug month for details. Don't get scared reading my
article, it is not difficult to code it. I have already given the
design and code in the article.

 4) Develop a command line e-mail client that talks IMAP, SMTP and
POP. Remember , there is competition here. If you support SSL also,
this has lot of potential.

 5) Develop a liveCD or liveDVD or liveUSB that is customized with
bare minimum functionality. It will be good if you use a lightweight
window manager like Windowmaker or XFCE. It will be great if it comes
customized with local language support.

 6) Develop a simple instant messaging and presence protocol , not as
complicated as XMPP.  This is cliche and a favourite acad project. If
you do it different, you win.

 7) A simple application to encrypt and decrypt files on disk. User
should be able to select the encryption algo. If you can also lock it
down to USB keys, it will be great. User has a secure date store that
he can plug in to computers. You should also copy protect and make
sure it doesnt leave the keydrive.

8) Develop a stripped down version of mplayer for playing videos and songs.

9) Develop a music jukebox software that plays sounds on different
networked computers with a single mediation server that talks to all
machines thro' TCP/IP. If done well this has great entertainment
potential.

10) Develop a simple download accelerator that opens multiple TCP
connections and downloads a single file in parts and reassembles it.

The above projects take anywhere between 1 to 10 months to do. It
doesn't need more than three or four ppl. In fact all my projects I
have done alone. So if you so prefer you can also do it individually.

Here are the list of electronics projects. I am not quite clued in ,
but some of them may be interesting.

1) Develop a simple PLL based FM radio

2) Use LDR(Light Dependent Resistors) to do something creative. Don't
do what is cliche like counting the number of ppl entering a room or
something. You have to combine sophisticated software proceesing to do
something useful with it. For instance, you could measure the voltage
output to figure out the luminosity of a place or something. Or you
could combine this with temperature sensor and do something. I don't
know. You find out.

3) Develop a simple remote control using lirc and linux. You can
interface with the serial port, use a simple IR diode and learn the
serial interface protocol. It is really simple.

4) Build a simple digital clock that plays polyphonic tones for each
hour. I should randomly play a tune; it will be interesting. You can
seed the PRNG from an array. You don't need much entropy for this to
be interesting.

5) There are several projects you could do with cheap microcontrollers
these days. Need not just be 8051. You could develop a simple sensor
that weighs, one rupee, two rupee and five rupee coins and dispenses a
ticket or something.

6) You can develop a burglar alarm that detects tampering. Once you do
that it will be simple to make it a house security system.

7) You can do some cool DSP based stuff like SDR(Software Defined
Radio).You can do GSM communications or DRM(Digital Radio Mondiale)
decoding using a general purpose computer and some C code.

8) Or you could use real DSP chip to do simple mp3 decoding. With a
lil bit of knowledge of FIR filters, Kaiser windows etc. and FFT , you
can do something interesting. No, I don't know anything more than
this. This project appears somewhat non trivial.

9) You could buy a Nokia bluetooth dongle and develop a simple
bluetooth handheld. May not be trivial but you could learn Bluetooth.
:-)

10) Develop a simple voice recorder with a USB interface.
       	

These are some of the top of the mind ideas I have. None of them have
had the luxury of a protracted thought process. So I can't guarantee
success but it will certainly help you learn and do something
practically relevant.

Understand that success invariably comes after a few failures. Prepare
to fail first. Otherwise your success won't be sweet. :-)

Wish you Godspeed!

love,
Girish

remember from time to time that anything that is
worth knowing cannot be taught.

- Oscar Wilde

Taking this debate in a more generic level :
Is contributing to Foss good for a IT Professional / aspiring IT
professionals....?

My view on this:

I see this something similar to paying taxes.

Sure , we all have hesitation in paying taxes. Particularly when we see most
of our tax money is going waste in mindless projects.

So naturally any sensible person will raise this question: When my hard
earned money and my hard efforts are only going  waste why the hell should i
pay taxes and contribute ...?

I would not advise a person contribute to a foss project which is either
repetitive or not of any real use and is just of some academic interest.

It is like advising some one to honestly pay his taxes, when no convincing
benefits and envisaged.

Therefore it is very important that the Foss efforts and Foss project
initiatives have to be really well thought ones. Foss projects, at the end
have to  be  addressing real  issues and be providing really
useful solutions to issues.

Having said that i would like to also point out the dangers of not
contributing to common causes like the tax and the foss.

a bit of history :

In the 9/10th century a few ministers to the king of northern India ( fore
fathers of the pritiviraj-samyukda) proposed to build a strong wall,
completely closing the kiber pass.( something similar to the the great wall
of china) .

The ministers advised the kind to levy a special "wall tax" on the people
for the construction.

But the people agitated and refused to pay the "wall tax". After some time,
the tax proposal and the wall project was dropped.


Many years after drooping the proposal Ghajini Mohammed was planning to
visit india  and found the kiber pass  to be the effortless way to enter. He
succeeded and looted  all the wealth and returned .

He used that route to repeatedly visit india in the 9th/10th century. In a
span of 20 years he made a total of 17 visits. Not even once he failed.
Every time he went back with tones and tonne of gold snatched from the
public.

When the brilliant ministers  proposed to completely close the kiber pass by
building a strong wall, all the people should have contributed immediately
and should have completed it .

unlike the thousands of kilometer length of the great wall of china, this
wall needed to be just a few kilometres long . The money and effort needed
to build the wall was not even point  one percent of what was lost for not
contributing the construction of the wall.

The morel of the story : Contribute for the right common cause.
( btw this is not a story.
this is a recorded history of india)

So, both for Foss development and tax payment, after understanding
the dangers to him on non - contribution , one has look for tangible
benefits of his contribution to himself and others, and then contribute
developing the project.

Invite opinions in academic interest :-)

According to you 10 percent of the professors / lecturers were good.
Can you claim that 25% of the students are good enough engineers ? If
we start comparing the salaries / facilities / hardships, can I say
that the output from "We engineers" is not good enough.

I am by training a physicist and researcher (theoretical, that too!!),
and I am least interested in judging anybody, leave alone engineers.
But it is a fact that many of the  present day engineers think that
they do not need any of the basics. Unfortunately, that is not the
case. As a physicist, I could produce an idea which can be used by
other physicists and, yes, engineers. However, an engineer has to
create things which are used by "lay" people -- the mantra of
"user-friendliness". Hence more responsibility and more creativity --
and naturally more complaints / criticisms.

Srinivasan.

Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> In addition, I'm still trying to figure out what all Girish has 
> written has to do with insulting pure researchers in general and 
> Tanenbaum in particular.

Heh., I read the archives and well., I'm quite confused about his claim
on 'Experience in software industry'.

Mr.Girish.,

<quote>
> It is an academic project by Tananbaum. He may be a great teacher and
>  an academician but one should remember that he is not an engineer.
</quote>

FYI., Andrew S Tanenbaum., is an Engineer. Not just for his degrees and
PhDs but for the knowledge and command he has in his field. He is one of
the few people who can comment on advanced operating system concepts
which current day OSes dont even have a clue about.

Giving derogatory remarks about such a respected person reflects poorly
on you. Please do your research before issuing comments like this on a
mailing list.

And., Linus is NOT god. Just because Linus makes a statement it does not
mean it is right. The reason for the success of 'Linux' is not because
it was the most kick ass kernel at the time. But rather because., no
other kernel was complete and Free at that time. It was a timing issue
which sparked interest in the project and the community poured in and
made it a success. If Minix was out Free during that time., Linus would
not have even bothered writing another kernel. And so., because the
Linux kernel became popular it does not mean that Tanenbaum's argument
was wrong. Any person who has a little bit of knowledge in that field
(operating systems) would tell you that.

<quote>
> Anyway forget Tananbaum.

> Understand my idea clearly. I want everyone to get practical.

> Close your textbooks, unlearn some of what your professors taught 
> you, forget stuff like multithreading is the way to go and that 
> databases should be used for storing records and all that.
</quote>

I did not quite understand what you are trying to say here. Are trying
to say that 'Databases', 'Multithreading', etc. are theoretical topics
which are just for the book and not for real world problems? If you are
going to dismiss something like 'Multithreading'., I'm sure you'd not
have bothered to even look into algorithms or data structures.

I can imagine the quality of code minted by so_called_engineers of your
vision.

<quote>
> OTOH, take up a real life problem, solve it. Make it an academic
> project. Who is stopping you from that?
</quote>

Interesting. Where do you think concepts such as "Multiprogramming
systems", "IPC", "real-time responsive systems", "Object oriented
programming", "Orthogonal persistence", "Reliable systems", "Verifiable
software systems", etc.. come from? You think it dropped out of a
fresh-man's head and got picked by researchers to research on?

I've been using Outlook for a long while. In the line of work I do, a 
good lot of information is part of the mailbag. So much so that mailbag 
size runs  up to 1.5 - 2GB despite cleanup and archiving of all mails 
older than 6 months to a different PST file.

Problems I face:
1. slow startup.
2. pretty slow mail search within Outlook. (thus I use google desktop 
search for mails too)
3. crashes which lead to pst recovery the next time around.
4. hangs.

I've used Linux a lot and have played around, installed and implemented 
mailing systems - mostly server end.

I'd like to know if anyone has attempted running a popular graphical 
mail client like Thunderbird/Evolution on Linux that handles such large 
mail files in a decent manner.

Things that I'd like to get feedback on:
1. ability to strip attachments from mails and maintain them in a 
separate directory with a link from the mail.
2. archiving based on age of mail.

Mohan

Well, today Companies out there need immidiate solutions and never bothered
whether one is good with basics. For example, anybody can start learning
Python even if he doesnt know C or C++. So, in the Industry, they might ask
for Python and he gets going. Later, he understands that the basic C/C++ is
required and starts learning.

Today, I find, me not taking much time in learning a new language. I learnt
many in no time , and also the basics of that particular language and
others. Its like, Professors HAVE to know everything in regard of the topic
, but /Engineers may not. A Good Enginner is one who can be accoustomed to
any field (in his related parent field) he is put in. Am a Software Engg and
I should not say, I can work only with GNU/Linux Platform. If so, I can be
put down very easily. The same, If i tell, I can work in GNU/Linux and also
in Windows and also in Mac, then my strength increases and I have lots of
oppurtunities.Thats how an Engineer lives.

I do agree that all 25% would not be good engineers, but sure, the good ones
would be more than that 10% of my Professors list.

My personal take is, leave those bad ones and MANY things can be done from
the good ones and thats what is happening in India today.

Its just not that Engineers are bad and Professors are not and vice versa.

And one more thing that stops Students to enter into GNU/Linux carrer, as
far as I have seen is the EXPERIENCE column. Most of the GNU/Linux hackers
would be good at their young age itself and many develop their skills during
their College days/projects.Companies want atleast 2 to 3 years of work
experience in the GN/Linux field and how can these people, eventhough they
might be very good, apply ?. They are ignored just becoz of this. This is
what has to change in India IMO. The EXPERIENCE should be, experience in
that particular field which is being asked , but not WORK.

Srinivasan.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Aug 30 12:06:36 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Aug 31 00:37:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sound not working in Kubuntu
In-Reply-To: <72288b670608301016n2311accbie144c01771485607@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060830190636.74330.qmail@web50213.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Vidhya Shankar,

--- Vidhya Shankar L <lv.shankar@gmail.com> wrote:
> Everything is fine but I can't hear any sound on my
> system. I've checked for
> obvious hardware problems. 

Can you run alsamixer on the terminal and check your
volume, PCM settings? Make sure they are not muted or
set low.

> I also happen to have my motherboard support CD
> which has some "Linux
> Drivers" for "sound" etc. Can anyone tell me how to
> use them? Or possibly
> give an alternative solution.

Open a terminal and post output of the following:

/sbin/lsmod
/bin/lspci
ls -l /dev/dsp

Note, you can redirect output to a file:

/sbin/lsmod > lsmod.txt

(Don't send them as attachments, just paste them
inline and send it - they are useful for debugging).
 
> Asus motherboard

Ouch. I have always seen people having problems with
it.

SK

> _______________________________________________

> <password> <address>"
> in the subject or body of the message.  
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc
> 
When I first tried out Dapper Drake Beta, 3 months ago, I had similar 
problem with sound. I was able to hear at most some sound with a loud 
buzz accompanying the sound. But, when Aanjhan and I were trying things 
out, suddenly it too stopped. We checked at bugzilla and found it was a 
known issue with Lenovo Laptop and but the bug was fortunately fixed in 
the later releases of the kernel from Ubuntu. I then updated my kernel 
for 2.6.15.23 to 2.6.15.25, which got me sound in the headphone but 
still my speakers were dead. I survived with this for a couple of weeks, 
when I updated to 2.6.15.26. After updating, I booted on my computer and 
  surprisingly I was able to hear the login music. Everything got right.

As shakthi said, first check your alsamixer output, especially for the 
PCM value. Generally, it is off by default. It has happened to me 
sometime, when I do some update/install of sound related plugin that PCM 
goes to 'MM' from 'OO'. If I turn it back to 'OO', the sound comes again :)

If this doesn't work, check out bugzilla for any known issues for your 
soundcard and any fixes are offered. If not bugs are found, then create 
a new one and wait for the community to come to your help ;)

Parthan ('technofreak')

Dev,

Sorry that you got demotivated. LUG is always a place where people from 
various backgrounds and ideologies come together, with a similar 
interest rather than calling it single interest. We differ in our 
principles, thoughts, ideologies, philosophies and the way we interpret 
things. So, the chance of flame wars is too high and till now flame wars 
has been an occasional entertainer to many of the luggies. Note 
entertainer doesn't mean that this is for fun, it means we take in a 
positive sense.

LUG is a common place where we share our views and when doing so, 
clashes of interest and ideas do occur. It should be taken in the 
healthy sense, and it has been so far. Otherwise ilugc wouldn't be as 
active as it is now. :)

As far as your motivation is considered, I (though am not a guru or 
expert in any sense, but just an active physical contributor to ilugc) 
will tell you one single advice - Hear what 1000 people say, but do what 
your heart says. Criticism will always haunt you at every part of your 
life, you will hear things which will make you feel the world to be 
ugly, but still if your heart says you can do something then just do it. 
Don't think about the end result, don't get turned down by criticism and 
initial failures. Just keep doing what you feel doing, provided it 
doesn't affect others negatively. Its better to learn by making mistakes 
than being all the way conscious of making none. Every successful man's 
career starts by doing something which they themselves call as "mistake 
I did in my life" and its nothing wrong in doing it.

so, if you are thinking of doing a project just do it and see. Don't 
keep thinking whether it will come out well or not. Trying out is always 
better than thinking out, especially with software ;)

Hi,

On 8/31/06, Dev Anand <deva.security@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> So going by your words that why re-invent the wheel , I would strongly
> disagree with you because its not re-inventing the wheel , its finding
> their way in the new world FS.


I would like to give you my own experiences.

I decided to do a Collaborative Tool as my last semester project and the
project was associated with ISRO. Now, Collaborative Tool is a tool which
would have Video Conferencing(audio&video),Application
Sharing,Whiteboard,Text Chat etc., in one application.

Now,how did we start off ?. We knew very well, the first part - Video
Conferencing can be easily achieved by VLC(Video Lan Client) and modifying
the GUI of VLC should help us a lot.And for others, we got separate
application, made VLC GUI as the main Interface and integrated eveything
with few little tweaks and fixes to fit in our needs.Ofcourse, it was not
that easy and understanding the working of VLC Gui and functions was a major
task and yes, VLC Community did help us.

If I had not chosen VLC and started off from the ground , by writing my own
codecs,drivers for all webcams....do you think thats a viable solution ?

Another example is with my Yoper Installer. As everybody would do, I started
this Yoper Installer (YIS) from scratch. I was very proud to start from
scratch, but was I able to give a good installer till today?. NO.There is a
basic version of the installer available but it wouldnt be that great. I
knew where my mistake was. I tried recreating the stuffs what already others
have done. Then, I tried looking around Anaconda installer,Mandrake
installer,Freespire installer,PCLinuxOS installer,Mepis Installer. I would
be coming up with what installer to use for Yoper very soon.Now, the job is
easier and also it wouldnt take much time to comply the original installer
to fit into Yoper needs.

Still, another example is, I always wanted to create a simple,yet effective
desktop distro. I had my own ideas and thoughts which I had not seen in any
distro. I started off with , Ok- I will create my own distro!. When I saw
about Freespire and Linspire, I saw everything that I thought was already
being implemented and without hesitating I joined Freespire and Linspire and
today I work with them too.

I think I was clear on actually what is "re-inventing the wheel". And
students should choose innovative and creative projects and I would
reccommend projects which would add extra functionalities to the existing
ones or totally a new one.


--

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

Hi Vidhya Shankar,

--- Vidhya Shankar L <lv.shankar@gmail.com> wrote:
> Everything is fine but I can't hear any sound on my
> system. I've checked for
> obvious hardware problems. 

Can you run alsamixer on the terminal and check your
volume, PCM settings? Make sure they are not muted or
set low.

> I also happen to have my motherboard support CD
> which has some "Linux
> Drivers" for "sound" etc. Can anyone tell me how to
> use them? Or possibly
> give an alternative solution.

Open a terminal and post output of the following:

/sbin/lsmod
/bin/lspci
ls -l /dev/dsp

Note, you can redirect output to a file:

/sbin/lsmod > lsmod.txt

(Don't send them as attachments, just paste them
inline and send it - they are useful for debugging).

> Asus motherboard

Ouch. I have always seen people having problems with
it.

SK

Hi,

IT@School GNU/Linux is a single CD customised GNU/Linux distribution
containing the typical software tools required by an high school
student or teacher. Apart from a host of typical desktop applications
it also contains various educational applications like TuxPaint,
Ghemical, Kalzium, DrGeo, Gcompris etc.

The CD was developed by IT@School Project in association with Free
Software Foundation of India (www.gnu.org.in).

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Thu Aug 31 11:29:24 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Thu Aug 31 11:28:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding projects for engineers
Message-ID: <1192.61.247.255.57.1157003964.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

I have been reading Girish's emails and the many responses from different
quarters with much interest.

Girish raises some interesting points which must not be overlooked just
because many dispute his comments about Tanenbaum - I am referring to his
comments that Tanenbaum is a researcher and not an engineer.

I think I see what Girish is trying to say here - correct me if I am
wrong, but I think his assertion was that there are many people in India
with the theoretical knowledge but very few with applied skills and
knowledge. I must say that I am in complete agreement with Girish on this.

The indian education system is geared towards making it very difficult to
get an entry into the educational institution, but it makes the process of
passing out of the institution with a degree/other-qualification
remarkably simple even if one doesn't have the requisite skills.

That is, it is difficult to enroll as a student in a higher education
system (eg: an engineering college), but once you are in, you can walk out
with a degree (even if it is a degree in a professional, applied field)
quite easily without having any of the required skills.

Letting all and sundry get these qualifications just because they managed
to get their feet in through the door is particularly dangerous in the
case of professional disciplines and courses. Someone who claims to be a
civil engineer may have no idea as to how to go about constructing a
building even though he has a degree which indicates that he does.

I personally feel that it should be the other way around - it should be
simple enough to get an entry into most institutions, but only the most
talented, and the skilled should be allowed to walk away with a degree.

Some systems even in India work this way already - for instance, the
Association of Chartered Accountants has strict rules for determining who
is allowed to pass with a certification and they will allow only a small
percentage of people to pass every year.

Another thing which I particularly like about the CA system is that it
mandates that all applicants go through a system of apprenticeship for a
period of 3 year (I think) before they can apply for taking the CA final
exam - and I can definitely say that an accountant with 3 years of
experience working under other accountants in a professional capacity will
really know his stuff rather more than an engineering student will know
engineering at the end of 3 years of study.

The association of chartered accountants wants to ensure that they don't
have someone bearing their certification who will bring their organization
disrepute. They ensure this by making sure that only the most deserving
get it. Sadly, this is missing in other organizations across the country.

(NOTE: I am not referring to the ethical standards of CAs. That is a
different discussion altogether. I am referring to just applied skills
here)

I think the standards of engineering will improve drastically if a similar
system of apprenticeships and very-difficult-to-pass examinations and
mandatory tightly-controlled-and-assessed project system is put in place.

There are just too many people who walk around with engineering degrees
who frankly don't deserve it. I think many of them are guilty of
misrepresentation and misleading the public when they claim to be
engineers/doctors when they just don't know the subject. Its like putting
a "100% Fat Free" sticker on a slab of cheese.

<SHOCKING-BUT-TRUE-ANECDOTE-WARNING>
I interviewed a "Electronics Engineer" a few months ago here in Chennai.
He was a recent graduate and was working elsewhere for a few months. I
asked him to explain the benefits of a NAND Gate. To my shock, he replied
that he didn't know what a NAND Gate is! Only thing worse is a doctor not
knowing what a blood cell/virus/bacteria is! How was this guy allowed to
walk out with an engineering degree?!
</SHOCKING-BUT-TRUE-ANECDOTE-WARNING>

<SHOCKING-BUT-TRUE-ANECDOTE-WARNING>
A highly experience chemical engineer I know told me how he has problems
finding chemical engineers these days with enough skills to atleast
balance an equation.
</SHOCKING-BUT-TRUE-ANECDOTE-WARNING>

Our education system for professional disciplines is a mess - it stresses
theory and does not stress applied skills nearly as much as it should.

I can safely wager that there are many engineers (I am referring to the
electrical/electronics engineers here) even from the premier engineering
schools of this country who cannot assemble even a door bell by themselves
if their lives depended on it.

Thank you and regards,
PK

From manokaran at gmail.com  Thu Aug 31 11:30:40 2006
From: manokaran at gmail.com (Mano)
Date: Thu Aug 31 11:30:49 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] a project idea
Message-ID: <7bf1bec50608302300x39c9c528ndfe4456455228cef@mail.gmail.com>

Seems to be high season for project ideas :-) . Here's one from me:

An open source implementation of a solution to the dynamic job shop
scheduling problem (DJSSP). Don't be misled into thinking this only applies
to production planning in manufacturing industries. Thats the classical case
for which much research has been done (surprisingly most research only
covers the JSSP - a 'D" before that is considered one of the hardest of NP
hard problems). Modern applications for this will be BPOs (eg. allocating
froms to be processed to people). It applies to any situation where a set of
jobs are to be allocated to a finite set of resources.

Since it is an NP hard problem, there is no point in trying to find the most
optimal solution. Instead, the focus is to find good enough 'feasible'
solutions. The prevailing view is that genetic algorithms are well suited
for these kinds of problems. There are a few articles about this on the web
but no implementations. So, if you can do this, it can get you academic,
industry as well as hacker recognition.

regds,
mano

On 8/31/06, Prem Kurian Philip <prem@songbirdtech.com> wrote:
> Our education system for professional disciplines is a mess - it stresses
> theory and does not stress applied skills nearly as much as it should.

I started a small program 3 years ago and have been pretty successful.
Identify an worthy apprentice and train one-on-one for about a year.
Aim for excellence, and teach the apprentice everything you know.  So
far, I've "trained" 4 people and they have now found bigger and better
opportunities else where (some of them may be lurking on this list).

Hopefully, your apprentice will imbibe the same culture and start
training others in the same fashion.  If you've seen the movie
"Pay it Forward", you'll understand the philosophy.

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Thu Aug 31 14:59:46 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Thu Aug 31 14:58:25 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding projects for engineers
Message-ID: <1359.61.247.255.57.1157016586.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

>> Our education system for professional disciplines is a mess - it stresses
>> theory and does not stress applied skills nearly as much as it should.

>I started a small program 3 years ago and have been pretty successful.
>Identify an worthy apprentice and train one-on-one for about a year.
>Aim for excellence, and teach the apprentice everything you know.  So
>far, I've "trained" 4 people and they have now found bigger and better
>opportunities else where (some of them may be lurking on this list).

>Hopefully, your apprentice will imbibe the same culture and start
>training others in the same fashion.  If you've seen the movie
>"Pay it Forward", you'll understand the philosophy.

>- Raja

Great to hear that you are doing something like that. It is perhaps the
best way to impart skills - the old gurukul system primarily worked that
way where a senior person with experience and skill taught younger
aspirants the skills. No education system can beat the one you have
described.

In this modern age with the vast numbers of students, we will perhaps need
a more formalized system which perhaps doesn't work as well as the
one-on-one system you are using at present - but nonetheless, one which is
better than the current system. CA is an example of such a system - you
will rarely find a CA who doesn't know his job.

I believe firmly that engineering students must start working in
engineering companies in core engineering jobs starting from perhaps the
third semester (2nd year) and attend classes in the evenings. It won't be
easy working on the shop floor for 3 years straight; and this will keep
out those "engineers" who are there for the glamour but want none of the
hands-on toil. At the end of 3 years, these students will have a far
better grasp of the subject and also an understanding of what
specialization interests them. Also, the experience will go a long way in
making them suitable for employment.


PK
